questions.text: An intern was asked to observe a histological section of the esophagus. What type of cells are seen by him in the basal layer of the epithelium of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the esophagus is the stratified squamous epithelium. The basal layer of cells present in the stratified squamous epithelium is composed of columnar cells.

The stratified squamous epithelium is made up of several layers of cells:

  • The cells in the deepest layer of the epithelium are columnar
  • The cells in the middle layers are polygonal
  • The cells in the superficial layers are flattened squamous cells

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the given life cycle:
questions.solution:
The life cycle depicted in the above image is of Dracunculus medinensis (Guinea worm).

Humans are the definitive host. They get infected by drinking unfiltered water containing infected cyclops. Larvae come out once cyclops are killed in the stomach and penetrate the wall of the duodenum. They reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues and develop into adults.

The fertilized female worm grows and migrates within the connective tissues. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water like the leg (most common). Here, the gravid female worm secretes a toxin that causes a blister formation. The blister ruptures discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous L1 stage larvae.

The larvae survive for about a week in water. They are swallowed by the intermediate host- freshwater cyclops. The larvae penetrate the gut wall of the cyclops and develop into the infective third-stage larvae. The lifecycle continues when humans drink water containing infective cyclops.

Other options:

Option A: Wuchereria bancrofti passes its life cycle partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

 

 

Option B: The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host.

 

Option C:  Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host, and in mango flies/day-biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors.

questions.text: A patient with a history of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart. On examination, it is noticed that her weight for height is 20 per cent below of what is expected. Which of the following needs to be done?

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.solution:
Patients with weight for height 20 per cent below of what is expected, should be considered for hospitalization.

Dur­ing a hospitalized treatment program

  • Patients should be weighed daily, early in the morning after emptying the bladder.
  • Daily fluid intake and urine output should be recorded.
  • If vomiting occurs, hospital staff members must monitor serum electrolyte levels regularly and watch for the development of hypokalemia.

Because food is often regurgitated after meals, the staff may be able to control vomiting by making the bathroom inaccessible for at least 2 hours after meals or by having an attendant in the bathroom to prevent the opportunity for vomiting.

Psychotherapy:

  • Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy
  • Dynamic Psychotherapy
  • Family Therapy

Pharmacotherapy:

Pharmacological studies have not yet identified any medica­tion that yields a definitive improvement of the core symptoms of anorexia nervosa. Some reports support the use of

  • Cypro­heptadine
  • Amitriptyline
  • Clomipramine
  • Pimozide
  • Chlorproma­zine
  • Fluoxetine

questions.text: A physician is studying parameter x. She checks the parameter x of all patients using an automated apparatus and compares them to manual checking (considered by her as the gold standard). For patient A, she finds that the automated apparatus and manual checking give very different values. However, on checking 5 times with the automated apparatus, all 5 values obtained are similar to each other. What can be concluded about the automated apparatus?
questions.solution:
The automated apparatus has low validity (accuracy) but high precision.

Validity (accuracy) refers to what extent the test accurately measures which it sets out to measure. It refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values. The values obtained by the automated apparatus are very different from the true values, reducing the validity of the automated apparatus readings.

Precision (reliability or reproducibility) is a measure of repeatability of a test. That is, the test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under the same conditions. The 5 values obtained by the automated apparatus are close to each other, making it precise.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels <9.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
In the given population, 5 women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels < 9.5 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean. 
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean. 
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

In a normal distribution, 2 SD from the mean will have 95% of the participants. Therefore, 95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels of 10.5±2*0.5 = 10.5±1 =  9.5-11.5 g/dL.

The remaining 2.5% of women will have Hb >11.5 g/dL and 2.5% of women will have Hb level <9.5 g/dL.

2.5% of 200 = 5. Hence, 5 women will have Hb of <9.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text:
A woman in her second trimester comes to the PHC for her regular check-up. You give her advice regarding her nutritional requirement. How much should the increase be in her caloric intake per day?

PHC: Primary health care
questions.solution:
The caloric intake per day should be increased to 340 Kcal/day for a woman in her second trimester. 

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 kcal during the last 20 weeks. This intake is not equally divided during pregnancy. It is divided as 0, 340, and 452 kcal/day added to the estimated non-pregnant energy requirements in the first, second, and third trimesters, respectively. 

During the first six months of lactation, an increase of 600 Kcal/day is recommended, and from 7-12 months of lactation, an addition of 520 Kcal/day is recommended.

Pregnancy is a period where a mother will require additional nutritional requirements to support the healthy growth and development of the fetus. According to the recommended dietary allowances by the Indian council of medical research (ICMR):

Protein

9.5g/day - 2nd trimester

22 g/day- 3 rd trimester

17g/day - First 6 months

13g/day - 7-12 months
Calcium 1000mg/day 1200mg/day
Iodine 220μg/day  280μg/day

Dietary Reference Intakes

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group
  • Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the individuals in a group

The EAR for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years) is 1500 Kcal/D.

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

questions.text: The pregnancy test kit launched by the government is called:
questions.solution:
Nishchay is a pregnancy test kit introduced by the government.

NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring of TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB)

Nikusth is the web-based solution for monitoring of Leprosy patients.

Axshya is the project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. If the structure marked in red arrow is injured, which of the following clinical manifestations would you expect?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in red is identified to be the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve). Injury to this nerve will result in loss of ankle eversion.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and ankle eversion
  • Diminishes sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved
  • High stepping gait is seen in this nerve injury

The common peroneal nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. 

It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The course of the common peroneal nerve is shown below.

Other options:

Plantar flexion is caused by the action of muscles gastrocnemius and soleus innervated by the tibial nerve. 

Ankle inversion is caused by the action of the tibialis posterior muscle innervated by the tibial nerve.

Ankle reflex (S1, S2) is characterised by the plantar flexion of the foot when the calcaneal tendon is struck with a percussion hammer. Thus it is lost in lesions of the tibial nerve.

questions.text:
Identify the condition in which the given findings are seen.

Platelet counts-Normal

BT-Increased

PT and aPTT- Normal

Flow cytometry - Decreased CD41 and CD61
questions.solution:
The given findings of increased BT and normal PT, aPTT is suggestive of Platelet aggregation disorders. Decreased CD41 and CD61 (Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa) is suggestive of Glanzmann Thrombasthenia.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disease which occurs due to inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa. There is normal platelet morphology and normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, absent or decreased clot retraction, and normal platelet aggregation in the presence of ristocetin. Platelet aggregation is absent in the presence of epinephrine, collagen, arachidonic acid, ADP. Under flow-cytometric analysis, CD41 and CD61 levels are markedly decreased or absent.

Acquired GT is seen with platelet transfusions, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myelodysplastic syndrome, hairy cell leukaemia, and acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation

questions.text: A 21-year-old male comes to the OPD with a peculiar complaint of feeling a sense of unfamiliarity with a familiar person/situation followed often by a brief period of amnesia. Further workup reveals he has temporal lobe epilepsy. The peculiar presenting complaint is known as:
questions.solution:
A sense of unfamiliarity with a familiar situation is known as Jamais Vu whereas the sense of familiarity with an unfamiliar situation is known as Déjà vu. Jamais entendu is a sense of unfamiliarity when hearing something familiar

 Jamais vu and deja vu are associated with pre ictal symptoms that may be seen in those with temporal lobe epilepsy/ complex partial seizures. 

 

  • Formication is a false sense of insects crawling on one's skin. It is also known as cocaine bugs.

questions.text: The COVID-19 outbreak is a type of ______________.
questions.solution:
This outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a propagated epidemic.

The propagated epidemic results from a person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. In this scenario, the cases of COVID occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease. Other examples of a propagated epidemic include Hepatitis A and Polio.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is single exposure from a point source.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposures epidemics:

  Point source, single exposure epidemic Point source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A patient with liver cirrhosis is scheduled to undergo a laparotomy for a perforated appendix. According to the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score, which of the following parameters will you not use for this patient?
questions.solution:
Creatinine is not included in the Child–Turcotte–Pugh score or Child-Pugh scoring system. 

It is used to assess the surgical mortality of cirrhotic patients undergoing intra-abdominal operations.

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

The Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension. It is also useful in predicting the surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations performed in cirrhotic patients.

Child-Turcotte-Pugh class and overall surgical mortality rates:

  • Class A = 5–6 points - Well-compensated - 10% mortality
  • Class B = 7–9 points - Decompensated and significant  functional compromise - 30% mortality
  • Class C = 10–15 points - Severerly decompensated - 75-80% mortality

Prognosis of the various CTP classes:

Class 1-year survival rate  % 2-year survival rate %
A 100 85
B 80 60

questions.text: A 15-year old child has a mental age of 5 years. He is suffering from ________
questions.solution:
The above child with an IQ between 20 to 35 is suffering from a severe intellectual disability.

So here IQ = (5/15) x 100 = 33.33

A child with IQ of 33.33 will have severe mental retardation.

Related Pearl: Intelligence Quotient

  • The intelligence quotient is a score that can be obtained from several standardized tests to assess human intelligence.
  • Historically, IQ = Mental age x 100/ Chronological age
  • Here, the mental age is obtained from intelligence tests.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old recently married woman committed suicide because of dowry torture by her husband's family. Under which of the following sections is this incident covered?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA
questions.solution:
This incident can be considered a dowry death. Dowry death is defined under section 304B IPC.

According to this, if the husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage; they shall be deemed to have caused her death. The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years, but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, who is a known case of PVD, comes with complaints of rest pain. Which of the following values of ankle and brachial pressure correspond to the values that can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
An ABPI of <0.5 is associated with rest pain. The ABPI of 0.4, seen in case of option D, Ankle - 48/36mm Hg, Brachial - 120/80mm Hg, will be corresponding to that of rest pain.

ABPI = Systolic Pressure at Ankle/ Systolic Pressure in the arm(Brachial)

=48/120 = 0.4

 

Other options:

A - ABPI =1.25

B - ABPI = 1

C - ABPI = 0.75

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged male who is drowsy is brought to the ER, by the police. On examination, he speaks inappropriately, provides different histories to intern, nurse, police. Imaging shows atrophic mammillary bodies. Labs show methylmalonic acid levels to be raised and folate deficiency. Which of the following would you use to treat him?

choices.text: IVF followed by thiamine followed by glucose
Thiamine followed by IVF followed by glucose

questions.solution:
Thiamine followed by glucose should be used to treat the patient to prevent the development of Wernicke encephalopathy. 

The features in the abovesaid clinical scenario such as drowsy state, incoherent and inappropriate speech, atrophic mamillary bodies (typically seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome), vitamin B12 deficiency (as given by increased methyl malonate levels), and folate deficiency point towards various complications of chronic alcoholism

Thiamine deficiency causes impaired glucose breakdown. Administration of glucose will worsen the patient condition.

Thiamine is required for glucose breakdown and it is required for the following enzymes:

  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Transketolase

Thiamine deficiency can be diagnosed by a decrease in RBC transketolase

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 33-year-old male who is being assessed for peripheral vascular disease, a Fuchsig’s test is performed. Which of the following is true about this test?

choices.text: It tests for the tibial artery blood flow.
The patient sits cross-legged with the limb being assessed below the other limb.
Rhythmic oscillations of the leg indicate significant stenosis
Patient’s attention is diverted in the form of taking history

questions.solution:
The patient’s attention is diverted in the form of taking a history.

Fuchsig’s Test:
It is performed to detect popliteal pulsation. The patient is asked to sit cross-legged with the leg being examined resting above the other limb - such that the popliteal fossa of the leg being examined rests on the knee of the other limb as indicated in the image.

The crossed leg will show oscillatory movements of the foot which occur synchronously with the popliteal pulse and the oscillations will be absent if the popliteal artery is blocked.

questions.text: In postoperative patients, what is the strength of the incision site in comparison with normal skin following suture removal at the end of 1 week?
questions.solution:
When sutures are removed, usually at 1 week, the wound strength is approximately 10% of that of normal skin.

This increases rapidly over the next 4 weeks. Wound strength reaches approximately 70 to 80% of normal by 3 months. Beyond this, there is not much improvement.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations do you expect to see in a patient with ferrochelatase deficiency?

choices.text: Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III
Increased urinary ALA and porphyrobilinogen III (PBG)
Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal coproporphyrin III
Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX

questions.solution:
Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX is seen in ferrochelatase deficiency. This leads to Protoporphyria.

Other options:

Option A: Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III are seen in ALA dehydratase deficiency.

Option B: Increased urinary ALA and porphyrobilinogen III (PBG) are seen in uroporphyrinogen I synthase deficiency causing acute intermittent porphyria. This enzyme is also called PBG deaminase or hydroxymethylbilane synthase.

Option C: Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III, and fecal coproporphyrin III is seen in coproporphyrinogen oxidase deficiency causing hereditary coproporphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:

questions.text: A 20-day old baby is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go to the nearby hospital. Which national programme has provisions to benefit this woman to take her baby to the health facility?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.

Assured 18 service guarantees are provided to all pregnant women under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative to provide assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare at no cost and zero tolerance for denial of services for every woman and newborn visiting the public health facility. It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths, morbidities and provide a positive birthing experience.

questions.text: In a study of a group of 40 people, a physiologist is studying the pacemaker actions of the sinoatrial node and the action potentials of each one of them were plotted in the graph given below. The ion channels predominantly responsible for the phase 0 marked in the graph is?
questions.solution:
The ion channels predominantly responsible for phase 0 marked in the graph is the L-type calcium channels. 

The graph in the given image represents the action potential of the SA (sinoatrial) node (i.e., the pacemaker potential). In the figure, phase 0 corresponds to the impulse/upstroke and, this is predominantly due to the opening of 'L' (long-acting) type of calcium channels resulting in an intracellular movement of the calcium ions down its electrochemical gradient.

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the SA node is -55 to-60 millivolts. Phases of this potential are: 

  • Phase 0 - Upstroke wave. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3 - Downstroke wave. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/ If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of the prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-(transient) type Ca2+ channel. The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate. 

Clinical aspect:

i) Vagal stimulation activates the cholinergic fibres to the SAN and leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by depolarizing effect of funny Na+ (If) channel on M2 receptor stimulation. There is also decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) causing the decreased firing of the T-type Ca2+ channel. Similar action is seen upon administering digitalis. 

ii) The frequency of SA node discharge is increased when the temperature rises. Thus, fever is usually associated with tachycardia.

questions.text: A 30 year old man comes with the complaints of difficulty in swallowing and food getting stuck in his throat. He also gives a history of atopic dermatitis. The endoscopic finding of the patient is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given endoscopic image shows multiple esophageal rings, longitudinally oriented furrows, and punctate exudate, which are the hallmark findings in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The symptoms of food impaction and dysphagia, along with the history of atopic dermatitis also point towards the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis:

  • Chronic immunologically mediated disorder
  • Symptoms: Adults- food impaction, dysphagia; children- feeding intolerance, GERD-like symptoms.
  • The cardinal histologic feature is epithelial infiltration by large numbers of eosinophils
  • Endoscopically evident rings in the upper and mid portions of the esophagus
  • Typically refractory to high-dose proton pump inhibitor treatment.
  • Most patients are atopic- may have atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, and peripheral eosinophilia.
  • Treatment: dietary restrictions to prevent exposure to food allergens, such as cow milk and soy products, and topical or systemic corticosteroids.

questions.text: During the attempted intubation of a patient, the senior resident complains that the glottis is too anterior and asks the junior resident to perform a maneuver so that the senior resident would be able to visualize the glottis better as shown below. Identify the correct sequence of steps that the junior resident would have performed for obtaining such a result.
questions.solution:
The maneuver that the junior resident would have performed is the BURP maneuver, where a Backwards->Upwards->Rightwards pressure is applied externally so as to move an anteriorly positioned glottis posterior for getting better visualization.

You can visualize the step-by-step result of the maneuver in the video below.

Note:

BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was diagnosed with AIDS and was started on antiretroviral drugs. After 10 months patient came to OPD and examination revealed hands as shown. The following change is encountered with the use of which of the following antiretroviral agents?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Nail hyperpigmentation which is commonly encountered with the use of zidovudine. This is seen with chronic zidovudine administration. 

The adverse effects of Zidovudine are:

  • Fatigue, malaise, myalgia, anorexia, headache, insomnia
  • Erythrocytic macrocytosis
  • Nail hyperpigmentation
  • Myopathy
  • Bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and granulocytopenia 

The image below shows zidovudine induced nail hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: The anomaly shown in the image given below is mostly associated with ____________
questions.solution:
The anomaly shown in the image is caudal regression which is mostly associated with maternal diabetes.

It is a rare anomaly. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and, to a lesser degree, the lumbar vertebrae, and occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infant of a diabetic mother than in other infants.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge. She has no other complaints. On examination, greenish frothy discharge is present. No laboratory facilities are available. How would you proceed with management?

choices.text: Local treatment with clotrimazole vaginal pessary
Give oral secnidazole to the patient
Treat the patient and her husband with acyclovir

questions.solution:
The patient should be administered a single dose of secnidazole 2g orally as she has trichomonas vaginitis in her second trimester of pregnancy.

 

This patient in her second trimester of pregnancy has greenish, frothy vaginal discharge that is suggestive of trichomoniasis. However, since laboratory tests are not available, they cannot be confirmed. Using the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, she should be treated with oral secnidazole.

An alternate option is to use Tab. Tinidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 5 days.

Metronidazole pessary is preferred in the first trimester of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice that the jugular venous pressure (JVP) does not fall during inspiration and in fact, shows a paradoxical rise. Which of the following clinical conditions is least likely to be associated with the clinical finding seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration is known as Kussmaul's sign. It is not seen in Dilated Cardiomyopathy. 

Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure, the JVP falls. When there is an impairment in the filling or expansion of the right ventricle or a raise in the right atrial pressure, the blood backs up in the jugular veins. The backpressure causes an elevation or a failure in the appropriate fall in JVP during inspiration. It is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

It is also a common, isolated finding in patients after cardiac surgery without other hemodynamic abnormalities.

questions.text: An offense registered under which of the following IPC sections dealing with sexual offenses is bailable?
questions.solution:
Section 376B dealing with sexual intercourse by the husband upon his wife, without her consent, during separation is cognizable (only on a complaint of the victim) and bailable.

Punishment is imprisonment for not less than 2 years, which may extend to 7 years and with a fine.

Other options:

Option A: 376D deals with a woman being raped by one or more people in a group with common intention and shall be punished for imprisonment not less than 20 years and can go for a lifetime. 

Option B: 376A deals with a person committing an offense of rape and inflicting injury which causes death or causes the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state.

Option D: 376C deals with sexual intercourse by a person in authority (police officer, public servant, member of armed forces, management or staff of a jail, remand home or other places of custody and management or staff of a hospital) induces or seduces any female inmate of such jail, remand home, place or institution to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offense of rape.

Related Pearl: Sexual Offences

Punishment

64(1)

Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 10 years which may extend to imprisonment for life.

65(2) The person committing an offense of rape on a woman under 12 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years but which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine or with death 376AB

Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 5 years but which may extend to 10 years and with a fine. 376C

As per the The Gazette of India, from the Ministry of Law and Justice, Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita Document 2023

questions.text: A mother came to a children's clinic with her 3-year-old child for a wellness visit. Which of the following milestone is not seen in this kid?

choices.text: Sings songs, poems  and tells stories

questions.solution:
A 3-year-old kid can not sing songs, poems, and tell stories. These are language milestones seen at the age of 4.

The following milestones are achieved by a 3-year-old kid:

Fine motor milestones: 

  • Builds a tower of 9 blocks
  • Builds bridge with block
  • Copies circle

Gross motor milestones:

  • Walks upstairs with alternate foot
  • Rides tricycle

questions.text:
A man is rushed to the ER after losing control of his car and crashing into a tree. Examination findings are given below. What is the most likely cause for his presentation?

BP - 190/100 mmHg

Respiratory rate - 22/minute

GCS - 9/15

Temperature - 106.8 °F

Head and neck examination - Minor abrasions over the face

CNS - Quadriparesis. Pupils are 2 mm and unreactive.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pontine haemorrhage. Clinical features of pontine haemorrhage are:

  • Deep coma
  • Quadriparesis and multiple cranial nerve dysfunction
  • Decerebrate rigidity
  • Pin-point pupils
  • Hyperpnea, hyperpyrexia, severe hypertension, and hyperhidrosis

Option A: The presence of hyperpyrexia and pin-point pupils rule out the possibility of spinal cord trauma.

Option B: Morphine poisoning is a differential diagnosis for pin-point pupils. But it leads to slower respiratory rate, not tachypnea.

Option D: In ponto-medullary laceration, medullary involvement would cause respiratory depression, leading to apnea. But here tachypnea is noted.

questions.text: The most common manifestation that you would expect in a child infected by E. histolytica is:
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic cyst passage is the most common manifestation of E. histolytica.

 

Amebiasis:

  • Caused by Entamoeba histolytica
  • Trophozoites are responsible for tissue invasion and destruction.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements (6–8/day).
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus, heme-positive stool. Some may have only intermittent diarrhea alternating with constipation.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers. 
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • It occurs in <1% of infected individuals.
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess.
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography, computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text:
A plastic surgeon is planning a split-skin grafting procedure. Arrange the following phases in the correct order during the take of the graft?
  1. Neovascularization
  2. Imbibition
  3. Adherence
  4. Inosculation
questions.solution:
The correct order of phases during the take of a split skin graft at a recipient site is: imbibition → inosculation → neovascularization → adherence.

During the first 48 hours following the placement of the graft on the recipient site, the graft survives by getting nourishment from the plasma exudate from the capillaries of the recipient bed. This is known as imbibition or plasmatic circulation. After 48 hours, the cut-ends of the blood vessels of both the graft and the recipient bed align together to form anastomoses. This phase is called inosculation. Neovascularization refers to the in-growth of the blood vessels from the recipient site into the graft. The organization of the graft begins immediately following the placement of the graft due to the formation of a fibrin layer. The graft becomes adherent to the bed by days 10-14.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with a slowly progressive swelling and pain in the middle of his right leg. On X-ray, multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions are seen in the tibial diaphysis. Microscopic examination of a biopsied specimen reveals epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given tumors, adamantinoma is the most probable diagnosis based on the above-given clinical scenario.

Adamantinoma is a rare tumor of the diaphysis and presents commonly with pain. It usually presents in the 2nd or 3rd decade and arises from the epithelial cells. The most common site for adamantinoma is the tibia but it may also involve the ipsilateral fibula.

Radiological examination shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis and a honeycomb/soap bubble appearance. Histology shows epithelial basaloid cell islands in a fibrous stroma.

Complete excision of the tumor is the treatment of choice.

The following image shows an X-ray and gross specimen of an adamantinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is on ART for AIDS presented with difficulty in vision. Fundoscopic examination revealed the following finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following subfamilies of the Herpesviridae family encompasses the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy in an immunocompromised person is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. It belongs to beta viruses subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.

Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Alpha herpesviruses (e.g. HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus)
  • Beta herpes viruses (e.g. CMV)
  • Gamma herpesviruses (e.g. EBV)

Alpha viruses

 Beta viruses Gamma viruses
Short replicative cycle – 12-18 hours Replicative cycle - >24 hours variable
Latency – sensory ganglia Latency – salivary glands and other organs Lymphocyte specific
Ex: HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus

Ex: CMV

HHV6

HHV7

Ex: EBV

HHV8

questions.text: A child is brought with fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. How long should a child be isolated in this case to prevent further transmission?
questions.solution:
Isolation is recommended until 24 hrs after the initiation of effective therapy in bacterial meningitis. Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis.

Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy.
  • Patients should be in private rooms, and hospital personnel should wear a face mask when they are within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.

CSF findings in different types of meningitis

Parameter/Meningitis Bacterial  Tubercular  Viral 
CSF pressure Raised Raised Raised
Appearance Turbid Clear (cob-web formation) Clear
Glucose Decreased Decreased Normal
Protein High Very high slightly high
Chloride Low Very low Normal
Cells Neutrophils Lymphocytes Lymphocytes

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes with a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability. The ultrasound image of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability along with ultrasound findings of double decidual sign points to the diagnosis of normal pregnancy.

This sign can be seen in first-trimester transvaginal sonograms. In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that are - the outer decidua parietalis and the inner decidua capsularis. The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac. The presence of the yolk sac confirms the intrauterine location of the pregnancy. It usually appears by the 5th week.

Another indicator of early intrauterine pregnancy is the intradecidual sign. It is seen as an anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim.

Cardiac motion is usually seen after the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy characterized by in situ dissection is:
questions.solution:
Rokitansky technique is characterised by ‘in situ’ dissection, in part, combined with removal of organ blocks.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: A 74-year-old male presents to the ER with fever, cough, and breathlessness. Examination reveals nonpurulent conjunctivitis, and diffuse pharyngeal erythema. Pulmonary auscultation reveals scattered rales and wheeze.  Blood investigations reveal leukopenia and further workup confirms the diagnosis. The physician puts him on intranasal zanamivir BD for 5 days.  Which of the following is the most common extrapulmonary manifestation of the underlying condition that this patient has?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is that of a patient suffering from Influenza and the most common extrapulmonary manifestation that occurs is myositis. 

Points in favor of a diagnosis of Influenza:

  • Fever, cough, and breathlessness
  • Nonpurulent conjunctivitis, and diffuse pharyngeal erythema.
  • Scattered rales and wheeze.
  • Leukopenia
  • Treatment with intranasal zanamivir BD for 5 days.

Myositis is characterized by severe muscle pain, and the muscles are tender to touch. Labs reveal elevated creatinine phosphokinase levels and a myoglobinuria that may lead to renal failure also. Interestingly, myositis is seen more often in the case of influenza B.

Myocarditis and pericarditis are less frequently associated and have been reported only in selected epidemics, but an excess cardiovascular hospitalization is often seen associated with an influenza epidemic. Post-infectious acute demyelination encephalomyelitis can follow an influenza infection.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient died of respiratory distress due to pneumonia caused by COVID-19 (test positive). What should be recorded in the line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
COVID-19 will be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate, as it is the condition that gave rise to the antecedent cause (pneumonia).

In this patient:

  • I(a)- Disease directly leading to death: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • I(b)- Antecedent cause: Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Condition which gave rise to antecedent cause: COVID-19

Line II is used to record the contributory factors/causes such as diabetes or hypertension.

ICD allows identifying COVID-19 as the underlying cause of death. COVID-19 should be reported in a sequence ending with a terminal condition such as acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Other scenarios:

1. In case of pregnancy, puerperium, or birth leading to death in conjunction with COVID-19, record the sequence of events as usual.

For example: 

  • I(a)- Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • I(b)- Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Pregnancy complicated by COVID-19

2. If an HIV patient is dead due to ARDS caused by COVID-19

  • I(a)-Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • I(b)- COVID-19
  • Line II (co-morbidities)- HIV disease

3. Note that COVID-19 patients may die of other diseases or accidents, such cases are not deaths due to COVID-19 and should not be certified as such. In case you think COVID-19 aggravated the consequences of the accident/disease, it may be reported in part II.

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pruritus, easy fatiguability, and right upper quadrant discomfort. Laboratory investigations show elevation of GGT & ALP and the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A perimenopausal age group female presenting with fatigue, pruritus, elevated GGT & ALP, and antimitochondrial antibody positivity points to a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). 

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is characterized by chronic, non-suppurative inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It shows strong female preponderance. Most of the patients are asymptomatic; symptomatic patients present with fatigue out of proportion to the extent of liver disease or the age of the patient. Pruritus is another common complaint. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease such as hepatosplenomegaly and ascites may be seen, but may not be common. 

Laboratory findings show a cholestatic pattern of liver enzyme elevation, with increased levels of GGT and ALP. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are present in 95% of the patients with PBC. A liver biopsy is relevant in the setting of AMA-negative disease and would demonstrate florid duct lesions/ granulomas. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line treatment early in the disease course. It has been shown to slow the progress of the disease. Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for patients with decompensated liver disease due to PBC.

Other Options:

Option B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by the presence of p-ANCA, not A anti-mitochondrial antibody.

Option C: Autoimmune Hepatitis may present with fatigue, pruritus, ⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT. It is often positive for anti-smooth muscle antibodies.

Option D: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis involves the fatty infiltration of the liver in non-alcoholics and usually presents with elevated liver enzymes (⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT) in obese individuals.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

 Ulcerative colitis
Diagnosis Biopsy MRCP/ERCP-strictures 
Biopsy findings  Florid duct lesion (granuloma) Concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis    
Long-term complication Cirrhosis

Cirrhosis

Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following patients will have predominantly fibrosis of upper lobes of the lung?

choices.text: A 25 year old man with  bleomycin use
A 45 year old woman with scleroderma
A 55 year old man with asbestosis
A 35 year old woman with sarcoidosis

questions.solution:
A 35-year-old woman with sarcoidosis is the most likely to have fibrosis of the upper lobes of the lung.

Note: Most pneumoconiosis involves the upper lobes of the lung (coal worker's pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis), except asbestosis.

Most connective tissue disease predominantly involves the lower lobes of the lung (RA, scleroderma, SLE), except for ankylosing spondylitis. The use of bleomycin also causes lower lobe fibrosis. 

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

Mnemonic to easily remember the lobe of lung involved in CTD is:

Upper Lobe - CHARTS

  • Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis
  • Histiocytosis X (LCH)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis, ABPA
  • Radiation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Lower lobes - RAIDS

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Asbestosis
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: In the OPD, you inform a patient that he has bladder cancer. However, he replies saying, "No, I cannot have cancer. I don't smoke or drink”. What is the type of defense mechanism exhibited by the patient?
questions.solution:
Denial is the defense mechanism seen in this patient. Denial is a refusal to accept external reality because it is too threatening.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who suffered myocardial infarction was given aspirin and another drug that acts by inhibiting thrombin-induced activation of platelets. The other drug given along with aspirin is _________
questions.solution:
The other drug given along with aspirin in patients with myocardial infarction is Vorapaxar. Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of PAR-1(Protease Activated Receptor-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.  

Abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Eptifibatide is contraindicated in renal failure and tirofiban needs dose adjustment in cases of renal impairment.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar 
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Dipyridamole

questions.text: Which of the following structure is most likely to be injured in a wrist slash injury over the radial side of the left wrist?
questions.solution:
Median nerve is more likey to be injured in case of deep laceration of radial side of the wrist.

Wrist slash injuries:

A deep laceration on the radial side of the wrist may injure the radial artery, median nerve, flexor carpi radialis tendon, and palmaris longus tendon.

A deep laceration on the ulnar side of the wrist may injure the ulnar artery, ulnar nerve, and flexor carpi ulnaris tendon.

questions.text: A 13-year-old child who weighs 70 kg weight and is a known case of hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 13 year old obese child with hypothyroidism with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip and tenderness in Scarpa's triangle points towards a diagnosis of slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE).

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

  • Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign. Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck.

 

Other options-

Option A: Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

Option C: Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option D: Fracture neck of the femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include comorbidities (diabetes, chronic kidney, and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors).

questions.text: Activated charcoal is a:
questions.solution:
Activated charcoal acts as a mechanical antidote.

Mechanical antidotes- They neutralise poisons by mechanical action or prevention of their absorption.

  • Activated charcoal- It acts mechanically by adsorbing and retaining organic and mineral poisons within its pores and thus delays the absorption from the stomach.
  • Demulcents- substances that coat the gastric mucous membrane and thus do not permit the poisons to    cause any damage, e.g. milk, starch, egg-white, mineral oil, milk of magnesia, aluminium hydroxide gel, etc
  • Bulky food is the mechanical antidote to glass powder, wherein it acts by imprisoning its particles within its meshes.

Chemical antidotes- They neutralise poison by forming harmless or insoluble compounds or by oxidation when it is brought in contact with them.

  • Common salt decomposes silver nitrate, forming the insoluble silver chloride.
  • Potassium permanganate has oxidising properties. 1:5000 solution is used in opium poisoning.

Chelating agents (metal complexing agents) are used in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. The metal-agent complex is more water-soluble than the metal itself, resulting in higher renal excretion of the complex.

questions.text: A child of age 5 years presents with developmental delay and multiple episodes of seizure which could not be controlled with multiple drugs. A diagnosis of  Lennox–Gastaut syndrome is made. What is the characteristic electroencephalogram finding will you expect?

choices.text: 4-5 Hz spike and a slow background in wakefulness
1-2 Hz spike and slow wave and polyspike bursts in sleep
3 Hz spike and slow-wave with a fast background in wakefulness
Hypsarrhythmia and a slow background in wakefulness

questions.solution:
1-2 Hz spike and slow waves and polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness is the characteristic electroencephalogram findings in Lennox–Gastaut syndrome.

A child with developmental delay, intractable seizures with an electroencephalogram (EEG) showing 1-2 Hz spike, and polyspike bursts in sleep are suggestive of the diagnosis of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome. It typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. Consists of a triad of

  • Developmental delay
  • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
  • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

 

   Disease    Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome (Infantile spasms) Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

 

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

  • Oxcarbazepine 
  • Lamotrigine
  • Levetiracetam
  • Phenytoin

  • Sodium valproate
  • Levetiracetam 
  • Lamotrigine

  • Ethosuximide (drug of choice)
  • Sodium valproate
  • Lamotrigine

questions.text: The given finding is seen in:
questions.solution:
The given image shows short 4th metacarpal. This is seen in the following conditions:

  • Pseudohypoparathyroidism
  • Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism
  • Turner’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic
  • Post infection

questions.text: A patient was made to sleep in the position shown in the image for doing rectal surgery under spinal anaesthesia. If the surgery is prolonged, this position may cause death due to___________
questions.solution: In this case, the patient is made to sleep in a jack-knife position. Jackknife position is a position where the person's thighs and knees are driven against chest causing indirect compression of chest and restriction of breathing movements leading to positional asphyxia, resulting in death.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of massive painless vaginal bleeding. She also reported amenorrhea for 2 months. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of painless vaginal bleeding preceded by amenorrhea with histopathological examination of the endometrium revealing a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a specialized form of anovulatory DUB, seen in women aged 40 to 45 years. The typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:

  • Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm
  • Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as Swiss cheese pattern
  • Absence of secretory endometrium i.e. absence of corkscrew glands 
  • Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity
  • Corpus luteum is absent
  • One or both ovaries may contain a cyst

Other options

Option A: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

Option C: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow are present. 

Option D: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents as postmenopausal bleeding. There may be a history of PCOS or HRT indicating chronic estrogen exposure. There will be no Swiss cheese appearance on histopathological examination.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and swelling in the right inguinal region and female-type external genitalia. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is 46XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the affected individual has testes producing the androgens, but the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea - Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts - Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region - Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, due to loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix - Due to the production of mullerian inhibiting substance from the sertoli cells of the testis.
  • The XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Option A - Swyer's syndrome : although the karyotype is 46XY, the testes are dysgenetic and do not produce androgens. As a result the external genitalia resemble that of a female. The Mullerian system is preserved as the dysgenetic gonads fail to produce anti Mullerian hormone.

Option C - Mullerian agenesis is another cause of primary amenorrhea characterised by absent uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix and upper vagina. The secondary sexual characteristics are preserved due to the presence of estrogen producing ovaries. However the karyotype is 46XX.

Option D - Turner's syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping reveals 45XO and the individual has streak ovaries and absent secondary sexual features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Yes

Yes

No

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:
