questions.text: An elderly male who is a known hypertensive presented with pain and swelling in his great toe. The aspirated synovial contents visualized under polarized light microscopy showed negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. What is the antihypertensive that is preferred in such patients?
questions.solution:
Losartan is the preferred antihypertensive in patients having gout, because of its uricosuric action.

Losartan inhibits active sites for reabsorption and secretion in the proximal renal tubule, hence the net reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubule is decreased. Similarly, calcium channel blockers like amlodipine and diltiazem are found to lower the risk of gout.

Gout is a hyperuricemic metabolic condition, typically manifested by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to crystal formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints and connective tissue.

Acute recurrent gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and substantially swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of gout flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory hypoxic conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light. WBC count may be increased in synovial fluid. Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic hyperuricemia urate-lowering agents like xanthine oxidase inhibitors(eg. allopurinol and febuxostat) or uricosuric drugs (e.g. probenecid) can be used.

Other options-

Options A and D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors like captopril are associated with an increased risk of incident gout among patients with hypertension. β blockers such as propranolol, atenolol, metoprolol, timolol, and alprenolol, also have been shown to increase serum uric acid levels. 

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

questions.text: The anesthesia resident notices slightly increased blood loss during surgery and decides to administer a crystalloid solution as the transfusion point is not yet reached. Which one of the following solutions, would the resident administer in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, as the resident decides to administer a crystalloid solution he would give plasmalyte to increases the intravascular volume. Plasmalyte is a crystalloid solution which is iso-osmolar (osmolarity 294mosm/L) with plasma. In settings other than massive trauma,  lactated Ringer’s solution or Plasmalyte  can be administered in approximately three to four times the volume of the blood lost, until the transfusion point is reached

Composition of Plasmalyte:

  • Na-140 meq/L
  • Cl- 98 meq/L
  • K- 5 meq/L
  • Mg -3 meq/L
  • Acetate and gluconate

The absence of calcium makes it suitable as a diluent for RBC transfusion. And it has less tendency to promote interstitial edema when compared with normal saline.

The other options given above are colloids.

The colloids are of two types: 

  • Blood-derived- human albumin and plasma protein fractions
  • Semisynthetic- dextran, gelatin, hydroxyethyl starch

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital due to an exacerbation of her symptoms. Which of the following sign shown in the MRI image below is a characteristic sign of this disease?
questions.solution:
The MRI image shows Dawson's fingers.

Dawson's fingers are demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location). They are a characteristic feature of multiple sclerosis and presents as T2 hyperintensities.

MRI is the imaging of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity.

Other options:

  • Hot cross bun sign is a finding in the pons, seen in Multiple system atrophy.
  • Molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles gives the midbrain the appearance of a molar or wisdom tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome.
  • The Tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients with Sturge-Weber Syndrome.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student develops infectious mononucleosis. About 15 days later, he develops a high fever and his sore throat worsens. He has lost his ability to swallow and has severe neck and chest pain. Upon admission, he has signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. Which is the organism most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest the diagnosis of Lemierre’s disease. Fusobacterium necrophorum is most likely to be involved in this condition.

Fusobacterium necrophorum is a Gram-negative anaerobic bacillus that is very pleomorphic. It is involved in very severe oropharyngeal infections that can progress to a complicated and life-threatening condition called Lemierre’s disease. It is most commonly caused by Fusobacterium necrophorum. However, species of Bacteroides, Eikenella, Streptococcus, and Peptostreptococcus may also be implicated.

Lemierre’s disease often occurs after infectious mononucleosis in older children and young adults. It is characterized by internal jugular vein septic thrombophlebitis. This progresses to abscesses of the lungs, mediastinum, pleural space, and liver with sepsis. It presents with pharyngitis that is not resolving, associated with rigors, neck pain, and swelling.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding emergency contraception?

choices.text: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose can be used for emergency contraception
Ulipristal 3 mg can be used for emergency contraception

questions.solution:
Ulipristal 30 mg taken within 5 days is used for emergency contraception.

Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and prevents/delays ovulation, and suppresses the endometrium thereby preventing implantation.

Emergency contraceptives act by various methods. They can make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation or prevent fertilization by altering the tubal transport of sperm and/or ova.

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, levonorgestrel 0.75 mg one tablet can be taken within 72 h of unprotected intercourse and another 12 h later.

questions.text: Carcinoma endometrium with metastasis to para aortic lymph nodes belongs to ______ stage.
questions.solution:
Carcinoma endometrium with metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes with or without metastasis to pelvic lymph nodes belongs to stage 3 C2.

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic, obese man presented to the OPD. His lipid profile showed hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated LDL and VLDL. Which of the following vitamins can be used for treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and elevated LDL levels point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia or Type II hyperlipoproteinemia. Nicotinic acid (niacin or Vitamin B3) is used in treatment as a lipid-lowering drug. It lowers lipoprotein levels significantly.

Lipolysis in adipose tissues is the major producer of free fatty acids (FFA). The liver converts FFAs to triacylglycerol (TAG) which is used to synthesize very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is derived from VLDL in the plasma. By inhibiting this lipolysis in adipose tissues, niacin causes a decrease in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides. So it is particularly useful in the treatment of type IIb hyperlipoproteinemia, in which both VLDL and LDL are elevated. Niacin also increases high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels and is prescribed at a dose of 1.5 grams per day.

The main adverse effect of niacin is cutaneous flushing and pruritus which can be controlled by pretreatment with aspirin. Niacin also causes hepatotoxicity, GI toxicity, and hyperuricemia.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with neck nodes. Examination of left ear reveals a dull tympanic membrane, deafness and tinnitus. On tympanogram, a Type B curve is obtained. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

The given scenario of neck nodes (cervical lymphadenopathy) in a 70-year-old male (5th -7th decade) with unilateral serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane and Type B tympanogram) are all suggestive of a nasopharyngeal growth, probably carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking. It commonly occurs in males in the 5th to 7th decade. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex 
    • CN II - exophthalmos 
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Examination of the ear shows a dull tympanic membrane and audiometry shows a Type B curve due to the presence of fluid in the middle ear. The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult suggests nasopharyngeal growth.

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to the involvement of the CN X may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Other options:

Option A: Chronic suppurative otitis media presents with ear discharge and perforation will be seen on examination.

Option B: On otoscopy, a red reflex is seen through the intact tympanic membrane in the glomus tumor. Tumor arising from the floor of the middle ear gives a rising sun appearance.

Option D: The dull tympanic membrane on examination and Type B tympanogram suggest the presence of fluid in the middle ear as the cause for deafness and not sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A factory worker at a plastic pipe factory presented with weight loss and abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant for the last 6 months. He had hepatomegaly. CT abdomen revealed that most of the liver was infiltrated by contrast-enhanced mass and the presence of thorium was detected. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the factory worker with upper quadrant abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and the CT inference suggest angiosarcoma of the liver.

Angiosarcoma of the liver is usually seen in individuals having occupational exposure to agents such as vinyl chloride, arsenic, or thorotrast. The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces. CT is the preferred investigation and it reveals infiltrating contrast-enhanced mass diffusely spread over the liver. Thorium is picked up in the CT due to the presence of heterogeneously enhanced attenuation in the liver, perihepatic area, and spleen.

Option A: Cavernous hemangiomas appear as red-blue, soft nodules, usually less than 2 cm in diameter. Their clinical significance is that they might be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for metastatic tumors. Peripheral filling at the delayed phase of the contrast administration is a typical finding in this condition as the tumor is more in the periphery of the liver.

Option B: Metastatic tumor of the liver can be differentiated from primary HCC on a CECT. There is no enhancement or enhancement less than the surrounding liver following contrast.

Option D: Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a delayed arterial filling phase and washes out rapidly in a CECT. It also shows a wedge-shaped perfusion abnormality in the CT due to arterioportal shunts. 

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented to the casualty in an unconscious state. His blood sugars were high, the ABG(Arterial blood gas) analysis showed metabolic acidosis, and urine tests were positive for ketone bodies. The ketone bodies were not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme:
questions.solution:
Ketone bodies are not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

The above clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis characterized by excess production of ketone bodies. The liver cannot utilize the ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase (also called succinyl CoA acetoacetyl CoA transferase).

Ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver mitochondria (by ketogenesis) and transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues. Here they are utilized by the following steps:

  1. β-hydroxybutyrate (the most predominant ketone body) is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  2. Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetyl CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  3. Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

When higher than normal ketone bodies are present in the blood or urine, it is called ketonemia or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis. The metabolism of free fatty acids to produce ketone bodies is exaggerated in pathologic states such as starvation and diabetes mellitus, thus causing ketosis. The continued buffering and excretion of ketone bodies deplete the alkali reserve, causing ketoacidosis.

 

Related Pearl: Ketone body utilisation

1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man was brought with a high-grade fever, productive cough, and confusion for the last 2 days. His vitals and chest radiograph are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

Temperature: 102°F

Pulse rate: 130 bpm

BP: 86/58 mmHg

Respiratory rate: 32/min

choices.text: Start oral antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and insert intercostal drainage tube
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and start IV antibiotics
Admit the patient in ICU and start IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever and productive cough and the chest radiograph showing lobar consolidation point to a diagnosis of pneumonia. Since this patient's CURB-65 score is at least 3 (1 point each for confusion, BP <90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate >30/min), the most appropriate management would be ICU admission and starting IV antibiotics.

Once the diagnosis of pneumonia is made, the next step in management is to determine the site of care for the patient. To identify the patients that require in-patient and ICU management, CURB-65 score is used. It includes:

  • Confusion
  • Urea ≥17 mg/dL
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • Blood pressure: SBP ≤90mmHg or DBP ≤60 mmHg
  • Age ≥ 65 years

1 point is given for the presence of each of the above. The total score determines the site of care, as shown below:

Total Score Decision
0 Outpatient treatment
1 or 2 Inpatient treatment in non-ICU setting
≥3 Inpatient treatment in ICU setting

 

Related Pearl: Empirical Antibiotic Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

questions.text: Leukemia cutis is most commonly seen in association with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Leukemia cutis is most common in patients with myeloid neoplasms, especially acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The risk is higher with translocation t(8,21).

Leukemia cutis is an infiltration of the skin by myeloid or lymphoid neoplastic leukocytes resulting in clinically identifiable cutaneous lesions. When made up of malignant granulocytic precursor cells, leukemia cutis lesions are also called myeloid sarcoma, granulocytic sarcoma, or chloroma.

Leukemia cutis typically presents as single or multiple monomorphic violaceous, dark‐red or hemorrhagic skin nodules and plaques, especially on the legs, arms, and face.

The image below shows violaceous infiltrated nodules and plaques on the trunk suggestive of leukemia cutis.

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. The immunohistochemical studies of this tumor are most likely to express which of the following tumor markers?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: A 45-year-old  P4L4 woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding and lower abdominal discomfort. She also gives a history of an incomplete abortion for which she had to undergo a D&C procedure. On examination, the uterus appears to be uniformly enlarged, corresponding to a 12-week gestation. The adnexa is free. You make a diagnosis and make the patient undergo a total hysterectomy. The images below show the transverse section of uterus and histology of the specimen. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, the gross specimen, histological slide, all point to the diagnosis of adenomyosis and OCPs are not risk factors for its development.

The history of a 45 yr old multiparous woman with a history of vigorous curettage, with complaints, of AUB, along with an enlarged uterus are points in favour of a diagnosis of adenomyosis. The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

  • Aetiology: Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (SERM)
  • Clinical features:
    • Multiparous females >40 years
    • Most common symptom: Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
    • Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia
    • Per-Vaginal: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus (corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy)
    • Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign: Tender, softened uterus
  • Diagnosis:
    • It is mainly clinical
    • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage
  • Management of adenomyosis
    • Total Hysterectomy (Treatment of choice)
    • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD is tried in younger women

questions.text: The Emsley-Fincham test is performed in a patient who complains of blurred vision and seeing colored halos. The patient reports breaking up of the halo into rotating segments. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Breaking up of coloured halos into rotating segments on performing the Emsley-Fincham test with a stenopaeic slit indicates cataract.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with low-grade fever. On examination, a characteristic slapped cheek appearance is seen on the face. Which of the following describes the genetic makeup of the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the classical slapped cheek appearance, the condition is due to Parvovirus infection also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease. Parvovirus is made up of single-stranded DNA.

Erythema infectiosum:

  • Also known as Fifth disease
  • Incubation period: 4-14 days
  • Rash appears first on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), spreads to the trunk

Clinical features:

  • Child will be febrile, non-toxic with a nonspecific prodrome
  • Transient aplastic anemia, myocarditis
  • Petechial/ purpuric skin eruptions: Papular purpuric “gloves and socks” syndrome (PPGSS)
  • Arthritis and arthralgia
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 33-year-old female with endometriosis, which of the following clinical findings do you least expect to encounter?

choices.text: Cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments on posterior fornix examination
Freely mobile painless Nodular mass on abdominal examination
Bluish puckered spots over posterior fornix on speculum examination
Lateral forniceal tenderness in vaginal examination

questions.solution:
Abdominal examination in endometriosis would typically reveal a fixed, tender, cystic swelling, not a freely mobile painless Nodular mass.

 

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 4 months-old male child was brought to the hospital with the complaints of a lesion in the abdomen as shown in the image. The drug used for the treatment of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows flat to elevated, irregular, red-blue masses in the skin of the abdomen suggestive of hemangioma. Propranolol is the preferred treatment of infantile hemangioma.

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis, and inhibiting angiogenesis. Propranolol at 2 mg/kg/day has been found useful in infants younger than 6 months and children up to 5 years of age. 

Complications of infantile hemangioma include pain, functional impairment, or permanent disfigurement.

Timolol is also used in the treatment of infantile hemangioma.

Other options:

Options B, C, D: Bisoprolol, acebutolol, and atenolol are cardioselective beta-blockers that are not used in the treatment of hemangioma.

questions.text: A nurse comes to you for advice regarding the disposal of a used insulin syringe. Which of the following containers would you advise her to use?
questions.solution:
Insulin syringes are syringes with fixed needles, which are to be disposed in White (puncture, leak and tamper proof) containers.

Other options are explained in the pearl given below.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)

pyrolysis

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: An 8 month-old baby is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss and failure to thrive. On clinical examination, there is inflammation of the skin around the mouth and the perianal region as shown in the image. What is the preferred drug to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
A child with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss, and eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica. It is due to zinc deficiency. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred drug.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene, SLC39A4, found on chromosome 8q24.3, which leads to zinc deficiency.

Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip.

Diagnosis by clinical features and low plasma zinc levels. Oral zinc therapy is the treatment of choice (3 mg/kg/24 h). 

Mnemonic- DEAL for Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

D – Diarrhoea

E – Eczematous dermatitis

A - Alopecia

L – Lethargy

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is composed of OKA strain?
questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine is composed of live attenuated OKA strain.

Other options: 

Option A - Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain is used for the rubella vaccine.

Option C - Live attenuated SA 14-14-2 strain is used for the JE vaccine (Japanese encephalitis) which is based on a stable neuro-attenuated strain of the JE virus.

Option D - The Edmonston-Zagreb measles strain is used for the live attenuated measles vaccine used in India.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male underwent tooth extraction for caries tooth. 3 days later he presents with a fever and swelling on the right side of his neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. He also complains of difficulty in moving his jaw. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is found to be displaced medially. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, would be parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone)

Other options:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • Vincent’s angina (trench mouth) is an acute necrotizing infection of the oral cavity and the oropharynx.

Related Pearl: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space

  Prestyloid Poststyloid
Relation to styloid Anterior Posterior
Relations

Medially: Tonsillar fossa

Laterally: Medial pterygoid muscle

Medially: Posterior part of the lateral pharyngeal wall

Laterally: Parotid gland
Contents Medial pterygoid muscle

Carotid artery

Jugular vein, IXth, Xth, XIth, XIIth cranial nerves

Sympathetic trunk
Presentation

Prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa,

Spasm of medial pterygoid muscle leading to trismus

The pharynx bulging behind the posterior pillar

Injury to of CN IX, X, XI, and XII leading to vocal cord paralysis

Sympathetic chain injury leading to Horner’s syndrome

Swelling of the parotid region

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient is undergoing focussed parathyroidectomy for parathyroid adenoma. According to the Miami criteria, for the resection to be considered adequate, the intraoperative drop in parathyroid hormone should be ______.

choices.text: More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in half an 30 min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 30 min

questions.solution:
Drop of parathyroid hormone to more than half the maximum value at 10 min postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma by the Miami criteria.

Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay for Miami criteria.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to >50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He had headaches, nausea, and vertigo after the accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Typically unilateral (85%) 
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

 

Image 1: CT image of acute subdural hemorrhage

Image 2: CT image of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of scanty foul-smelling discharge from the right ear. The following is her otoscopic finding. What will be your main modality of management?
questions.solution:
The child has a history of scanty foul-smelling otorrhoea and the otoscopic picture shows an attic cholesteatoma. This favors the diagnosis of an atticoantral (unsafe) type of chronic otitis media. A surgical procedure like tympanomastoid exploration would be the main modality in managing this child.

Surgery is the only treatment for cholesteatoma. The procedure of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy (MRM), a type of canal wall-down tympanomastoidectomy.

Cholesteatomas are keratinized squamous epithelium masses present in the middle ear cavity. They are described as skin in the wrong place. Although it is called cholesteatoma, this term is a misnomer as it is not a tumor and is not composed of cholesterol crystals.

Cholesteatomas can be classified into the following types :

  • Primary acquired cholesteatomas occur in the absence of previous infection or perforation and patients present with hearing loss.
  • Secondary acquired cholesteatomas occur in those who have a preexisting perforation. 
  • Congenital cholesteatomas arise from the embryonic epidermal cells present in the middle ear cleft. It can be visualized as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. 

Clinical features of cholesteatomas include hearing loss (due to perforation of the tympanic membrane and middle ear bone destruction) and otorrhea. Cholesteatomas have a high potential to destroy the bone due to invasion and enzymatic bone destruction. 

Diagnosis of cholesteatoma can be done by history, examination, and radiography. CT can demonstrate bony defects such as ossicular erosion, mastoid aditus widening, and bony ear canal erosion.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for detection of scarring and pyelonephritis.

  • DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents.
  • It allows better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans.

Other Options:

  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion and hence used for direct measurement of GFR.
  • Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is excreted through renal route via both glomeruli infiltration and tubular excretion; hence, in paediatric patients and patients with poor renal function this test is considered superior to DTPA scan.
  • The screening investigation used in renovascular hypertension is Captopril DTPA and gold standard investigation is renal angiography.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, you notice a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex,  radiating to the axilla and back. Which of the following changes in the Murmur would you expect to see if the patient is made to squat from a standing position?

choices.text: Variable change depending on age of patient

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, having a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex, radiating to the axilla and back indicates a probable diagnosis of Mitral Regurgitation. 

On squatting from a standing position, systemic vascular resistance, blood pressure, and cardiac size increase. Thus the intensity of murmur would increase

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman diagnosed with breast carcinoma was prescribed trastuzumab. Which of the following statements regarding this drug is true?

choices.text: It is an antibody produced entirely from mouse containing no human component
It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting HER-2 antigen
It is a monoclonal antibody containing only human component

questions.solution:
Trastuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the external domain of HER2/neu. In humanized antibodies, all components are identical to human antibodies (95% human component), except the complementary region of the variable chain that contains sequences from other species.

It is indicated in the management of adjuvant therapy in early and metastatic HER-2 positive breast cancer. 

Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase receptor (HER-2-TK) inhibitors are:

  • Lapatinib
  • Neratinib

Anti-Her-2 monoclonal antibodies are:

  • Trastuzumab
  • Pertuzumab

The FDA recently approved tucatinib (kinase inhibitor) in combination with trastuzumab and capecitabine for the treatment of advanced unresectable breast cancer and metastatic HER-2 positive breast cancer including brain metastasis.

Related Pearl: Monoclonal antibodies nomenclature

Murine - 0% human: “omab” (Tositumomab)

Chimeric - 65% human: “ximab” (Rituximab)

Humanized - 95% human: “zumab” (Trastuzumab)

Fully human - 100% human: “umab” (Adalimumab)

questions.text: The given image shows a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) of a 3-year-old boy. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children
Both males  and females are affected
Antenatal USG would have shown oligohydramnios
Transurethral ablation of leaflets can be done

questions.solution:
The given image of an MCU shows dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects corresponding with the valves. This is suggestive of a posterior urethral valve. The posterior urethral valve affects only males.

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are obstructing membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra, which hinders the outflow of urine from the urinary bladder. It may precipitate chronic renal disease in children. It is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in male newborns.

Antenatal USG would show oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.

On performing an MCU, the posterior urethral valve appears as a sharply defined perpendicular or oblique lucency in the distal prostatic urethra. The posterior urethra is dilated and elongated with a shield-like appearance. The bladder is trabeculated with clear demarcation of the hypertrophied bladder neck.

Children with PUV who are not diagnosed before birth may present with delayed voiding or a poor urinary stream. Infants are predisposed to repeated UTIs. Other common signs and symptoms may include a palpable abdominal mass, failure to thrive, lethargy, poor feeding, urosepsis, and urinary ascites. Older boys may have persistent diurnal incontinence or abdominal distention. Physical examination of the newborn reveals a palpable bladder. 

Transurethral ablation of leaflets is done in older boys who have a posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: The Fernandez reaction of lepromin test is read at _________
questions.solution:
The Fernandez reaction or the early reaction of the lepromin test is read at 48 hours.

Lepromin test is a prognostic test used in the classification of Leprosy. It has no diagnostic purpose.

  • It involves performing an intradermal injection of the lepromin antigen (synthesized from M. leprae) on the flexor surface of the forearm.
  • It is an indicator of cell-mediated immunity and hence may be positive in normal individuals as well. 
  • A positive test indicates good cell-mediated immunity and towards Tuberculoid side of the spectrum
  • A negative test indicates poor cell-mediated immunity and towards the Lepromatous side of the spectrum.

There are two possible responses:

  • The early reaction of Fernandez - Positive within 48-72 hours if there is the erythema measuring >10 mm
  • Late Reaction of Mitsuda - Positive at 21 days if there is the onset of a papule measuring 5 mm or more (A better indicator of Cell-Mediated Immunity)

questions.text: In a primary health center, a nurse asks you about using a polio vaccine vial which has not crossed its expiry date. You look at the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) and tell her that it can be used. What did the VVM most likely show?

choices.text: Inner square white, outer circle blue
Inner square blue, outer circle white
Outer square white, inner circle blue
Outer square blue, inner circle white

questions.solution:
The vaccine vial monitor has most likely showed inner square white and outer circle blue.

The standard polio vaccine vial monitor has a colour monitor or labels on the vaccine bottles. The label has an inner white square and an outer blue circle.

It can be used if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle. When the colour of the inner square becomes that of the circle, it means that the vaccine has been exposed to a higher temperature and it cannot be used. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker patient is brought to the hospital due to pain and weakness in the left arm for the past week. He also complains of left-sided chest pain for the last 3 weeks along with malaise, fever and weight loss for the past month. Which of the following tests is more preferred to point to the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features of left-sided chest pain, fever, weight loss, and malaise combined with pain and weakness of the left arm are suggestive of a Pancoast tumor. Chest CT is more preferred along with PET scan. MRI can be supplemented to aid the diagnosis.

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or postobstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread of the tumor can cause:

  • Tracheal obstruction,
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman dies following a crude first-trimester abortion carried out by a quack practitioner. He would be punished under IPC section ____.
questions.solution:
IPC Section 314 deals with causing the death of a mother due to miscarriage:

Doctor and Abortion:

IPC section

Section it deals with

312

Causing miscarriage with consent

313

Causing miscarriage without consent

314

Death of mother due to miscarriage

315

Preventing the child from being born alive or causing it to die after birth

316

Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

Note: Quick child is a fetus that has developed to such a stage that it moves within the womb of the mother. It shall mean an unborn child whose heart is beating, who is experiencing electronically measurable brain waves, who is discernibly moving, and who is so far developed and matured as to be capable of surviving the trauma of birth with the aid of usual medical care and facilities available in this state.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, and glucose intolerance. After an appropriate workup, she is diagnosed with an adrenocortical adenoma, with a hormone secreted by a zone marked as B. Identify the given hormone -
questions.solution:
In the above image, structure marked B is Zona fasciculata. Glucocorticoids are secreted from the Zona fasciculata. 

Zona fasiculata secretes:

  • Glucocorticoids
  • Cortisol
  • Corticosterone

Other structures marked are as follows:

A – Zona glomerulosa (just underneath the eosinophilic connective tissue)

C – Zona reticularis (cells arranged in the form of irregular cords giving rise to the reticular pattern)

D – Adrenal Medulla
