questions.text: What form of prevention is the prospective screening of COVID infection among the international passengers at the airport?
questions.solution:
The prospective screening is a form of primary prevention. It is done for the benefit of others, who have not gotten the disease. This is done so that the disease is controlled and not spread. 

The prescriptive screening is done for the case detection, and the people are screened for their own benefits of early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. e.g., neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Conley’s pointer is related to:
questions.solution:
Conley’s pointer is one of the anatomical landmarks for identification of facial nerve during superficial parotidectomy.

It refers to the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal and facial nerve lies 1 cm deep and inferior to it.

questions.text: Nitric oxide synthase contributes to the erection of the penis by relaxing the smooth muscle and increasing blood flow by _________

choices.text: Blocking phosphodiesterases to increase cAMP levels
Activating guanylyl cyclases to increase cGMP levels

questions.solution:
Nitric oxide synthase, by synthesising nitric oxide, contributes to the erection of the penis by activating guanylyl cyclases to increase cGMP levels that relax smooth muscle and increase blood flow. 

Nitric Oxide

  • Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF).
  • Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
  • Mechanism of action:
    • NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → relaxation of vascular smooth muscle → vasodilation.
  • Effects of NO:
    • Vasodilation.
    • Neuromodulator in the brain.
    • Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells.
    • In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle
    • Penile erection.

Note:

The drugs like sildenafil (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis), and vardenafil (Levitra) all inhibit the breakdown of cGMP by phosphodiesterases and are used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient came with complaints of neck and upper limb pain. She also gives a history of weakness, incoordination, and clumsiness of upper limbs. Her CT scan is as given below. The diagnosis is

choices.text: Ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament
Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament

questions.solution:
The CT scan shows an ossified posterior longitudinal ligament. 

Patients typically present with symptoms of neck and upper-limb pain, weakness, incoordination, clumsiness, muscle wasting, and bladder-bowel dysfunction, etc and are typically older than 50 years of age

It occurs mainly in the cervical spine, most commonly at the level of C5. It can result in spinal stenosis and cervical myelopathy causing pain and weakness in the limbs. X-ray shows dense ossification along the back of the vertebral bodies in the mid-cervical spine. Cervical spinal cord injury can be induced by minor cervical trauma in these patients.

Treatment is needed if the symptoms are progressive. Posterior decompression is the operation of choice.

questions.text: An elderly patient with chronic black tarry stools underwent an upper GI endoscopy. Gastric mucosa appeared as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the snake-skin appearance of the gastric mucosa, which is seen in cases of portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Portal hypertensive gastropathy is characterized by the diffuse dila­tion of the mucosal and submucosal venous plexus of the stomach associated with overlying gastritis.

Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly, characterized endoscopically by watermelon stripes. It is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions, including hepatic, cardiac, and renal diseases.

Option C: Hypoproteinemic hypertrophic gastropathy also known as Menetrier's disease is a rare, acquired premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, little or no acid production, and excessive mucous production with resultant protein loss. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor-alpha.

Option D: Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a large tortuous arteriole that erodes and bleeds and occurs most commonly in the stomach wall.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the OPD by parents for a well-baby checkup when you notice the following lesion. They say the lesion has been present since birth and has been decreasing in size. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots.

Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. Therefore, these spots are congenital, and are easily distinguished from the bruises of child abuse. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

They usually fade away during the first year of life, and the parents should be reassured about this.

 Other options:

  • Salmon patch or naevus simplex is small, pink-colored macules that are commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. They are an ill-defined lesion, which develops due to vascular ectasia. (Note: The subungual oil droplets seen in nail psoriasis are also known as salmon patches).
  • Neonatal pustular melanosis is a congenital benign lesion characterized by evanescent superficial pustules, ruptured pustules with fine scales, and hyperpigmented macules. The pustular lesions last for 2-3 days, while the hyperpigmented macules may last for about 3 months.
  • Harlequin color change is a congenital lesion, usually seen in low-birth-weight infants where half of the body in the dependent portion turns red in color, while the other half of the body is pale. This occurs due to an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism. Changing the infant's position causes a reversal of the pattern.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with pruritis which worsens particularly on undressing at night. On examination, his skin is found to be dry and a characteristic ‘crazy-paving’ pattern is observed on the legs. This patient is suffering from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asteatotic eczema.

  • Asteatotic eczema usually develops in elderly patients.
  • Asteatotic eczema affects the legs, arms, and hands of elderly people in the context of very dry skin.
  • A characteristic crazy-paving pattern is observed on the legs, in particular, resulting in the synonym of eczema craquele.
  • It is also called as Winter eczema.
  • Irritation in this form of eczema is often intense, and worse with changes in temperature, particularly on undressing at night.

questions.text: A teenager presents to the OPD with fever, malaise and lymphadenopathy. Heterophile agglutination test is positive, The causative virus uses the complement receptor ____________ to attach to and infect B cells?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described here is of infectious mononucleosis. The causative virus is the Epstein-Barr virus. It uses the complement receptor CD 21 to attach to and infect B cells.

EBV infects B lymphocytes and possibly epithelial cells of the oropharynx. The infection of B cells is latent; that is, there is no viral replication and the cells are not killed. However, B cells latently infected with EBV express viral proteins that result in the ability to propagate indefinitely in vitro.

CD 10, 22 are B cell markers but are not used by EBV to infect B cells.

CD 3 is a T cell marker.

questions.text: A 47-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is admitted for the treatment of a fractured tibia. On the 3rd day of admission, he develops severe restlessness and becomes agitated. He has visual and tactile hallucinations. On examination, he is disoriented, diaphoretic and has tachycardia and fever. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delirium tremens. Administration of lorazepam would be the appropriate treatment for this patient. 

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal. Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Benzodiazepines such as lorazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours) are given. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options: 

Option A: Phenytoin which is a non-benzodiazepine anti convulsant is usually not helpful in the prevention or treatment of alcohol withdrawal delirium or seizures. 

Option B: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic and is usually avoided in patients with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal due to its propensity to reduce the seizure threshold in alcoholics.

Option C: Fomepizole is used in the treatment of ethylene glycol and methanol intoxication. 

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation
Symptoms/signs
Onset since last drink (hours)
Tremulousness
Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz
6–8
Alcoholic hallucinosis/
Psychotic and perceptual symptoms
Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs. 
8-12
Seizures (rum fits)
Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic
12–24
Delirium tremens
Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, impaired orientation
< 72

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG classically depicts polymorphic ventricular tachycardia—torsades de pointes. Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance.

There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

The other cause of torsades de pointes include:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform).
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulphate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate - electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion or intravenous atropine 

Note: Although hypocalcemia is associated with prolongation of QT interval, there are only rare reports of torsades de pointes associated with hypocalcemia. So, among the above options, the best answer would be hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 75-kg woman has a preoperative hematocrit of 35%. How much blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered? (Consider transfusion cut off of Hematocrit as 30%)
questions.solution:
750 ml blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered

The transfusion point can be determined preoperatively from the hematocrit and by estimating blood volume. Patients with a normal hematocrit should generally be transfused only after losses greater than 10–20% of their blood volume. The exact point is based on the patient’s medical condition and the surgical procedure. The amount of blood loss necessary for the hematocrit to fall to 30% can be calculated as follows:

  1. Estimate blood volume
  2. Estimate the red blood cell volume (RBCV) at the preoperative hematocrit (RBCV preop).
  3. Estimate RBCV at a hematocrit of 30% (RBCV 30%), assuming normal blood volume is maintained.
  4. Calculate the RBCV lost when the hematocrit is 30%; RBCV lost = RBCV preop – RBCV 30%
  5. Allowable blood loss = RBCV lost x3.

Blood Volume

Neonates:

  • Premature 95 mL/kg
  • Full-term 85 mL/kg
  • Infants 80 mL/kg

Adults:

  • Men 75 mL/kg
  • Women 65 mL/kg

Estimated blood volume = 65 mL/kg x 75 kg = 4875 mL.

RBCV 35% = 4875 x 35% = 1706 mL.

RBCV 30% = 4875 x 30% = 1462 mL.

Red cell loss at 30% = 1706-1462 = 244 mL.

Allowable blood loss = 3 x 244 mL = 732 ~ 750ml

Therefore, transfusion should be considered only when this patient’s blood loss exceeds 750 ml.

Increasingly, transfusions are not recommended until the hematocrit decreases to 24% or lower (hemoglobin <8.0 g/dL), but it is necessary to take into account the rate of blood loss and comorbid conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the structure marked by the red arrow?

choices.text: Injury causes Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue
Arises from the posterior trunk of mandibular nerve
It is joined by the chorda tympani branch of facial nerve
It is joined by a branch of inferior alveolar nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the lingual nerve. Injury to the lingual nerve results in loss of sensation to the anterior two thirds of the tongue.

Points of identification: The nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

The lingual nerve arises from the posterior trunk of the mandibular nerve. It is joined by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve and a branch from the inferior alveolar nerve.

Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue is due to the injury to glossopharyngeal nerve.

Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The provided history of falling on an outstretched arm and the X-ray revealing an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint point to the diagnosis of Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. 

Patients present with pain, swelling, and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has hearing difficulty in his right ear, with frequent episodes of tinnitus. Further clinical examination shows a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Given below is his brain MRI image. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI image are diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. The rollover phenomenon is seen in this condition.

When speech audiometry is done on this patient, it shows poor speech discrimination. A reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is called the rollover phenomenon. It is seen in retrocochlear type of hearing loss, as with an acoustic neuroma.

Vestibular schwannoma or ‘acoustic neuroma’ are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and arise from the vestibular division of the VIII nerve but rarely may arise from the cochlear division of the VIII nerve within the internal auditory canal.

  • Mostly seen in 40- 60 years and no sexual predilection.
  • Progressive unilateral hearing loss with tinnitus is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Vth cranial nerve is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved.
  • Other nerves involved are IX, X, and XI cranial nerves and may also cause displacement of the brainstem resulting in increased intracranial pressure.

MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Other options:

The recruitment phenomenon refers to abnormal growth of loud sounds (sound is amplified in order to be heard better). A loud sound that is tolerable by a normal ear may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in the recruiting ear and thus becomes intolerable. It is a feature of cochlear pathologies like Meniere's disease and presbycusis. 

Diplacusis is the discordance of sounds in which a single auditory stimulus of a particular frequency is heard at different pitches in both ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds produce vertigo due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

The recruitment phenomenon, diplacusis, and Tullio phenomenon are all seen in Meniere's disease.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

Related Pearl: The differences between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss

Test
Cochlear hearing loss
Retrocochlear hearing loss
Recruitment (ABLB test)
Present
Absent
*SISI score (Short Increment Sensitivity Index)
70 – 100%
0 – 20% 
Acoustic reflex threshold
Decreased due to recruitment
Increased
**Tone decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
Acoustic reflex decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
OAEs
Absent
Present
BERA (Best test)
Delayed wave-I, rest are normal
Only wave-I is present, rest are absent or affected
Speech discrimination score
  • Reduced
  • Roll over phenomenon absent
  • Very poor
  • Roll over phenomenon present

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A preterm baby is brought with symptoms of abdominal distention and hematochezia. The abdominal x-ray shows a portal vein gas shadow. The child's condition is classified as Modified Bell's stage IIIa, which of the following findings is likely to be seen?

choices.text: Modified Bell's Stage IIIa NEC has radiological findings only

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in the preterm baby is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). In a child with Modified Bell's Stage IIIA NEC, signs of generalized peritonitis like abdomen with guarding and rigidity would be present. 

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria:

Stage I - Suspected NEC
Stage II - Proven NEC
Stage III - Advanced NEC

Stage   Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs
IA Suspected NEC Mild abdominal distention, emesis, guaiac-positive stool Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus
IB   IA + Bright red blood from the rectum Same as IA Same as IA
IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sounds Same as IA  Pneumatosis intestinalis, ileus
IIB Moderately ill  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness IA+ Metabolic acidosis and thrombocytopenia   IIA + portal venous gas, with or without ascites
IIIA Severely ill, bowel intact  IIB + peritonitis with marked tenderness, and abdominal distension  IIB+ hypotension, bradycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia  IIB + definite ascites 
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A Same as IIIA   IIB +pneumoperitoneum

Necrotizing enterocolitis:

It is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated are:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is diagnostic. It corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures - nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows). It is seen as a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

questions.text: A 40 year old male comes to OPD with a chronic history of  deformity of penis, erectile dysfunction and pain on erection. On examination there were palpable penile plaques. What is the surgical procedure commonly employed to correct this penile deformity?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbitt procedure. This corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture.

Other options:

Options A and B: Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgery performed for hydrocoele.

Option D: Anderson-Hynes operation is a pyeloplasty procedure performed for hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A surgeon applies a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, when the patient informs the doctor, the doctor says he is too busy to remove the cast. After a few days, the patient develops a permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  • The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  • The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  • When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Other options:

Option D: Medical maloccurrence is a defence against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: What is false regarding the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image of the gluteal region?

choices.text: Causes lateral rotation of the thigh in extension
Causes abduction of the thigh in flexion
Sciatic nerve lies closely related to the muscle

questions.solution:
The structure marked is the piriformis muscle.

The muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It passes outside the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.

It inserts into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibers or above the muscle.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position.

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels

questions.text: During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants, it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

  • LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in the function of neutrophils that include adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.
  • As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.
  • There is delayed separation of the cord, which is usually associated with infection of the cord stump.

There are three types of LAD:

  • LAD 1- Defective beta 2 integrin (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 
  • LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X, leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling.
  • LAD 3- Defective signaling for integrin activation, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. (milder than type 1)

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: 1 Lakh students took the Grand Test conducted by marrow. The mean score was 628 with a standard deviation of 18. Assuming a normal distribution, how many students scored more than 664?
questions.solution:
2500 students scored more than 664 marks. 

664 is 2 standard deviations above the mean. 95% of the students fall between -2 to +2 and only 5% lie below -2 or above +2. Here, 95% of the students (95% of 1 lakh = 95000) lie between 592 and 664. 5000 lie below 592 or above 664. Hence, the number of students who scored more than 664 is 5000/2 = 2500.

questions.text: A baby boy at 7 months of age presented with a history of vomiting and failure to thrive. On evaluation, he is found to have raised blood ammonia levels and no ketones. Also, he has high plasma glutamine and alanine levels, with low levels of citrulline and arginine. Which is the enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby is ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC). 

In this X-linked disorder, males are more severely affected than females. In this disorder, there are episodes of hyperammonemia which is manifested by vomiting, and neurologic abnormalities like ataxia, mental confusion, agitation, combativeness, and frank psychosis. These episodes are separated by the period of wellness.

Laboratory findings during the acute attack:

  • Hyperammonemia is accompanied by marked elevations of plasma concentrations of glutamine and alanine with low levels of citrulline and arginine. High glutamine in urine is usually seen in hyperammonemia as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.
  • The blood level of urea is low.
  • A marked increase in the urinary excretion of orotic acid. Orotate precipitates in urine as pink-colored gravel or stones.
  • Increased uracil in urine is also seen. When OTC is deficient carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria spills into the cytoplasm then it enters into pyrimidine synthesis. 

 The diagnosis is most conveniently confirmed by gene analysis.

Other options:

Option A: In the near-complete enzymatic deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1, symptoms appear during the 1st few days or even hours of life. the baby presents with the signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia (refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, convulsion, coma). Increased intracranial pressure is frequent. Orotic aciduria and increased production of pyrimidines like uracil in this case are not seen in Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 deficiency.

Option C: Arginase deficiency is a rare distal urea cycle disorder that presents as acute neonatal form with intractable seizures, cerebral edema, and death. Laboratory findings include marked elevations of arginine in plasma and CSF.

Option D: The deficiency of the Argininosuccinate synthetase enzyme leads to citrullinemia type I, also called classic citrullinemia.  The severe or neonatal form (the most common form) appears in the 1st few days of life with signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia. In the subacute or mild form, clinical findings such as failure to thrive, frequent vomiting, developmental delay, and dry, brittle hair appear gradually after 1 year of age. Laboratory findings are similar to those found in patients with OTC deficiency, except that the plasma citrulline concentration is greatly elevated.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is clubbing, hence the patient is unlikely to have COPD. Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. 

In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window gets obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

Psoriasis, Reiter’s syndrome, Alopecia areata

questions.text: A young male presented with fever and lymphadenopathy in the cervical and inguinal region. The histology of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation in the background of T-reactive lymphocytes. What is the clinical staging according to Ann-Arbor staging?
questions.solution:
Involvement of lymph nodes on both sides of diaphragm with fever is stage III (B) of Ann-Arbor staging.

Clinical staging of both Hodgkin and Non Hodgkin Lymphoma is done by Ann Arbor staging.

Related Pearl: Ann Arbor Staging for Hodgkin and NonHodgkin Lymphoma

Stage Distribution of disease
I

Involvement of a single lymph node region (I)

or 

a single extra lymphatic organ or site (IE)
II

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II)

or

localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site (IIE)
III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site
IV

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement 

All stages are further divided on the basis of the absence (A) or presence (B) of fever, night sweats and/or unexplained weight loss >10% of body weight.

questions.text: You are working in an earthquake-affected area in the triage team. You see a 32 year old man with a suspected undisplaced fracture of the tibia. He is stable. Which color will you use to tag him?
questions.solution:
This stable patient probably requires surgery within the next 24 hours but does not need immediate resuscitation. He gets medium priority, hence a yellow tag.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given

  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.

Green (Low priority)

  • Minor lacerations etc.

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A 30-year-old  P1L1  woman is found to have an asymptomatic invasive disease of the cervix penetrating to a depth of 4 mm and 6 mm wide. She wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Invasive cervical disease measuring 6mm in width and 4mm in depth is stage IA2. The most appropriate management here would be a radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

Stage IA2 is defined as carcinoma is strictly confined to the cervix and the measured stromal invasion is >3 mm and not >5 mm in depth and no wider than 7mm.

For patients who desire to preserve their fertility, radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are the treatment of choice. For women who do not desire to preserve fertility, radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are advised.

Other options:

Option A - Chemoradiation is indicated from stage IB onwards.

Option B - Conization is indicated in women who want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

Option D - Simple hysterectomy is indicated in women who do not want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: The most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome is:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome is head injury followed by rupture of abdominal organ.

The classic head injury associated with battered children is subdural hematoma.

questions.text: While reading the X-Ray of a 32-year-old female who has come for her annual health check,  you notice the unilateral elevation of the diaphragm. Which of the following conditions is it least likely to be?
questions.solution:
Poor inspiration would result in a bilaterally elevated diaphragm, not unilateral elevation.

Causes of Unilateral Elevation of the Diaphragm

  • Gaseous distension of stomach or colon
  • Dorsal scoliosis
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary collapse
  • Phrenic nerve palsy
  • Eventration
  • Pneumonia or pleurisy
  • Pulmonary thromboembolism
  • Rib fracture and other painful conditions
  • Subphrenic infection
  • Subphrenic mass

 

Causes of Bilateral Symmetrical

Elevation of the Diaphragm

 

  • Supine position
  • Poor inspiration
  • Obesity
  • Pregnancy
  • Abdominal distension 
  • Diffuse pulmonary fibrosis
  • Lymphangitis carcinomatosa
  • Disseminated lupus erythematosus
  • Bilateral basal pulmonary emboli
  • Pain after abdominal surgery
  • Bilateral diaphragmatic paralysis

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from ________
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopy image shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis.

The image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's Prussian blue.

The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with nutritional melalgia?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid/ Vitamin B5 deficiency leads to burning feet syndrome, also known as nutritional melalgia or Gopalan's syndrome.

It acts as a functional part of CoA or acyl carrier protein. CoA plays a role in fatty acid oxidation, the citric acid cycle, acetylations, and cholesterol synthesis. ACP is involved in the fatty acid synthesis.

Deficiency leads to peripheral nerve damage leading to burning foot syndrome. It is mostly seen during a famine, in prison camps, in chronic alcoholics, and in renal dialysis patients.

questions.text: A 34-year-old morbidly obese female patient was examined for thyroid swelling. The patient is asked to place the hands behind the neck and asked to push her head against the clasped hands on the occiput. This method is known as:
questions.solution:
In Pizzilo's method, the patient is asked to place their hands behind the neck and the patient is asked to push her head against the clasped hands on the occiput. It is used to inspect the thyroid gland more easily, especially useful in obese short-necked individuals. 

In Lahey's Method, the examiner stands in front of the patient and the lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the right lobe medially by the left hand, and the left lobe is palpated with the right hand of the examiner.

The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb. This gives a clear indication regarding the slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules. This is known as Crile’s method.

Kocher’s test is done when one suspects pressure on the trachea. Gentle pressure on the lateral lobes of the thyroid causes stridor due to a narrow trachea. This test is positive in multinodular goitre and carcinoma infiltrating into the trachea.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus diseases?

1. Z-plasty
2. Limberg flap
3. Bascom's procedure
4. Incision and drainage
5. Surgical approaches along the natal cleft
questions.solution:
Surgical approaches parallel to the natal cleft, and not along the natal cleft are preferred, to reduce chances of recurrence. 

Pilonidal sinus disease treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches. The non-surgical approach includes conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. 

In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are advised.

Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include:

  1. Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment
  2. Bascom's procedure- is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft are removed under local anesthesia
  3. Karydakis procedure- an ovoid area of pathologic tissue is excised parallel to the natal cleft and a fasciocutaneous flap is mobilized to cover the defect
  4. Limberg/ rhomboid flap- excises the pilonidal disease in a rhomboid shape and rotates a fasciocutaneous flap for wound closure
  5. Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plasty

The given image shows a Limberg/rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery:

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type II (Pompe's disease) glycogen storage disease is the most probable diagnosis from the above-given clinical scenario.

The clinical symptoms are hypotonia (floppy infant), hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, which is characteristically seen in Pompe's disease. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. 

Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.

The enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) for Pompe disease is the recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

questions.text: Verocay bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles.

Palisading of nuclei is common and “nuclear-free zones” that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies.

  • In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Modified Prague’s maneuver is shown in the image. It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Other options:

Lovset’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

 

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Pinard’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: There is an outbreak of chickenpox among the children at a daycare center. What is the most common extracutaneous site of involvement of this disease?
questions.solution:
The most common extracutaneous site of involvement by the varicella-zoster virus in children is the central nervous system.

Central nervous system (CNS) involvement is a benign complication of VZV infection in children and generally does not require hospitalization. They may develop acute cerebellar ataxia and meningeal inflammation around 21 days after the onset of the rash. The CSF findings include the presence of lymphocytes and elevated levels of protein. Other CNS manifestations include

  • Aseptic meningitis
  • Encephalitis
  • Transverse myelitis
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome

The most common infectious complication of varicella is secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus while the most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.

Other options:

Option A: Hepatic involvement is common in chickenpox and is usually asymptomatic. It is characterized by elevated levels of liver enzymes, particularly aspartate and alanine aminotransferase. Reye’s syndrome may occur in children concomitantly treated with aspirin and hence is not used.

Option C: Chickenpox may involve the joints and cause arthritis as a complication.

Option D: Lung involvement is more common in adults than children and is more severe in pregnant women. The most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male is being evaluated for multiple lesions found in his spine. Which of the following conditions is least likely?
questions.solution:
Histiocytosis would be the least likely among the given list as the patient is 49 years old.

Histiocytosis would be considered in the differential diagnosis if the patient was less than 30 years old. Histiocytosis usually presents as a diaphyseal lesion common in ages 5-30.

■ Osteoblastoma

■ Aneurysmal bone cyst

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of sudden painless loss of vision as if a curtain fell before his eyes. He also experiences flashes of light. On examination, pigments are found on the anterior vitreous like tobacco dusted over the posterior wall of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis from the clinical scenario is retinal detachment.

Retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Retinal detachment is classified into the following depending upon the fluid accumulation:

  • Rhegmatogenous
  • Tractional
  • Exudative

Risk factors include myopia, previous intraocular surgery such as aphakia or pseudophakia, a family history of retinal detachment, and trauma.

Clinical features include sudden painless loss of vision, flashes of light or photopsia, floaters in the eye, and curtains in the field of vision.

Examination findings will reveal:

  • Normal or slightly low intraocular pressure
  • Marcus Gunn pupil (relative afferent pupillary defect)
  • Altered red reflex on the distant direct ophthalmoscope
  • Indirect ophthalmoscopy may show grey reflex of the freshly detached retina or breaks in the retina 
  • Vitreous pigments on the anterior vitreous (Shaffer sign)
  • Shifting fluid sign- Change in the position of the detached area with a change in gravity is the hallmark of exudative retinal detachment.

Management of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment includes sealing of retinal breaks, reducing the vitreous traction on the retina, and flattening of the retina by draining the subretinal fluid. Scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy, and pars plana vitrectomy can help in maintaining the chorioretinal apposition. 

Treating the cause helps in exudative retinal detachment. Enucleation can be done if intranuclear tumors are present.

Other options:

Option A- Stargardt disease is the most common type of macular dystrophy. It presents as decreased vision in the first or second decade of life. Fundus examination will show beaten bronze or snail-slime reflex in the macular area.

Option B- Macular edema is the collection of fluid in the macula. It occurs due to the leakage from dilated capillaries. Slit lamp examination will show loss of the foveal reflex and thickening at or around the macula. Fluorescein angiography is used to identify the areas of leakage.

Option C- Eales disease is the inflammation of peripheral retinal veins leading to recurrent retinal hemorrhages. Patients will have a sudden painless loss of vision and floaters. The examination will show hemorrhage and vascularisation of the retina.

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause
Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painful loss of vision
  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball
Gradual painless diminution of vision
  • Corneal dystrophy
  • Senile cataract
  • Primary open angle glaucoma
  • Optic atrophy
  • ARMD
  • Refractive error
  • Diabetic retinopathy
Gradual painful diminution of vision

questions.text: During an ophthalmoscopic examination of a patient in bright light, you notice a finding similar to that of 'A' in the given image. The same patient is made to sit in a dark room and a subsequent examination reveals you a fundus similar to that of 'B'. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a comparison in the fundus appearances ("A" shows golden yellow colour of the fundus in a light-adapted state; "B" shows normal-appearing funds after prolonged dark adaptation of 3 to 4 hours). The fundus has an unusual golden yellow colour in the light-adapted state, which becomes normal after prolonged dark adaptation is called Mizuo or Mizuo–Nakamura phenomenon. 

Mizuo phenomenon is seen in Oguchi's disease. 

Oguchi's disease is a type of congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus. Rod function is absent even after 30 minutes of dark adaptation (normal dark adaptation time is 20–30 mins) but recovers to a near-normal level after a long period of dark adaptation (4 hours).

Congenital stationary night blindness refers to a group of disorders characterised by infantile-onset nyctalopia but non-progressive retinal dysfunction.

questions.text: The following upper GI series shows:
questions.solution:
The upper GI series shows Zenker's diverticulum.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: During the clinical examination of an elderly male patient with bilateral pitting pedal edema, a 3.7 cm rise of jugulovenous pulse is noted on gentle compression with the palm over the abdomen for about 30 seconds. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called positive hepatojugular reflux.

It is elicited by applying firm pressure over the liver for 15 to 30 seconds while observing the neck veins for increasing jugular venous pressure (JVP). This reflux indicates that the right ventricle cannot accommodate the increase in venous pressure.  

This sign is positive in right heart failure and severe tricuspid regurgitation. Additionally, there are prominent V waves and Y descent in tricuspid regurgitation.

JVP is measured as the distance between the top of jugular venous pulsation and the sternal angle of Louis. The normal height of JVP is between 6 cm to 8 cm H2O. 

Other options:

Option A - A large pericardial effusion can compress the base of the left lung. This is noted as Ewart's sign - an area of dullness and increased fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula. 

Option C & D - Friedrich's sign and Kussmaul's sign are both seen in constrictive pericarditis. Friedreich's sign is the prominent y descent of the jugular venous waveform, and Kussmaul's sign is the rise (or lack of fall) of JVP with inspiration. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of diabetic retinopathy with proteinuria and the histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules with increased mesangial matrix is highly suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease is also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis

Mesangial matrix appear as ovoid or spherical, acellular nodules in the periphery of the glomerulus. These nodules are PAS-positive. Capillary loops at the periphery are dilated. Accumulations of hyaline material occurs in the capillary loops (fibrin caps) and bowman capsules (capsular drops).

Other renal lesions that are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, mainly hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Given below is another histopathology image of diffuse and nodular diabetic glomerulosclerosis (PAS stain). Diffuse increase in mesangial matrix and characteristic acellular PAS-positive nodules are seen.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse lupus nephritis is the most common form of lupus nephritis (Class IV).

The lesions may be global or diffuse. It is characterized by the proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and epithelial cells of the involved glomeruli. Subendothelial immune complex deposition forms a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, resulting in wire-loop lesions.

The histopathology image given below shows a hypercellular glomerulus (endocapillary proliferation). Glomerular capillary loops appear circumferentially thickened, forming a "wire loop" lesion, which is classically seen in diffuse lupus nephritis.

Option B: Renal amyloidosis: The kidney is the most common organ involved in amyloidosis. Glomerular deposits appears as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid. Capillary lumens are obliterated.

Image below shows amyloidosis of the kidney. The glomerular architecture is almost totally obliterated by the massive accumulation of amyloid.

Option D: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes. Histology reveals focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall. Lipid droplets and foam cells are present in the sclerosed area.

Image below shows the histopathological image of FSGS.

questions.text: A man was brought to the hospital after he suffered a stab wound. CT-scan revealed an injury to the part of the artery that lies lateral to pectoralis minor muscle. Which of the following vessels is least likely to have its flow cut off completely?
questions.solution:
The third part of the axillary artery lies lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle. Injury in this part causes decreased blood supply in all branches of the third part of the axillary artery. The superior thoracic artery is a branch of the first part of the axillary artery, and is, therefore, the least likely to be affected.

The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery. It extends from the outer border of the 1st rib to the lower border of teres major, from where it continues as the brachial artery.

Pectoralis minor divides the artery into 3 parts (proximal to, posterior to, and lateral/distal to the muscle).

Part of the artery Relation to Pectoralis minor Branches
1st part Lies proximally Superior thoracic artery 
2nd part Lies posteriorly

Thoracoacromial artery

Lateral thoracic artery
3rd part Lies laterally/distally

Subscapular artery

Anterior circumflex humeral artery

Posterior circumflex humeral artery

questions.text: The device shown in the image is _______ and the patient _______ with the machine:
questions.solution:
The image shows incentive spirometer and the patient inhales with the machine.


The patient sits upright and inhales with a slow deep breath after placing his mouth tightly around the mouthpiece.

The incentive spirometer mimics normal sighing. It serves to prevent/reverse atelectasis.

Incentive spirometer is used in post-op patients and in pneumonia patients to ensure sustained maximal inspiration so as to prevent stasis.

The simple float spirometer. It was previously used in spirometry measurements.

The image shows a Electronic Spirometry test being performed. They have better accuracy and efficiency compared to the other previously used types of spirometers.

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for anemia. The oral and eye examination findings are shown below. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with its image showing cheilosis, angular stomatitis, a magenta-colored tongue, and corneal vascularisation, points to the diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency. RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing this condition.

Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products.

The following signs and symptoms characterize the deficiency state of riboflavin:

  • Cheilosis- pallor in the angle of the mouth and fissuring of the lips, which extends radially to the skin.
  • Glossitis- the tongue becomes smooth, and there is a loss of papillae (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes- keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features- seborrheic dermatitis and anemia.

Note: Because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Other options:

Option A: RBC transketolase assay diagnoses vitamin B1/ thiamine deficiency. Thiamine deficiency mainly manifests as peripheral neuritis, beriberi, and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option B: The serum methyl malonate level is used to diagnose vitamin B12/ methylcobalamin deficiency. Patients typically present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and signs and symptoms of subacute combined degeneration, manifesting as loss of vibration and proprioception and absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option C: The RBC transaminase assay assesses glutamate levels inside RBCs. Human erythrocytes require a continual supply of glutamate to support glutathione synthesis, but this is not routinely tested.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and should be used very cautiously as slow bolus.

There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias).

For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1000 dilution can be used. 

In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use. The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of 1:10,000 solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.
