questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of swelling in his thigh. Radiographs show a radiolucent center and surrounding irregular bone formation. CT shows a well-circumscribed mass within muscle with areas of bright calcification. A diagnosis of myositis ossificans is made. The most likely pathological mechanism associated with this is:

choices.text: High levels of prostaglandins within the nidus causing local inflammation
Production of osteoid matrix by the malignant cells
Metaplasia of fibroblast and bone formation
Inflammation, bone necrosis and reactive new bone formation

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette described here is of myositis ossificans and the pathology associated is metaplasia of fibroblast and bone formation.

Myositis ossificans is a reactive lesion occurring in the soft tissues. It is characterized by fibrous, osseous, and cartilaginous proliferation of the subperiosteal hematoma. This is later followed by metaplastic changes.

High levels of prostaglandin E2 and prostacyclin within the nidus causing local inflammation and vasodilation is seen in osteoid osteoma.

Production of an osteoid matrix by the malignant cells is seen in osteosarcoma.

Inflammation, suppuration, bone necrosis, reactive new bone formation and ultimately, resolution and healing are seen in osteomyelitis.

questions.text: During the ward rounds, you notice the notes on a patient file says dysdiadochokinesia present. To elicit this, which of the following would you ask the patient to perform?

choices.text: Stand with the feet close by and the eyes closed
Fix the eye on an object on one extreme of the room
Supination and pronation of the hand in quick succession
Walk heel to toe on a straight line without any support

questions.solution:
The patient should be asked to perform a rapid alternating movement like the supination and pronation of the hand in quick succession for eliciting dysdiadochokinesis.  Dysdiadochokinesia is the inability to perform rapid alternate movements.

It is a clinical manifestation of cerebellar dysfunction and is most evident when strength and sensation are intact. Focal lesions in the nervous system may produce highly asymmetric dysdiadochokinesia. 

Standing with the feet close by and the eyes closed is used to check for Romberg sign. Walking heel to toe on a straight line without any support is known as the tandem walking test.

 

The following movement is the method to check for dysdiadochokinesis. The patient is showing normal movement, with no dysdiadochokinesis. 

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of the cerebellum

  Dorsal Spinocerebellum Ventral Spinocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) Vestibulocerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) 
Constituents Vermis (except the nodulus) The adjacent medial portion of the hemisphere The lateral portion of hemispheres Nodulus and flocculus 
Afferent (input) Somatosensory from the trunk, visual, auditory, and vestibular Somatosensory input from the limbs From the cerebral motor cortex, premotor, and somatosensory cortex  Vestibular input, visual input, somatosensory from the neck
Efferent (output) Via Fastigial nucleus to the medial descending system Via interposed nucleus to lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal systems Via dentate nucleus to motor, premotor and prefrontal cortex  To vestibular nuclei in the brain stem (direct projection)
Functions    

Maintains posture and helps in the execution of gross movements

It controls the interplay between agonist and antagonist group of muscles

 Controls the  distal muscles of the limbs (smoothens and coordinates movements) Planning the sequence of voluntary movements    

 Participates in maintaining equilibrium and posture

 

Controls ocular movements

It is responsible for regulating the stability of the head and body in space

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with myopia at 10 years of age came for an opinion on LASIK surgery. On routine preoperative assessment, the estimated residual stromal bed was calculated to be 200 μm, and surgery was deferred. Which of the following anticipated complications made the surgeon take such a decision?
questions.solution:
LASIK, when performed in this patient, would predispose him to ectasia of the cornea (keratectasia) because of the inadequate residual stromal bed thickness.

Because LASIK is a procedure involving the ablation of stroma, a preoperative calculation of the residual stromal bed thickness can aid the eye surgeon to predict the postoperative risk for corneal ectasia.

The residual stromal bed thickness can be calculated by subtracting the anticipated flap thickness and maximum ablation depth from the central corneal thickness. A residual stromal bed thickness of 250 to 300 μm is generally recognized as a minimum requirement before LASIK surgery. Hence, the calculation of central corneal thickness is an important element of preoperative evaluation.

Patient selection is of utmost importance in refractive eye surgeries. The following factors must be considered before taking up a patient for refractive eye surgery.

  • Minimum age of 21 years
  • Stable refraction for at least 1 year
  • Measurement of the central corneal thickness ( to calculate the residual stromal bed thickness)
  • A detailed review of ocular and systemic conditions

Limitations and contraindications of LASIK: The following group of patients poses a high risk for laser vision correction, and when done are associated with adverse surgical outcomes.

  • Collagen vascular disease
  • Autoimmune and immunodeficiency diseases
  • Pregnant and nursing mothers
  • Keratoconus
  • Chronic intake of isotretinoin and amiodarone
  • Fuchs corneal dystrophy
  • Ophthalmic herpes simplex and herpes zoster

Other options:

Option A- Punctate epithelial dystrophy (dry eye) is the most frequent complication of LASIK surgery, and the same can be managed with frequent lubrication using artificial tears.

Option B- Flap displacement usually occurs within 24 hours after surgery. Once diagnosed, the flap should be lifted and repositioned as soon as possible.

Option D- The corneal epithelium grows in the interface between the flap and stromal bed. This is termed epithelial ingrowth. If it causes vision disturbances, Nd:YAG laser application is warranted to treat the condition.

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures Lens-based procedures

Laser-based:

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

Refractive lens exchange

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Phakic intraocular lens
Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Clear lens extraction
Orthokeratology  
Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is present in skeletal muscles, but absent in a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But troponin is absent and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young female came to the Dermatology OPD with non-acantholytic blisters. She was advised to get a histopathological examination of the lesion done which revealed the pathology shown in the image. The most likely diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
Bullous Pemphigoid is characterized by subepidermal (as shown in the image) non-acantholytic blisters.

As the antibodies in bullous pemphigoid are directed against BPAg2 and BPAg1 present in the basement membrane zone, intercellular junctions are intact and acantholysis is not seen. Hence the blisters that form are non-acantholytic.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:

  • Pemphigus and its variants (Options C and D)
  • Acantholytic dermatosis
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease
  • Warty dyskeratoma

Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:

  • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles) (Option A)
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Solar keratoses
  • Squamous cell carcinoma - some forms like adenoid
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome 

Other options:

Option A: Varicella has intraepidermal blisters.

Option C: Pemphigus Vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal acantholytic blisters.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by subcorneal acantholytic blisters.

questions.text: The pre-anesthetic evaluation of a 33-year-old male who has been posted for surgery is conducted, and the oral cavity examined is as depicted in the image given below. This would be______________ according to Mallampati classification.
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, fauces, and part of the uvula are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class II.

Mallampati classification: Here the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity is assessed. The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult the intubation.

Mallampati class III and class IV are considered risk factors for difficult ventilation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text:
Which cyclin-CDK (cyclin-dependent kinase) combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition of cell cycle?

G2 - Gap 2
M - Mitotic
questions.solution:
Cyclin B-CDK1 combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

Related Pearl: Cell Cycle Regulators and Associated Cancers

Cell cycle regulator

Proto-oncogene

Mode of activation in tumor

Associated tumor

Cyclins

CCND1 (Cyclin D1)

Translocation

Amplification

Mantle cell lymphoma, multiple myeloma

Breast and esophageal cancers

Cyclin-dependent kinase

CDK4

Amplification or point mutation

Glioblastoma, melanoma, sarcoma

questions.text: A pregnant female at 36 weeks gestation, presents with palpitations, protrusion of the eyeball, and heat intolerance. On blood investigations, it was found that she had increased T3 and T4 levels and decreased TSH levels.  Which of the following should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is thyrotoxicosis. As she is in her third trimester, the drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis is methimazole.

Treatment of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy has been summarized in the table below.

Trimester Treatment options
First trimester

Propylthiouracil
Second trimester Methimazole (preferred)
Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester Methimazole

Thyrotoxicosis during pregnancy is usually controlled by thioamide drugs. Propylthiouracil was preferred previously because it partially inhibits the conversion of T4 to T3 and crosses the placenta less readily than methimazole. However, since it has a higher risk of causing propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy, methimazole is prescribed according to guidelines in the second trimester and third trimesters. Methimazole is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy. 

Other options:

Option B: Subtotal thyroidectomy is done once the hyperthyroidism is medically controlled. It is usually avoided during pregnancy, however, may be done in some cases in the second trimester where it can't be controlled via medication.

Option D: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it may cause fetal thyroid gland destruction.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

 Drugs inhibiting iodide trapping:

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient has completed a family and wanted a sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible. The following method of sterilization was done as shown below.
questions.solution:
The sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible and shown in the image is the Pomeroy technique.

The Pomeroy method is the most popular technique of tubal ligation in which the fallopian tube is identified on each side and brought out through the incision. The middle portion is then formed into a loop, tied at the base and excised. 

It is surgically reversible and has a short hospitalization. 

Other options:

Option A: In Uchida's method, the serosa in the midsegment of the tube is stripped off from the mucosa and then excised. The proximal segment is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimum tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty. 

Option B: The technique of fimbriectomy is irreversible. In this method, fimbria is excised. Thus, it is a permanent method of sterilisation. 

Option D: In Irving's procedure, the mid-portion of the tube is ligated with excision of the intervening portion. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible method and may require a laparotomy incision.

The below image shows Pomeroy technique

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the highlighted triangle?
questions.solution:
The highlighted triangle is the supraclavicular (subclavian/omoclavicular/ Ho's triangle) triangle. The spinal accessory nerve is not the content of this triangle.

The supraclavicular triangle is the lower and smaller division of the posterior triangle of the neck.

Boundaries :

  • Superior - inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle
  • Inferior - clavicle
  • Anterior - posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Posterior - anterior border of the trapezius

Contents:

  • Nerves - trunks of the brachial plexus, nerve to serratus anterior (long thoracic nerve of bell), suprascapular nerve, nerve to subclavius.
  • Vessels - the third part of the subclavian artery and vein, suprascapular artery and vein, the origin of the transverse cervical artery, lower part of the external jugular vein
  • Lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of facial pain from the last 2 weeks. Pain is on the right side of the face and is aggravated by bending forward. Tenderness can be elicited while palpating over the right cheek. The doctor suspects sinusitis. Which of the following best confirms the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnostic nasal endoscopy findings are used to confirm the diagnosis of sinusitis.

Indications of diagnostic nasal endoscopy:

  • To diagnose any disease of the nose and PNS.
  • To diagnose the source of bleeding in epistaxis.
  • To assess response to medical or surgical treatment of the nose and PNS disease.
  • To take a precise biopsy from the nose and nasopharynx.

questions.text: Which of the following mucopolysaccharidosis does not show leukocyte inclusions?
questions.solution:

Morquio disease is different from other mucopolysaccharidoses as it presents as spondyloepiphyseal skeletal dysplasia.

Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

  • Most common MPS: Sanfilippo > Hurler’s and Hunter’s
  • MPS with no mental retardation: Scheie’s disease, Morquio syndrome, and Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.
  • MPS with no corneal clouding: Hunter’s disease and Sanfilippo syndrome
  • MPS with XLR inheritance: Hunter’s disease
  • MPS with no visceromegaly: Morquio’s disease
  • Skeletal deformity associated with all MPS: Dysostosis multiplex
  • MPS with no leucocyte inclusions: Morquio’s disease

questions.text: Identify the area marked with a red arrow.
questions.solution:
The area marked in the red arrow is the hypoglossal trigone.

The above image represents the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is a shallow diamond-shaped depression on the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral half of the medulla. It contains the nuclei of the cranial nerves (V-XII).

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullaris
  • Striae medullaris divides the rhomboid fossa into 2parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

  • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

  • The bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
  • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
  • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

  • Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus
  • Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

  • Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought in to the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. An MRI  revealed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done and the image is given below. Which of the following test can be used for the diagnosis of the organism?
questions.solution:
The above image (showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasmosis bradyzoites encased in cysts with a cyst wall) and the case scenario suggest that the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep grey nuclei.

  • Acute lesions exhibit central necrosis, petechial hemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci.
  • Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by the gliotic brain.

Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma. IIF, IHA, and CFT (component fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. The dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine & leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Primary Prophylaxis:

  • Prior toxoplasmic encephalitis and CD4+ T cell count <200/μL: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin
  • TOXO IgG antibody positive and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL : Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX)
  • The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

Other options:

Option A: Casoni’s test is used for Hydatid cysts.

Option B: Bachman test is used for Trichinellosis.

Option D: Montenegro test is used for Leishmaniasis.

questions.text: An intern in ICU decides to insert a central venous catheter through a femoral vein in a burns victim to administer IV fluids. However, while inserting the needle, he accidentally injured a solid structure lying immediately medial to the femoral vein, lying within the femoral sheath. Which of the following drains into the injured structure?
questions.solution:
Deep inguinal lymph node (also known as the node of Cloquet) lies medial to the femoral vein and is likely to be injured in this case. The glans penis drains into the deep inguinal lymph node whereas, the rest of the penis drains into the superficial lymph nodes.

The scrotum drains into superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Femoral sheath is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains the femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains the femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and lymph node of Cloquet.

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING
Para - aortic lymph nodes Ovaries /Testis
External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis

 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with painful blisters over oral mucosa and genital areas. She gives a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Pemphigus Vulgaris.

Points in favor:

  • 40-year female
  • Painful blisters over oral mucosa and genitalia
  • Suprabasal split 
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg3 > Dsg1

Option A: Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Here there will be extremely pruritic vesicular eruptions over extensors.

Immunofluorescence shows Granular IgA deposits along with the dermal papillae.

Option C: Bullous pemphigoid

  • It usually affects elders (60-80 years).
  • Tense subepidermal blisters will be present.
  • No mucosal involvement (unlike pemphigus vulgaris).
  • Immunofluorescence: Linear IgG deposits.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus

  • No mucosal involvement.
  • Subcorneal blisters are seen.
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg1.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked area is pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion and side to side movement of the jaw.

In addition, lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted to the articular disc and capsule of TMJ.

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It inserted into the lateral surface of ramus of the mandible and coronoid process

Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and articular disc.

 Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from medial surface of lateral pterygoid plate and pyramidal process of palatine bone. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of mandible

questions.text: A 54-year-old incapacitated patient admitted under your care has an advance directive regarding his treatment. You believe the advance directive is not in the best interests of the patient and wish to follow a different clinical plan. Which of the following is the most suitable approach?

choices.text: Take consent from the relative/ caretaker whoever is available and proceed
Send an application to mental health board to alter the advance directive
Inform the ethics board of the hospital and proceed as per new plan
Proceed as per patient's advance directive as it is final and binding

questions.solution:
According to the Mental Health Care Act, 2017, the mental health professional who does not wish to follow the directive by the patient can write an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is expected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of serous otitis media, and type B tympanogram is seen with this condition.

Following features in the given image favours the diagnosis of serous otitis media.

  • The golden yellow colour of the tympanic membrane (due to clear watery straw-coloured effusion filling the middle ear)
  • Structures of the middle ear are seen clearly (due to the clear fluid in the middle ear cavity)
  • Thin leash of blood vessels are seen along the handle of the malleus and the periphery of the tympanic membrane (this differentiates the condition from ASOM where there is marked congestion of the tympanic membrane)

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A primigravida in her 1st trimester presents with genital prolapse. On examination, the cervix visible outside the introitus is replaced into the vagina and held in place by a ring pessary. What is the ideal time to remove the pessary?

choices.text: At the end of her 1st trimester

questions.solution:
Genital prolapse in pregnancy is treated with the application of a ring pessary which should be kept in place until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy, when the body of the uterus is sufficiently enlarged to sit on the brim of the pelvis.

Patients may present with copious vaginal discharge and a decubitus ulcer may develop if the cervix remains outside the introitus. If the uterus does not rise above the pelvis by the 16th week of pregnancy, there is a chance of incarceration of the uterus.

The symptoms are mostly pronounced in early pregnancy.

There is an increased chance of miscarriage, premature rupture of membranes and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy.

Treatment involves the application of a ring pessary to keep the cervix in place. A ring pessary is also used to treat prolapse in very elderly women who cannot be surgically managed. It is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy. It is also used in puerperium to facilitate involution.

The image below shows a ring pessary.

If the pelvic floor is too lax, the patient is advised to lie in bed with the foot end elevated, and the prolapsed mass is covered with a gauze soaked in glycerine and acriflavine. This is continued until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy till the prolapsed mass is reduced in size and replaced inside the vagina. 

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: A 32-year-old working woman is pregnant, she already has 2 surviving children. According to the Maternity Act 2017, what duration of paid leave would she receive?
questions.solution:
According to Maternity Act 2017, a working mother who already has 2 surviving children will be given a paid leave for a maximum duration of 12 weeks of which not more than 6 weeks precedes the expected date of delivery.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: There is a small school in a village, which has students from class 1-10. The classrooms are overcrowded and the area around the school is not clean. To ensure there is no breakout of tuberculosis, which of the following methods should the school adopt as primary prevention?

choices.text: Start ATT for those that are smear positive

questions.solution:
Reducing overcrowding in classrooms is a primary prevention method. Primary prevention is action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes/reduces the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Ex: Improving standard of living, vaccination, etc.

Other Options:

Option A: Starting ATT for those that are smear-positive would be secondary prophylaxis 

Option C: Educating children is a primordial prevention method. It aims to prevent  development of risk factors.

Option D: Screening symptomatic children with Mantoux is a secondary prevention method.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Aim

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Diagnosis and treatment

questions.text: You are a doctor posted in the emergency medicine department. There is an intubated patient who had been in a road traffic accident. Your PG examines him and tells you that the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 4 NT. Which of the following can the patient have?

choices.text: Eye opening to painful stimulus and withdrawal to pain
Eye opening to pressure and extension of limbs
Localizes pain and no eye opening
Eye opening to sound and flexion of limbs

questions.solution:
A patient who has eye opening to pressure (2) and extension of limbs (2) will have a GCS of 4. Because he is intubated, verbal response is not testable.

Option A: Eye opening to painful stimulus (2) and withdrawal to pain (4) gives a GCS of 6.

Option C: Localizes pain (5) and no eye opening (1) gives a GCS of 6.

Option D: Eye opening to sound (3) and flexion of limbs (4) gives a GCS of 7.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A young nulliparous female who desires pregnancy comes to you with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. On palpation, an abdominal mass corresponding to 14 weeks of gestation is felt. The mass is found to be a subserosal pedunculated fibroid on imaging. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in this nulliparous female with subserosal pedunculated fibroid is myomectomy. Myomectomy is indicated if the uterus size corresponds to more than 12 weeks of gestation and the patient desires pregnancy.

Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in fibroids which present with the following 

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size > 12 weeks, patient desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of the uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapid growth during follow up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid

Myomectomy can be performed by laparoscopy, hysteroscopy, or laparotomy. It is contraindicated in patients with an infected fibroid, pelvic or endometrial tuberculosis, suspected malignancy, and growth in post-menopausal and multiparous women where hysterectomy can be the safe definitive management.

Fibroids are benign estrogen dependant tumors of the uterine smooth muscles and connective tissue. 

Management of uterine fibroids in asymptomatic patients includes observation with regular follow-up regardless of the size of the fibroid. Surgery is indicated in cornual fibroids if it causes infertility or pedunculated fibroids (due to the risk of torsion). 

In symptomatic patients, medical therapy is done to shrink the fibroid. It acts as a preoperative adjunct. Surgical methods such as myomectomy, laparoscopic myolysis, hysterectomy, and endometrial ablation are tried for patients with persistent symptoms despite conservative management. Hysterectomy is done in postmenopausal women and in multiparous women who have completed their families or are not desirous of childbirth.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who visited North America presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Radiological examination of the chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. Culture from the abscess at 37°C, shows the appearance given in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of travel to North America suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces fungi. 

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and is also called North American Blastomycosis.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in contaminated soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  • Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, military lesions or abscess formation. 
  • Disseminated disease - can lead to multiple abscesses and has high fatality.
  • Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be a papule, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis when cultured at 37°C shows thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud.

Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option B- Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis. Infection is acquired by inhalation. Most infections are asymptomatic but infection of the reticuloendothelial system manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia and it is highly fatal. 

Option C- Coccidiodes immitis is also a dimorphic fungus causing coccidiomycosis. Infection is acquired through inhalation of dust-containing spores of the fungus. Mostly they are asymptomatic and a self-limiting influenza-like fever termed valley fever or desert rheumatism develops in some individuals. The infection leads to lifetime immunity. 

Option D- Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis is again a dimorphic fungus causing paracoccidioidomycosis also termed South American blastomycosis. Infection is initially acquired by the inhalation of spores causing primary pulmonary infection. It spreads to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics by hematogenous spread resulting in ulcerative granulomas of the buccal and nasal mucosa. 

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text: During the autopsy, the forensic expert performed the incision test after seeing the following changes on the skin of the body. What is the reason behind performing this test?

choices.text: To determine the cause of death.
To differentiate antemortem bruise from postmortem hypostasis.
It helps determine the methemoglobin level in the blood.
It clears the site of examination and improves the field of view during the autopsy.

questions.solution: The classic test used to differentiate a bruise from hypostasis is the incision test.The suspected area is incised to see if the underlying blood is intravascular (hypostasis) or infiltrating the tissues outside the vessels (contusion or bruise).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate >100 bpm
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with >3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

MAT is characterised by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia has a rate of 150-200 bpm. It also has a regular rhythm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. It can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation has an irregularly irregular rhythm. The rate is >300 bpm. The 'P' wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter has a regular rhythm. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw-tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: A medical student receives a booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccination. A few hours later, she develops weakness in the abduction and lateral rotation of that arm. Which nerve is most likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve or surgeon's nerve is frequently injured during inadvertent intramuscular (IM) injections. 

The course of axillary nerve:

  • It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus in the axilla
  • It exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm
  • In the arm, it winds around the surgical neck of the humerus and gives cutaneous supply to the lower part of the deltoid (upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm)

Injuries to the axillary nerve can be caused by:

  • Fracture of surgical neck of humerus
  • Inferior dislocation of the humerus
  • Inadvertent IM injection

Test for axillary nerve involves testing sensations of skin over the lower part of the deltoid. In the case of axillary nerve lesions, there is a loss of sensations over this region. It is called regimental badge anesthesia.

Named nerves of the upper limb are:

  • Laborer’s nerve - median nerve
  • Musician’s nerve - ulnar nerve
  • Surgeon’s nerve - axillary nerve
  • Nerve of Bell - long thoracic nerve

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the casualty with severe bleeding following a road traffic accident. He is a known cardiac disease patient on anticoagulant therapy.  As an intern, you were asked to collect blood for coagulation studies. Which colour vacutainer will you pick?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate.

The benefits of trisodium citrate are that the calcium ion is neutralized more rapidly in citrate.

Other anticoagulants are unacceptable for coagulation studies. The labile factors (factors V and VIII) are unstable in oxalate (grey), whereas heparin (green) and EDTA (lavender) directly inhibit the coagulation process and interfere with end-point determinations. Also, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) tests are more sensitive to the presence of heparin (green).

The image given below shows colour coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their practical uses.

Note: Heparin is used for blood sample collection for electrolyte estimation.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed to have Meniere's disease. He says he constantly gets vertiginous episodes when exposed to loud sounds. Which of the following term can be used to describe this symptom?
questions.solution:
Tullio phenomenon describes the vertiginous episodes associated with exposure to loud noise in a patient with Meniere's disease. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Pathogenesis not well understood.

Lermoyez syndrome - Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 48-year-old female who had undergone hysterectomy one year back, you notice the vault protrudes through the introitus. You would classify the vault prolapse as?
questions.solution:
Since the vault protrudes through the introitus, it is a second-degree vault prolapse.

Vault prolapse:

  • Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of both abdominal and vaginal hysterectomy when the supporting structures at the level I become weak and deficient.
  • It also results from failure to identify and repair an enterocele during a hysterectomy.
  • A technical error in the previous surgery, age, estrogen deficiency in a menopausal woman, parity, obesity, and chronic cough may contribute to its occurrence.

Management of Vault prolapse:

  • Right Transvaginal sacrospinous colpopexy is now considered the preferred surgery of choice in most cases.

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: Which component of  Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) has the highest maximum score?
questions.solution:
Skeletal and soft tissue injury component of Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) has a maximum score of 4 which is the highest.

Components of Mangled Extremity Severity score :

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischaemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

Other options:

Option B: Limb ischaemia component has a maximum score of 3.

Option C: Shock component has a maximum score of 2.

Option D: Patient’s age component has a maximum score of 2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who is a smoker presents with complaints of gastric reflux for the past 3 months. Endoscopy and biopsy results are as shown in the images given below. Which among the following histopathological images correctly represent the carcinoma which this patient would most likely develop?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus which has the potential to transform into an adenocarcinoma in the future. The slide B correctly represents an adenocarcinoma of esophagus showing tubular glands infiltrating the lamina propria and the squamous epithelium.

The given endoscopy reveals patches of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction.
The histopathological slide shows the intestinal type mucosa (left) replacing the normal squamous esophageal mucosa.
Hence a diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus can be confirmed.

Other options:

  • Slide A – Represents a normal squamous esophageal epithelium
  • Slide C – Represents a squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus. On high power, keratin pearls are characteristically seen in SCC.
  • Slide D – Represents a squamous papilloma of the esophagus which is a benign entity.

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

questions.text: Identify the hysterosalpingogram.
questions.solution:
The above hysterosalpingogram (HSG) shows bilateral dilated fallopian tubes with no free spill suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx.

 

Hysterosalpingogram: Filling defects:

In the images given above: A-Normal, B-Unicornuate, C-Arcuate, D to G-Septate uterus of different grades, H-Bicornuate, I-Didelphys

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the aortic valve will open at point ________.
questions.solution:
The aortic valve will open at point 3.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Pressure-volume diagram during the cardiac cycle:

The pressure-volume diagram plots the changes in the pressure and volume in the left ventricle that occur during the cardiac cycle. The X-axis shows the changes in ventricular volume, while the Y-axis shows the changes in ventricular pressure.

 

It has the following phases.

Phase I- This phase is called the period of filling and extends between points A and B. Point A is at the end of systole when the ventricular volume is about 50 mL. This volume is called end-systolic volume. The pressure at this point is about 2 to 3 mmHg. The volume and pressure go on increasing as the blood from the atrium flows to the ventricle during diastole. At the end of diastole, marked by point B, the ventricle will have a volume of around 120 mL. This volume is called end-diastolic volume. The pressure is slightly raised to 5-7 mmHg. 

Phase II- It is the phase of isovolumetric contraction, and extends between points B and C. At the end of diastole (point B), a slight increase in the ventricular pressure closes the mitral valve, and contraction starts. The ventricle contracts while both mitral and aortic valves are closed. Therefore, the pressure within the ventricle slowly rises without any changes in the volume. 

Phase III- It is the phase of ejection and extends between point C and point D. Point C is the place where the aortic valve opens. The pressure within the left ventricle rises slowly during isovolumetric contraction until it is sufficient to open the aortic valve. Once the aortic valve opens, blood within the left ventricle is ejected into the aorta. This decreases the volume of the left ventricle, while increasing the pressure within the ventricle.

Phase IV- It is the period of isovolumetric relaxation. It extends between points D and A. At the end of the ejection (Point D), the aortic valve closes. However, the ventricular relaxation continues despite closed aortic and mitral valves. Therefore, the ventricular pressure continues to fall while the volume remains the same. The ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 mL of blood left in the ventricle and pressure of about 2 to 3 mmHg.

End-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR)

ESPVR is the maximum pressure that can be developed by the ventricle at the end-systolic volume. It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops. This line can be extended down to the x-axis. The slope of this line is called as ESPVR slope.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman from Assam presented with fever and chills recurring every 48 hours. On examination, she was conscious, oriented, and febrile. CBC, LFT, and RFT were normal. Peripheral smear revealed the following. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing crescent-shaped gametocytes are suggestive of uncomplicated falciparum malaria. As this woman is from a North-Eastern state, the drug regimen of choice is ACT-AL (artemisinin combination therapy): 

  • Artemether (20mg)
  • Lumefantrine (120mg)  

This regimen is followed in the North-Eastern states of India due to documented resistance to sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine in these areas. ACT-AL is contraindicated in:

  • 1st trimester of pregnancy
  • Children < 5 kg

questions.text: A child presents with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia. X-Ray of femur showed Erlen Mayer flask deformity. Bone marrow shows cells with crumpled tissue paper appearance. Which of the following is accumulated in the cells?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features and bone marrow biopsy showing cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance suggest Gaucher’s disease. Glucocerebroside (glucosylceramide) is getting accumulated in the cells.

Gaucher's disease is a genetic disorder in which glucocerebroside accumulates in cells and certain organs due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase). It is characterized by the following clinical features:

  • Painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Hypersplenism and pancytopenia
  • Bleeding tendencies
  • Bone pain
  • Osteoporosis, pathological fractures, Erlenmeyer flask deformity
  • Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze palsy (seen in type 3)

Gaucher's cells - These are formed as a result of the accumulation of massive amounts of glucocerebrosides within the phagocytes. The cells have a fibrillary cytoplasm and give a crumpled tissue paper appearance.

Treatment:

  • Enzyme replacement therapy is available for type 1 disease in the form of:
    • Human recombinant acid β-glucosidase (Imiglucerase/ Velaglucerase alfa)
    • Taliglucerase alfa

Note: Neurological involvement is not seen in type 1 Gaucher's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the marked vessel?
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is the basilar artery. The posterior inferior cerebellar artery is not a branch of the basilar artery. It is a branch of the vertebral artery.

Branches of the basilar artery are:

  • Numerous pontine branches
  • Labyrinthine artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery

Note: Labyrinthine artery is usually a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, but variations in its origin include basilar artery, superior cerebellar artery and occasionally posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region. 

Related Pearl: Arteries supplying specific parts of the brain

  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior and posterior  choroidal arteries
  • Thalamogeniculate branch of PCA

  • Medial striate artery (Recurrent artery of Heubner) - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior choroidal artery - a branch of ICA
Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery

  • Posterior cerebral arteries

  • Basilar artery

  • Superior cerebellar arteries.

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: Identify the drug which causes this adverse effect ________
questions.solution:
Ergotamine causes occlusion of peripheral blood vessels in susceptible persons. It acts as a partial agonist and antagonist at α adrenoreceptors and all subtypes of 5HT1 and 5HT2 serotonin receptors.

The numbness progressing to bluish discoloration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can lead to gangrene if left untreated eventually leading to amputation. Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of ergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine: 

  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came to the local emergency department with severe headache and stiffness of the neck. The CSF specimen is cloudy. While in the emergency room, an intern performs gram stain of the CSF but by mistake forgets the step in which iodine is added. Assuming that the women has meningitis caused by streptococcus pneumoniae,  how would the bacteria on the intern’s slide appear?

choices.text: No gram stain results would be obtained due to lysis of all cells

questions.solution:
In the above question, the intern forgot to add iodine, i.e., the second step of gram staining. As a result, the purple iodine-dye complex will not form, and the entire crystal violet dye will wash away during the decolorization step. Now when the safranin is added, all the cells will stain red.

The various steps in gram staining are as follows:

  • The crystal violet dye (basic dye) stains all cells purple.
  • The iodine solution (a mordant) is added to form a crystal violet–iodine complex. At the end of this step, all cells continue to appear purple.
  • In the decolorization step, the organic solvent, such as acetone or ethanol, extracts the blue dye complex from the lipid-rich, thin-walled gram-negative bacteria to a greater degree than from the lipid-poor, thick-walled gram-positive bacteria. At the end of this step, the gram-negative organisms appear colorless; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.
  • The red dye safranin (counterstain) stains the decolorized gram-negative cells red/pink; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.
