questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with a mass protruding from the anterior vaginal wall that appears like grape clusters. Histopathological examination reveals tadpole cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides).

It is an uncommon vaginal tumor composed of malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. It is most frequently found in infants and in children < 5 years of age. They are locally invasive tumors that cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity or by obstruction of the urinary tract.

Grossly, polypoid, rounded, bulky masses that appear like grape clusters can be seen. On microscopy, small tumor cells with oval nuclei, and small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end resembling a tennis racket (tadpole cells) can be seen. Beneath the vaginal epithelium, the tumor cells are crowded in a cambium layer, in the dermis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old nulliparous woman presents with menorrhagia for 3 months. The first day of her last menstrual period (LMP) was 3 weeks ago. She undergoes a Pap smear which shows atypical glandular cells of unknown significance. How would you proceed with further management?

choices.text: Schedule an endometrial and cervical sampling

questions.solution:
The pap smear shows atypical glandular cells in a woman aged ≥35 years should proceed with an endometrial and cervical sampling.

Atypical glandular cells on a Pap smear usually signify underlying cervical or endometrial neoplasia. The glandular abnormality is evaluated by doing a colposcopy and endocervical curettage. Endometrial biopsy is also needed in the following cases to be certain that the endometrial cells originated in the endometrium:

  • Female patients ≥ 35 years.
  • Female patients < 35 years, and a risk factor for endometrial diseases like abnormal uterine bleeding(AUB) or anovulation.

Other options:

Options A & D: Since the atypical glandular cells are seen on a pap smear, we need to sample the endometrium and cervix to see from where the cells have originated. Colposcopy will help in locating abnormal areas and accurately obtaining a directed biopsy from the suspicious areas on the cervix. Hence, only an endometrial biopsy or only colposcopy(Option D) is not sufficient.

Option B: Loop electrosurgical excision procedure is an acceptable option for patients who have moderately severe to severe dysplasias. As the pap smear shows atypical glandular cells, colposcopy with endocervical curettage and endometrial sampling is required before an excisional procedure is considered. 

 

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: A 34-year-old male who was newly diagnosed with HIV is being evaluated prior to initiation of antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following techniques is used to determine the CD4+ cell count in his peripheral blood?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is used to determine the CD4 count in the peripheral blood.

Flow cytometry is a laser based method which analyzes the cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules which are named as per cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature.

There are about 300 types of CD molecules. Monoclonal antibodies against specific CD molecules are tagged with fluorescent labels. Incubation of the cells with a variety of different CD labeled antibodies allows the flow cytometric analysis of distinct populations of cells in the mixture.

Flow cytometry is routinely used in identifying CD4-positive cells, CD8-positive cells, B cells, macrophages, and cells expressing a variety of cytokines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: An ICU patient with a central venous catheter developed sepsis. A bacterial skin commensal was found to be grown in the blood culture. Which of the following laboratory results is appropriate for the organism found in the blood culture?

choices.text: Catalase negative, coagulase negative, optochin sensitive
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive
Catalase negative, coagulase positive, bacitracin resistant

questions.solution:
Skin commensal responsible for catheter-related bloodstream infections are coagulase-negative Staphylococcus namely Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, and novobiocin sensitive.

Novobiocin sensitivity distinguishes S. epidermidis from S.saprophyticus.

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of seizures. Examination revealed delayed milestones. Chest and abdominal examination showed no significant findings. Fundoscopy revealed the following image. The enzyme that could be deficient in the child is:
questions.solution:
The presence of seizures, developmental delay, and cherry-red spots in the fundus (seen in the image), in an infant without hepatosplenomegaly, is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, which is due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A.

In this condition, there is an accumulation of the lipid ganglioside. Other features include mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness. 

Other options:

Option A: β-Glucosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease, which commonly has a combination of developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly with the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency leads to Niemann-Pick disease, where infants exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, interstitial lung disease, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option D: α-Galactosidase deficiency leads to Fabry disease, which has symptoms of skin rash, kidney, heart failure, and burning pain in the lower extremities.

questions.text: A known cardiac patient was advised not to take omeprazole while he is on clopidogrel medication. What is the liver enzyme common to the metabolism of these drugs?
questions.solution:
CYP2C19 is the liver enzyme common to the metabolism of Clopidogrel and Omeprazole.

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that is activated to its active metabolite by the liver enzyme CYP2C19. Apart from CYP2C19, CYP3A4, and CYP2C9 are also involved to a certain extent.

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19. Thus, omeprazole may inhibit the activation of clopidogrel and decrease its antiplatelet action.

questions.text: Which of the following patients is most likely to develop thyroid storm?

choices.text: A 45 year old man with Grave's disease and pneumonia
A 32 year old woman with toxic nodule and no complaints
A 27 year old woman with long-standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis on treatment
A 56 year old man with TSH secreting adenoma and no complaints

questions.solution:
Thyroid storm occurs most commonly in patients with underlying Grave's disease probably due to an acute elevation in catecholamine levels during infection, surgery, cessation of antithyroid medication, or any form of stress.

Thyroid storm refers to the abrupt onset of severe hyperthyroidism. It is a medical emergency where a significant number of untreated patients die of cardiac arrhythmias.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who presented with diarrhea and flushing was found to have an ileal tumor. The histological image of the resected specimen is given below. Which of the following markers will these cells be positive for?
questions.solution:
The given history and histological image are diagnostic of ileal carcinoid. The tumor cells are typically positive for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry.

Histology of carcinoid typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules.

Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum. These tumors may cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:

  • Neuron-specific enolase
  • Synaptophysin
  • Chromogranin A
  • Leu 7

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A young man met with a bike accident. He lost all his motor, sensory, and autonomic functions of the spinal cord below the level of the lesion. However, vibration and position sensations are preserved. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis of the patient is Anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome. 

ASA infarct typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion. Since the dorsal column is located in the posterior or dorsal aspect of the spinal cord, it is spared.

Other options:

Central cord syndrome:

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and crossing spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. In the cervical cord, the central cord syndrome produces arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness and a “dissociated” sensory loss, meaning loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution), in contrast to the preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in these regions.

Foramen magnum syndrome:

Around the clock pattern of weakness is described and manifests as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. The pattern of the weakness may begin in any of the limbs. 

Brown–Sequard Syndrome: ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract) and loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column), with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract) one or two levels below the lesion

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease, acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Betahistine (vertin), used in the medical management of Meniere's disease acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels, thereby improving the microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea. It is also found to inhibit the vestibular nuclei activity.

Other drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease are

  • Prochlorperazine (stemetil), is a vestibular sedative.
  • Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control recurrent attacks.
  • Propantheline bromide (probanthine), an anticholinergic agent is also found to be effective.

questions.text: A patient is brought with bleeding from a deep penetrating wound in his right thigh. His pulse is weak and 100/min, BP is 90/60 mmHg. The skin on his extremities is cold and clammy. Which of the following is the best method of restoring adequate cardiac output and tissue oxygenation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of hemorrhagic shock.

In the case of hemorrhagic shock, the most effective method of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by locating and stopping the source of bleeding.

Volume repletion will allow recovery from the shock state only when the bleeding has stopped. The first-line agents are crystalloids.

Since the patient already has cutaneous vasoconstriction, vasopressors are not administered without prior adequate fluid resuscitation to avoid further vasoconstriction and gangrene formation.

Nearly 70% of the body’s total blood volume is estimated to be located in the venous circuit. Compliance of the venous system involves a relationship between venous volume and venous pressure. This pressure gradient drives venous flow and therefore the volume of venous return to the heart. Blood loss depletes this component of venous volume and reduces the pressure gradient; consequently, venous return is reduced.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OP with painful genital ulcers. Gram staining revealed gram-negative coccobacilli as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a suitable culture medium?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painful genital ulcer with gram-negative coccobacilli arranged in parallel chains is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the suitable culture medium of Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid or soft sore is a venereal disease characterized by tender non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia. This infection remains localized, spreading only to the regional lymph nodes which are enlarged and painful. The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'rail road track' appearance.

On chocolate agar, enriched with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum, and containing vancomycin as a selective agent, H.ducreyi forms small, grey translucent colonies after incubation at 35°C under 10% CO and 2 high humidity in 2-8 days.

H.ducreyi requires X factor, but not V factor for growth. H.influenzae requires X and V factor for growth.

Note: Fish in-stream appearance is seen in Vibrio cholera.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A screening test that has 80% sensitivity is done on two towns A and B. The prevalence of the disease is 10% in A and 40% in B. What does a positive test result mean?

choices.text: The person definitely has the disease, whether he lives in A or B
The person does not have the disease, whether he lives in A or B
A person living in A who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive
A person living in B who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive

questions.solution:
A person living in B who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive.

The predictive value of a positive test indicates the probability that a patient with a positive test result has, in fact, the disease (true positive). This predictive value depends on the sensitivity, specificity, and the disease prevalence. If the disease is more prevalent in a given population, the predictive value of the positive screening test will be more accurate. Hence, a positive test in a person living in town B, which has a higher prevalence is more likely to be a true positive.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following is used to stabilise a fracture of the distal femur as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a rail fixator.

In this type of external fixator, multiple pins are inserted into the bone. These pins are then attached to different blocks which can move over a track or rail.

Given below is an Ilizarov ring fixator. Here, pins are attached to an adjustable ring system.

Tension band wiring is used in the fixation of transverse patellar fractures. In this method, two K-wires are used to transfix the reduced patellar fragments and a flexible wire is looped around them tightly.

The following X-ray image shows tibial intramedullary interlocking nailing.

questions.text: First-line treatment for a patient presenting with the symptom shown below is _______
questions.solution:
The first-line treatment for this condition is albendazole.

The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Ivermectin and albendazole are the first-line drugs for the treatment of cutaneous larva migrans.

Dosage and frequency:

  • Ivermectin - 200μg/kg orally single dose
  • Albendazole - 400mg orally for 3 days

questions.text: A Chinese man was brought to the hospital with complaints of difficulty in breathing, fever, and chills. After admission, the patient developed rapidly progressive pulmonary edema. There is a history of coming in contact with a deer mouse burrow a few days back. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: The pathogen is classified under Bunyaviridae family
Laboratory diagnosis depends on viral nucleic acid detection by RT-PCR
The case fatality rate is 30% or higher in pulmonary syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical picture and history are suggestive of hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS). Human to human transmission is never reported in hantavirus infection.

  • Hantavirus is classified under Bunyaviridae.
  • Transmission to humans occurs by inhaling aerosols of rodent excreta.
  • Hantavirus causes:
    • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome
    • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome
  • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is characterized by influenza-like illness followed rapidly by respiratory failure.
  • The case fatality rate is 30% or higher in hantavirus pulmonary syndrome
  • Laboratory diagnosis depends on viral nucleic acid detection by RT-PCR

questions.text: A drug that acts as a rheologic modifier and is hence used in the treatment of lower limb claudication is __________
questions.solution:
Pentoxifylline is a rheologic modifier used in the treatment of lower limb claudication.

It is a methylxanthine derivative and it increases the deformability of red blood cells hence called a rheologic modifier.

Other uses of pentoxifylline are:

  • Prevention of atherosclerosis
  • Prevention of cardiovascular events like acute coronary syndromes
  • Control of stable angina
  • Prevention of stroke and transient ischaemic attacks
  • Treatment of acute ischaemic stroke
  • Slowing of progression of vascular dementia
  • Preservation of tissues after thrombolytic therapy
  • Decreased inflammation and tissue damage following cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Improved outcomes in congestive heart failure
  • Improved diabetic control

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

questions.text: An AIDS patient presented with neurological symptoms like seizures, focal neurological deficits, and diplopia. There is history of headache, nausea, dizziness, irritability, and a low-grade fever for the past 3 months. Brain biopsy showed granulomatous inflammation, trophozoites, and cysts. The trophozoites were large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia. Which of the following organisms is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granulomatous amebic encephalitis. It is caused by acanthamoeba.

Granulomatous amebic encephalitis: It is a granulomatous infection of the brain and spinal cord that typically occurs in persons with a compromised immune system. 

  • Granulomatous amebic encephalitis is believed to follow the inhalation of the dried cysts. The incubation period is long and the evolution of the illness is slow. 
  • The clinical picture is that of intracranial space-occupying lesions with seizures, pareses and mental deterioration.
  • Diagnosis of GAE is made by demonstration of trophozoites (The trophozoites are large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized
    by spine-like pseudopodia)     and cysts in brain biopsy, culture and immunofluorescence microscopy using monoclonal antibodies.

Other options:

Naegleria fowleri a pathogenic free-living amoeba which causes the disease primary amoebic meningoencephalitis(PAM)

Naegleria fowleri:

  • Patients are mostly previously healthy young adults or children, the infection comes from water containing free-living amoeba and usually follows swimming or diving in ponds.
  • The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis (PAM).
  • The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.
  • In the incubation period, the patient experiences anosmia, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck, ataxia, seizure and coma and ends fatally within a Week. (average 5 days). 

Toxoplasma: Trophozoites are crescent-shaped and are 3-7 μm in size.

Plasmodium falciparum: Runs more acute course. In peripheral blood smear, ring forms and gametocytes are seen.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl complains of lower abdominal pain. History reveals she has mild pain around the time of ovulation every month and the pain subsides within a few hours. Pelvic examination is normal. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
Acute lower abdominal pain around ovulation that typically subsides within a few hours indicates ovulatory pain or Mittelschmerz syndrome. It is treated conservatively with rest and NSAIDs such as acetaminophen.

The pain has been hypothesised to be due to the following reasons:

  • Swelling of the ovarian follicles around the time of ovulation
  • Disruption of the ovarian surface epithelium during ovulation
  • Irritation of the peritoneum by blood from ruptured Graafian follicle
  • Contraction of ovarian smooth muscle and ligaments
  • Contraction of the fallopian tube

The pain may be one sided or bilateral. When one sided, it can be used to predict the ovary involved in ovulation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. α1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases.

The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that are characteristic of this disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathology showed the following appearance. Which of the following is true about this tumour?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Mutation in CDH-1 gene is associated with lobular carcinoma.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

ER-positive, HER2- negative

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she presented with seizures, aphasia, and hemiparesis. Which of the following investigations is useful to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis. This condition can be diagnosed using MR venography.

Cortical vein thrombosis :    

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Prothrombotic conditions

Clinical presentation is highly variable. Headache is the most common symptom. Motor or sensory deficits may be seen. Seizures along with focal deficits in the absence of raised intracranial pressure are suggestive of cortical venous thrombosis. Brain MRI with MR venography is a sensitive investigation to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: The deformity depicted here is:
questions.solution:
In the given image, there is hump (or bump) in the dorsum of the nose, hence the deformity depicted is a hump nose.

The hump may involve the bone or cartilage or both bone and cartilage. This is corrected by a reduction rhinoplasty.

Option B: Deviated nose - Midline is straight but deviated to one side.

 

Option C: In crooked nose, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner. 

Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who has regular periods and is sexually active comes with a history of new onset post-coital bleeding. She mentions that her last period was much heavier than usual. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a pap smear in the OPD

questions.solution:
In this patient with a history of new-onset post-coital bleeding and menorrhagia, cervical cancer can be suspected in the patient, and a pap smear would be the next step in management to rule it out.

Papanicolaou test or pap test is a screening test routinely employed in gynaecological practice. 

 The screening guidelines include the following

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Cytology alone is done in women aged 21-29 years, every 3 years. 
  • In women who are aged 30-65 years, for every 5 years, FDA-approved primary hrHPV testing and co-testing (hrHPV testing and cytology) are done and cytology alone, is done every 3 years
  • Women can stop cervical cancer screening if previous negative results after the age of 65 years or hysterectomy along with cervix removal are done.

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain.

The instruments used for pap smear are summarized in the image below.

Pap smear should be obtained prior to the vaginal examination (Option A), because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report, the lubricant may prevent detection of organisms, and any vaginal bleeding during the examination may preclude proper visualization of the cervix.

The laboratory investigations and transvaginal ultrasound can be ordered after taking a Pap smear and doing a per-vaginal examination. (Options C and D). A transvaginal ultrasound should be taken to assess the endometrial thickness and rule out any fibroids. Hemoglobin levels should be estimated to assess the need for iron supplementation since heavy blood loss can cause anemia.

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

The image given below shows a normal pressure-volume loop.

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is Hurler's syndrome.

As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Other options:

Option A- Tay-Sachs disease is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase-A resulting in the excess storage of GM2 ganglioside within the lysosomes of cells. The clinical features include developmental delay, intellectual impairment, seizures, and breathing difficulty.

The CT image shows macrocephaly and reduced attenuation of the cerebral white matter. MRI can delineate deep white matter demyelination, and indicate calcification in thalami on T2 weighted sequences.

Option C- Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance due to the deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of a glycolipid (glucocerebroside) within the lysosomes of macrophages.

The clinical features include bone pain, pathological fractures, bone crises hepatosplenomegaly, and hematological disturbances.

The radiological features of the skeletal involvement include osteopenia, osteonecrosis, fractures (pathological), Erlenmeyer flask deformity, and H-shaped vertebra.

Option D- Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 2 resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

The clinical features include abnormal facies characterized by the prominent forehead, flattened nasal bridge, coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, hepatosplenomegaly.

These patients lack clouding of the cornea.

The radiological features include thickened calvaria, enlargement of the skull, broad clavicle and ribs, thoracolumbar kyphosis, hip dysplasia, and genu valgum deformity.

questions.text: Suspicious deaths were occurring after receiving parcels via mail in the USA. The microscopy of the specimen collected showed the following appearance. The bioterrorism agent involved can also show ___________
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a bioterrorism agent with the gram stain showing a box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance is suggestive of Bacillus anthracis (Category A bioterrorism agent). Bacillus anthracis can also show a medusa head appearance on microscopy.

Bacillus anthracis is a non-motile gram-positive bacillus that has a characteristic box car or a bamboo stick appearance on gram staining. On the agar plate, they form irregular round colonies that are raised, dull, greyish-white colonies giving a frosted glass appearance as given in the image below.

Long interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling matted hair, are present on the edge of the colonies giving it a medusa-head appearance when seen on low-power microscopy.

M’Fadyean’s reaction is used to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule which is stained with polychrome methylene blue. It also shows an inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab culture. On a solid media containing penicillin, the colonies give a string of pearls appearance as given in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A: A fried egg appearance of colonies is seen in the case of Mycoplasma.

Option C: Draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies on blood agar is seen in the case of Streptococcus pneumonia, as given in the image below.

Option D: A fluorescent antibody-stained specimen of Yersinia pestis reveals rod-shaped bacteria with characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin or hairpin-like appearance.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of psychiatric illness presents to the outpatient. She admits to abusing diuretics for the past 2 weeks. On examination, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. With respect to extracellular fluid volume (ECF), intracellular fluid volume (ICF), and plasma sodium, which of the following changes will this patient have?

choices.text: Increased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Increased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium

questions.solution:
Diuretic overuse shows decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium, leading to hypoosmotic volume contraction.

A similar picture is seen in adrenal insufficiency. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Other Options:

Option A: This is seen in cases of hypoosmotic volume expansion like in the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) and bronchogenic tumors. 

SIADH is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Option B: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume contraction like in diabetes insipidus and excessive sweating.

Option D: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume expansion like in high NaCl intake. The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

The illustration given below shows the Darrow-Yannet diagram in various conditions.

questions.text: An intern, during his medicine postings, was asked to calculate the cardiac index of a patient whose heart rate is 80 beats/min and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient's heart was able to pump 75 mL of blood from each ventricle per heartbeat and the body surface area was determined to be 1.5 sq. meters. What would be the value of the calculated cardiac index?
questions.solution:
The cardiac index is the cardiac output per minute per square meter of the body surface. It would be 4 L/min/m2. 

Cardiac index = Cardiac output/body surface area

Cardiac output is given as follows:

Cardiac output = heart rate X stroke volume.

The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of each ventricle per beat (i.e. 75 mL in the given question) and heart rate is given as 80 beats/min.

Cardiac Output = heart rate X stroke volume = 80 X 75 mL = 6 L/min

Therefore, cardiac index = 6 L/min/1.5 m2 = 4 L/min/m2 

It has been observed that cardiac output increases proportionally with an increase in body surface area. Hence, cardiac output is frequently expressed in terms of cardiac index.

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: In which of the following patients is it least advisable for the following airway maneuver to be performed?

choices.text: A 44 year old patient that suddenly collapsed in his chair and is now unresponsive
A 9 year old child that suddenly collapsed during jogging and is now unresponsive
A 23 year old patient that fell from height and is now unresponsive
A 62 year old diabetic patient that collapse in the ward and is now unresponsive

questions.solution:
The airway manoeuvre shown is the head tilt and the chin lift. This should not be performed in those with a suspected cervical spine injury. It is prudent to exclude the manoeuvre from the medical plan of a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury after a fall from a height. 

Basic life support (BLS) involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. In such cases a head tilt, chin lift manouver may be performed. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead, applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat. Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

A jaw thrust can be performed in a patient with cervical injury, but caution must be exercised to not hyperextend the neck. Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head, and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It

questions.text: A 36-year-old Mexican male had a tick bite following which he develops fever, headache, and rashes. Later he is diagnosed with Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Drug of choice for  Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever(RMSF) is Doxycycline.

RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. It is usually transmitted by ticks. Fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia are the most common symptoms during the first 3 days. Rash is evident in only 14% of patients on the first day of illness .

The most common serologic test for confirmation of the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay.

The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. It is administered orally at 100 mg twice daily.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of loose stools. On history taking, he reveals to have consumed food from a bakery 3 hours back. Which of the following is wrong about the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an acute episode of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The toxin involved, enterotoxins, are heat stable.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hours after consuming contaminated food (other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hours is Bacillus cereus-Emetic strains).

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

Enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus:

  • There are 15 enterotoxins, they are superantigens
  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile).
  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.
  • Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

  • Bacillus anthracis

questions.text: The iceberg phenomenon in epidemiology is not shown by ____.
questions.solution:
The iceberg phenomenon in epidemiology is not shown by measles.

Diseases like tuberculosis, diabetes, malnutrition, anemia, hypertension and mental illnesses show the iceberg phenomenon of disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

The iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: A patient who was hospitalized and started on an intravenous antibiotic has developed diarrhea. The findings of the colonoscopy are given below. Which of the following antibiotic is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis most likely due to clindamycin. 

Pseudomembranous colitis is an advanced form of clostridium difficile infection (CDI) that is visualized at endoscopy. Pseudomembranes are seen as whitish yellow plaques on the mucosa. Clostridium difficile infection is the most commonly diagnosed nosocomial diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, that causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora. This leads to the colonization of C. difficile.

Antibiotics that may cause CDI are:

  • Clindamycin
  • Ampicillin
  • Cephalosporins- cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ceftazidime
  • Fluroquinolones- ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin

Clinical features include diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria: 

  • Diarrhea without other recognized causes, and
  • Detection of toxin A or B in the stool, toxin-producing C. difficile in the stool 

Discontinuation of the offending antimicrobial, if possible, is the first step in management. Oral vancomycin and fidaxomicin (Option B) are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

Other options:

Option A: Daptomycin may cause allergic pneumonitis in patients receiving prolonged therapy for more than 2 weeks.

Option D: Chloramphenicol is mainly associated with adverse effects such as bone marrow suppression, and hypersensitivity reactions. When given to infants, it may cause grey baby syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been extensively smoking for the past 5 years, presents to the ED with a sudden onset of fever with hemoptysis and hematuria. On examination, he is dyspneic and pale. A panel of blood investigations done on him shows anemia with deranged renal function. The nephrologist suspects him to have antibodies against α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and proceeds to perform an urgent renal biopsy. Which of the following histological pattern is expected to be present in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features, lab investigations, and suspicion of having antibodies against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV narrows down the diagnosis to Goodpasture’s syndrome. The expected histologic pattern in this patient is the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, as seen in image B.

Patients who develop antibodies against glomerular basement antigens frequently develop glomerulonephritis termed anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. When glomerulonephritis is combined with lung haemorrhage, as seen in our case, it is termed Goodpasture’s syndrome.

Certain features of the anti-GBM disease

  • The autoantibodies are directed against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group.
  • The clinical presentation can occur in two groups
    •  Younger men in their late twenties
      • They present in an explosive manner with hemoptysis, a sudden fall in hemoglobin, fever, dyspnoea, and hematuria
      • Lung haemorrhage is a usual presentation in smokers, but surprisingly they do better than the other group
    • Older men and women in their sixties and seventies
      • These geriatric populations run a prolonged, asymptomatic course and end up with chronic renal failure with oliguria, and the prognosis is usually worse.

Characteristic histological pattern progresses as given below

  • Focal or segmental necrosis
  • Crescent formation (due to the destruction of capillaries by excessive cellular proliferation)
  • Interstitial nephritis with fibrosis and tubular atrophy

Immunofluorescent staining shows a linear pattern for IgG.

Other images

Image A shows a normal glomerulus

Image C shows segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli

Image D shows diffuse thickening of the basement membrane

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was diagnosed with constipation and was started on senna laxatives. After 5 months, the patient came to the hospital with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping. The colonoscopy of the patient is shown. The diagnosis of this patient is ____________
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a black pigmentation of colonic mucosa that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coil.

As the laxative travels down the intestinal tract, it remains in its inactive form until it reaches the large intestine. Once in the large intestine, the molecules transform into their active form. These active forms of laxative lead to cell damage in the lining of the intestine and death by apoptosis and create a dark pigment, lipofuscin, which eventually lines the large bowel. Eventually, these dead cells are taken up by macrophages. Melanosis coli can occur within only a few months of chronic laxative use. 

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: bisacodyl, sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: senna, cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: prucalopride
    • Fixed oil: castor oil
    • Prostaglandin analogue- lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulfate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulfate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose

The main indication of laxatives is the prevention and treatment of acute and chronic constipation.

Docusates are associated with side effects like cramps, abdominal pain, and hepatotoxicity on prolonged usage. Liquid paraffin may be associated with foreign body granulomas, lipid pneumonia, and vitamin deficiencies. Bisacodyl may cause allergic reactions.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with fungal infection of the sinuses and periorbital region, with significant visual impairment, as shown below. Vascular involvement and thrombosis are seen in the biopsy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The description of the patient typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection in diabetes mellitus, leukemia, and lymphoma patients. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus oryza.

The agents of zygomycosis are angioinvasive. The major clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis. It results from the germination of the sporangiospores in the nasal passages of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels. This causes thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The disease progress to invade the paranasal sinuses, eyes, cranial bone, and brain. It damages blood vessels and nerves, thereby developing edema of the involved facial area, a bloody nasal exudate, and orbital cellulitis.

A culture of nasal discharge, tissue, or sputum will show broad hyphae with uneven thickness, irregular branching, and sparse septations.

Treatment includes aggressive surgical debridement, rapid administration of amphotericin B, and control of the underlying disease.

Other options:

Option A: Coccidioidomycosis primarily includes pulmonary infection. It is caused by Coccidioides immitis. A self-limited influenza-like fever may occur in some individuals. Disseminated disease is seen in less than 1% of the people

Option B: Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It presents as a pulmonary disease that resembles tuberculosis. Disseminated histoplasmosis involves infection of the reticuloendothelial system which manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia.

Option D: Aspergillosis is a spectrum of diseases that are caused by a number of Aspergillus species. It can either present as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, or invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of resistance to acyclovir in HSV-1?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of resistance to acyclovir in HSV-1 is deficient or absent viral thymidine kinase activity.

Viral thymidine kinase is needed in the conversion of acyclovir to acyclovir triphosphate which competitively inhibits the viral DNA polymerase activity.  

Mutation of viral DNA polymerase is rare.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with congestive cardiac failure develops sudden onset skin rashes, tongue swelling, and stridor. He had taken a newly prescribed tablet today morning. Which medication is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of drug-induced angioedema. The drug most likely to have caused this is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor like captopril. 

ACE inhibitors can cause angioedema in a small group which presents as swelling of the throat, mouth, tongue, and glottis. It is usually self-limiting once the drug is discontinued. Glucocorticoids, antihistamines, or epinephrine can be given if required. 

Other adverse effects include hypotension, dry cough, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure.  A rarer complication is visceral angioedema marked by vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It is a known teratogen and needs to be replaced with other drugs during pregnancy/ birth control measures should be advised.

These drugs are inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system and are commonly used in hypertension, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and acute myocardial infarction. 

Other options:

Option A: Propranolol is a nonselective beta-receptor antagonist. Side effects include bronchospasm, depression, and insomnia. It is not recommended for diabetics as it can mask hypoglycemic symptoms.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic can cause hypotension, hypokalemia, and hyponatremia.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist which can cause dry mouth, sedation, and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: The amino acid deficient in carcinoid syndrome has which of the following groups?
questions.solution:
The amino acid deficient in carcinoid syndrome is tryptophan. It has an indole group.

Carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours producing serotonin. Serotonin is synthesized in the body from tryptophan. Carcinoid patients can have tryptophan deficiency as the normal intake of niacin and tryptophan don’t meet the demand from the cancer cells. Tryptophan has an indole group.

Tryptophan deficiency results in pellagra.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be activated after a carbohydrate-rich meal?
questions.solution:
Only phosphofructokinase 2 will be activated after a meal.

Phosphofructokinase 2 is a bifunctional enzyme that can phosphorylate fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 2,6 bisphosphate during glycolysis. The same enzyme protein is also responsible for its breakdown since it has fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase activity.

When there is an abundant supply of glucose, the concentration of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate increases, stimulating glycolysis by activating phosphofructokinase-1 and inhibiting fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase. 

Other options:

HMG CoA lyase is an enzyme involved in ketogenesis which occurs during the fasting state.

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis which is favored by glucagon during the fasting state.

Insulin indirectly inhibits β-oxidation by activating acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis) and increasing the malonyl-CoA concentration in the cytoplasm, which inhibits carnitine acyltransferase (Fatty acid oxidation).

questions.text: A young man, during a property dispute, attacked his brother with an axe. His brother sustained a 14x7 cm laceration in the left thigh and fracture of the left femur shaft. The man who attacked is punishable under which of the following section of IPC?
questions.solution:
He should be punished under Section 326.

Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapon(imprisonment upto 10 years with fine).

Section 320 of IPC states that the following kinds of hurt only are designated as “grievous”:
  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Other options:

  • Section 320 - defines grievous hurt
  • Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt).
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment upto 7 years with fine)

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady was started on an ocular medication that she was instructed to take daily. She develops redness of the eye. Examination reveals a colour change of the iris and orbital fat atrophy. Which of the following medications was she likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a patient that has iris pigmentation and redness of the eye, was most likely started on latanoprost.

Drug Side Effects
Latanoprost

Allergic conjunctival hyperemia, permanent increase in iris pigmentation, orbital fat atrophy.
Timolol  Exacerbation of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, impotence 
Scopolamine Photosensitivity, blurred vision 
Pilocarpine Corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia, decreased vision, brow ache, retinal detachment

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of his nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. The histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a nodule on the nose and the given histological image showing Mikulicz cells are suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli. The history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodules corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). It has 3 stages:

1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.

3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called a tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option A: Even though the inner canthus of the eye is a common site for the occurrence of basal cell carcinoma, the given histology does not show palisade of the basaloid epithelium, which is very classical of BCC.

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman presents at 34 weeks gestation with bleeding per vaginum (PV). She had 3 episodes of spotting during this pregnancy, which resolved on their own. She has no pain. On examination, vitals are stable and the fetus is found to be in transverse lie with a fetal heart rate of 140 beats/min. What is the gold standard investigation to diagnose the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This woman’s history is suggestive of placenta previa, for which the gold standard investigation would be an MRI. The sagittal images of the MRI best demonstrate the relationship of the placenta to the internal cervical os, although it is not required in most instances.

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. Placenta previa and abruptio placenta together account for 70% of the cases of antepartum hemorrhage.

Other Options:

A transvaginal sonogram (TVS) is more accurate to assess placenta praevia, as the transabdominal sonogram overdiagnoses it.

Note: Transvaginal sonogram (TVS) is the most common investigation, but MRI is the gold standard investigation to diagnose placenta previa since it demonstrates the relationship of the placenta to the internal cervical os.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. On examination, there was no discharge from the cervix. Microscopy reveals the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a clue cell - an epithelial cell with a fuzzy border due to adherence of bacteria. This along with the given clinical features suggests bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: According to DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs, uterosacral ligaments belong to which level of pelvic support?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey, the uterosacral ligaments and cardinal ligaments belong to level 1.

This dense visceral connective tissue complex maintains the vaginal length and horizontal axis. It allows the vagina to be supported by the levator plate and positions the cervix just superior to the level of the ischial spines. Defects in this support complex may lead to apical prolapse.

Level I support suspends the proximal vagina. Level II support attaches the midvagina along its length to the arcus tendineus fascia. Level III support results from the fusion of the distal vagina with adjacent structures. 

Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man met with a road traffic accident. What will be the nature of breathing if his brainstem is transected at the mid-pontine level with bilateral vagus being spared?
questions.solution:
The transection of the brainstem at the mid-pontine level with bilateral vagal sparing causes the continuation of regular breathing.

The respiration is regulated by the pneumotaxic centre and the apneustic centre, which are located in the pons. At mid pontine level lesion, the apneustic centre is intact while the pneumotaxic centre is separated.

questions.text: Choose the correct pedigree chart for autosomal dominant inheritance:
questions.solution:
Among the given pedigrees, 'chart 1' is representative of an autosomal dominant type of inheritance.

In the autosomal dominant chart, we see that at least one parent of the index case is usually affected. It is manifested in the heterozygous state. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, there is a one in two chance of being affected by the disease. 

It is also seen that both males and females are affected by autosomal dominant inheritance patterns. Also, both males and females can transmit the condition.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

 

Option B shows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is seen that the parents of the affected individual are usually not affected and there is a one in four chance of being affected by the trait, among the siblings. 

Option C shows the X-dominant pattern of inheritance. This pattern of inheritance is caused by dominant alleles on the X chromosome. It is seen that an affected female parent transmits the disease to half her sons and half her daughters. An affected male parent with an unaffected female transmits it to all his daughters. None of his sons will be affected.

Option D shows the X-linked recessive pattern. Mutated genes on the X chromosome do not have corresponding alleles on the Y chromosome. Thus, males are hemizygous for X-linked mutant genes, and they express these disorders. A heterozygous female may express the disorder partially or may be a carrier.
