questions.text: A 6-year-old with HIV is brought with complaints of the rash shown below. Where does DNA replication occur in the viruses falling in the same family as the microbe causing this rash?
questions.solution:
The image shows pink, fleshy umbilicated papules suggesting molluscum contagiosum. It is caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus belonging to Poxviridae. DNA replication in these viruses occurs in the host cytoplasm.

Replication of DNA in DNA viruses typically occurs in the host nucleus. However, poxviruses are the exception - replication of DNA occurs in the host cytoplasm. Replication of RNA in RNA viruses typically occurs in the host cytoplasm. However, orthomyxoviruses and retroviruses are the exception - replication of RNA occurs in the host nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in a patient with a Dextrocardia?

choices.text: Inverted P wave in lead I and lead aVL
Negative QRS comples in Lead I
Negative T wave in Lead I
Progressively increasing voltage across precordium in chest leads

questions.solution:
Progressively decreasing (not increasing) voltage across the precordium is seen in dextrocardia. This is because the heart is located on the right side, while the leads are placed on the left. Right-sided lead placement would show a normal progression.

Findings Suggestive of Dextrocardia

  • Inverted P waves in Lead I and aVL
  • Negative QRS complex and T wave in Lead I
    • (Lead I: inversion of all complexes, aka ‘global negativity’ i.e. inverted P wave, negative QRS, inverted T wave)
  • Progressively decreasing voltage across the precordium

 

ECG showing dextrocardia:

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of diarrhea for the past 3 days. On examination, he is tachypneic. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
pH 7.2
pCO2 20 mmHg
HCO3- 7 mEq/L
Cl- 120 mEq/L
Na+ 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. The normal pH is 7.35-7.45. 

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is >12 mEq/L. It occurs in conditions such as methanol poisoning, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, paracetamol poisoning, lactic acidosis, salicylate poisoning, etc. 

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH. 

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought by his mother with growth failure and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations revealed a hemoglobin of  8 g/dL and normal levels of vitamin B12 and B9. His peripheral smear is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing hypersegmented neutrophils with normal vitamin B12 and B9 levels is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare autosomal recessive condition. It occurs due to an error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine resulting in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. It is of two types:

  • Type I - deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase)
  • Type II - deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Children clinically present with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intellectual disability.

Confirmation of the diagnosis requires an assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patient's red blood cells. Anemia responds well to the administration of uridine.

Other options:

Option A: Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. It is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It usually presents as painful monoarthritis that mainly involves the metatarsophalangeal joints of the first toe.

Option B: Severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) occurs due to a deficiency in adenosine deaminase, an enzyme of purine metabolism. This results in the accumulation of adenosine metabolites. This causes premature cell death of B, T and NK cells. Children with SCID present with recurrent oral candidiasis, failure to thrive, diarrhea and interstitial pneumonitis.

Option D: Copper deficiency is usually seen in a condition called Menkes kinky hair syndrome. Children usually present with intellectual disability, hypocupremia, and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: You are an intern and have been assigned the task to calculate the bishop score of a patient. On per vaginal examination, the fetal head is at -2 station and the cervix is 3cm dilated. What score will you record for head-station and cervical dilatation respectively:
questions.solution:
According to Bishop’s score, a score of 1 and 2 will be assigned for the fetal head station and cervical dilation respectively

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: What type of study is shown below?
questions.solution:
The study shown is a prospective cohort study. 

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. It can be divided into:

  • Prospective cohort studies: Outcome has not occurred at the time of the beginning of the investigation 
  • Retrospective cohort studies: Outcome has occurred before the beginning of the investigation 
  • Combination cohort studies: Both retrospective and prospective elements are combined

A cohort is a group of individuals who share a common experience or characteristic within a defined time period. The cohort groups are selected before the appearance of the disease under investigation. They are divided into study and control cohorts. The study cohorts are exposed to a particular factor thought to be related to the disease occurrence whereas the control cohorts are not exposed to this particular factor.  

Studying the effects of exposure to uranium in causing lung cancer is an example of a cohort study. Uranium miners are taken as the study cohort and other individuals who are not exposed to uranium mining are taken as the control cohort. 

Note: In a nested case-control study, cases of disease that have occurred in a defined cohort are identified. A specified number of matched controls who have not developed the disease are then selected from the cohort. 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was treated with a diuretic for heart failure. He now presents with complaints of hearing impairment and dizziness. Which diuretic is likely to be associated with these side effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced hearing loss, and furosemide is likely to be associated with these side effects, causing ototoxicity.

Loop diuretics have the potential to cause damage to the ears, resulting in symptoms such as ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing impairment, dizziness, and a feeling of fullness in the ears. The risk of ototoxicity is highest when loop diuretics are administered rapidly through an intravenous route and lowest when taken orally. To prevent ototoxicity, it is important to avoid infusing furosemide at a rate of more than 4 mg/min.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is used in cases of acute pulmonary oedema, cerebral oedema, hypertension, and hypercalcemia of malignancy.

Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects.

Other options:

Option B: Thiazides act on the DCT. They inhibit Na+-Cl− symporter present in the distal convoluted tubule. It is used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic oedema. Their adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypochloremia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Decrease glucose tolerance
  • May increase the lipid levels

Option C: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide inhibit the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal convoluted tubule. Used to treat glaucoma and mountain sickness and to alkalinize urine. Side effects are acidosis, hypokalaemia, fever, rashes, and paresthesia. Bone marrow depression is rare but a serious side effect. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

Option D: Tolvaptan is an orally active nonpeptide selective V2 receptor antagonist. Its main mechanism of action is to enhance the excretion of free water by the kidneys, which helps restore normal sodium levels in the blood. It is a new addition to the treatment options for hyponatremia caused by congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, or syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). The most common side effects of this medication include increased thirst and a dry sensation in the mouth. Other possible side effects are fever, gastrointestinal disturbances, and elevated blood sugar levels.

questions.text: Maximum penetration is seen with:
questions.solution:
Gamma rays show maximum penetration.

When a nucleus disintegrates, it will emit radiation either as photons (X or gamma rays) or as high-velocity particles. Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation (EMR) similar to X-rays, however, distinguished from the latter by the fact that they are emitted from an excited nucleus. Gamma radiation is highly penetrating and interacts with matter through ionization via two processes, the photoelectric effect, and Compton scattering.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and is heat stable and obtained from bacteria?
questions.solution:
Taq polymerase is used in PCR. It is heat stable and is obtained from the bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus. It lacks a proofreading activity.

DNA synthesis in PCR is catalyzed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase. It is purified from thermophilic bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Thermostable DNA polymerases withstand short incubations at over 90°, temperatures required to completely denature DNA.

The technique of PCR:

Denaturation- sample DNA strands are separated by heating at 95℃ for 15 seconds to 2 minutes.

Annealing- the primers, added in vast excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically 50–75°C). The primers hybridize with their complementary single-stranded DNA.

Extension- each strand is copied by a Taq polymerase, starting at the primer sites in the presence of all four nucleotides (dNTPs) at 72℃.

The image given below shows the steps involved in PCR.


The image given below shows the resources required for PCR:


Other options:

Option A: DNA polymerase III is involved in the replication. This enzyme binds to template DNA to synthesize DNA in the 5' to 3' direction at the replication fork.

Option B: Endonuclease is involved in the replication. The mismatched base during replication is identified and removed by the endonuclease activity.

Option D: DNA gyrase is involved in the replication. It unwinds the DNA and relieves supercoils during replication. They act on the closed circular DNA of bacteria.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is lively, dramatic, and enthusiastic. She is flirtatious and is dressed in accordance with the latest fashion. She is visibly upset when the psychiatrist had to leave in between to attend an emergency case. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of histrionic personality disorder.

It is classified under cluster B. It is characterized by an excitable, overly emotional, dramatic person with exaggerated behavior, who uses physical appearance to draw attention to themselves i.e., sexually seductive.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

questions.text: The bodies shown in this image (highlighted) are seen in which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows Call exner bodies which are seen in Granulosa cell tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene is seen in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumors.

Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumors. It is used in monitoring patients being treated.

Other options -

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumor cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes. The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa. 

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Krukenberg tumor.

Option D : A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with an unclear medical history presented with swelling around the left ankle joint and a left foot ulcer. He complains of instability of movement which is associated with minimal or no pain. Interestingly, the examination reveals, movements beyond normal limits and a loose bag of bones feel. X-Ray reveals obvious bone destruction and the presence of irregular calcified masses. The most probable cause of the underlying joint pathology in this patient is ______________
questions.solution:
The clinical picture indicates a neuropathic cause like Charcot arthropathy, which is most commonly caused by diabetes.

Points in favor of a diagnosis of Charcot arthropathy:

  • Swelling of ankle joint being associated with foot ulcer (?diabetic foot ulcer)
  • Instability of movement
  • Movements beyond normal limits and a loose bag of bones feel
  • X-ray that shows obvious bone destruction and the presence of irregular calcified masses

Diabetes is the most common cause of Charcot arthropathy, while tertiary syphilis was one of the common causes previously. Charcot's arthropathy can also be caused by the following: 

  • leprosy
  • dialysis
  • chronic alcoholism
  • spinal cord injury
  • syringomyelia
  • meningomyelocele

questions.text: Which among the following drugs can cause the fetal condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The above USG shows a fetus with spina bifida. Sodium valproate is associated with specific malformation of spina bifida. Pregnant women taking sodium valproate have a 1-2% risk of delivering a baby with spina bifida.

Other options:

  • Phenytoin is usually associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome, characterised by CNS anomalies, Intrauterine Growth restriction, cardiac abnormalities, cleft lip, Phalyngeal hypoplasia. Thus, the best option is sodium valproate.
  • Levetiracetam and lamotrigine are relatively safe in pregnancy and do not seem to cause neural tube defects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissue and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. 

The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee) takes place. 

Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine, amlodipine is used and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used. 

Other options:

Options A and C- Anti-ds DNA antibodies and  Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE.

Option D- Anti-SRP antibodies are characteristically seen in necrotizing myopathies.

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

questions.text: A man who sustained a crush injury during an earthquake was rescued. His blood pressure was stable and no internal bleeding was detected. A significant reduction in his urine output was noted after some time. Investigations showed urine/plasma creatinine ratio < 20 and urinary sodium of 50 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI). The history of crush injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis leading to AKI.

AKI is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:

  • Prerenal azotemia 
  • Intrinsic parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction

Intrinsic causes can further be divided into acute tubular necrosis, acute glomerulonephritis, and acute interstitial nephritis. Ischemia and nephrotoxins are the main causes of acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxins can be exogeneous such as vancomycin, cisplatin, and iodinated contrast agents used for CT imaging. Endogenous toxins include myoglobin, uric acid, and hemoglobin. Crush injuries, heat stroke, and myopathies can result in rhabdomyolysis releasing large amounts of myoglobin. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is usually ≤ 40.

In acute tubular necrosis, urinary sodium is >20 mEq/L. 

Prerenal azotemia arises due to a reduced renal plasma flow. Common causes include hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is ≥ 40 and urinary sodium is usually <20mEq/L.

Bladder outlet obstruction, urethral obstruction, and benign prostatic hyperplasia lead to postrenal azotemia. Urinary sodium can be variable.

More causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: A person is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was placed in a surgical position as shown in the image below. Identify the position.
questions.solution:
The above image shows the reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15-30 degrees higher than the feet.  

It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level. In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly turned to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

The below image shows the various surgical positions and the procedure they are used in:

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsion is suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.solution:
In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side. After the de-torsion, the adequacy of the blood flow has to be assessed by Doppler.

In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis. The patient usually presents with acute onset pain and swelling of the scrotum. On examination, the cremasteric reflex is lost, and the scrotum looks asymmetrical. 

Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion. Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis, and it is seen in epididymo-orchitis.

At the time of surgical exploration, contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed to the dartos fascia in order to prevent possible torsion occurring in this testes.

More than 80% of the testis can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis is found to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexy of the contralateral testis is done.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia, with a leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The flow cytometry of cells is as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given pattern is suggestive of B-CLL.

Interpreting flow cytometry graph:

See the markers on X-axis and Y-axis. Divide the graph into 4 quadrants.

1)In the first graph, X-axis shows CD5 and Y-axis shows CD19. The particular cell population in question is positive for CD19 and CD5.

2)In the second graph, it is shown the cells are negative for CD10 and positive for CD19.

3)The third graph shows CD 23 is positive. CD20 is dimly expressed.

4)FMC-7 is negative. CD20 is dimly expressed.

 

It is understood from the cytometry analysis that the cells are positive for CD5, CD19, CD23, CD20.  All these suggest the diagnosis of B-CLL.

 

 

Other options:

  • Mantle cell lymphoma can be diagnosed by its characteristic immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, CD22+, CD23(-), CD 5+.
  • DLBCL and Follicular lymphoma are positive for CD10.

Comparison between Mantle Cell Lymphoma and Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL):

  Mantle cell lymphoma CLL/SLL
CD5 Positive Positive
CD23 Negative Positive
Cyclin D1 Positive Negative
FMC7 Positive Negative
CD10, BCL6 Negative Negative

Related Pearl: Origin of leukemia / lymphoma and their immunophenotypes

B cell precursors Derived lymphomas/leukemia Immunophenotype

questions.text: “Pie in the sky” field defects are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The term "pie in the sky" defects refers to superior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the inferior fibres of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer’s loop) are involved.

"Pie in the floor" defects

  • Refer to inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of the superior fibres of optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop)

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient came with complaints of a sudden decreased vision in both eyes and pain while moving his eyeballs. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart.  Fundus examination showed normal discs and vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis. The normal optic disc is an important pointer toward retrobulbar neuritis.

Optic neuritis is of three types, based on the appearance of optic disc on fundoscopy:

  • Retrobulbar neuritis - Normal optic disc because optic nerve head is not involved.
  • Papillitis - Hyperemic and edematous disc with peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhages.
  • Neuroretinitis - Macular star appearance due to involvement of nerve fiber layer (NFL)

The clinical features of retrobulbar neuritis include sudden painful vision loss, decreased color contrast sensitivity, Marcus Gunn pupil and pain on movement of eyeballs.

Demyelinating disorders like multiple sclerosis are the most common cause of retrobulbar neuritis.

Steroids are the mainstay of treatment for such demyelinating causes.

Option A: Eale's disease is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. Due to this, the fundoscopic findings will not be normal. It is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to tubercular proteins. This causes periphlebitis leading to hemorrhages.

Option B: Papilloedema is swelling of the optic nerve head due to raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Here also the optic disc would not be normal. The patient will have symptoms of raised ICP such as headache, nausea, deterioration of consciousness, etc.

Option D: Papillitis will have an abnormal optic disc as described above.

questions.text: The given image shows the strength of muscle contraction with successive stimulation. What is the cause of the phenomenon shown?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon and occurs because of increased intracellular calcium.

When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, the strength of muscle contraction during each twitch increases successively with each stimulus. After this, the strength of contraction in each twitch reaches a plateau. This phenomenon is called the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon. It is caused primarily by the increasing calcium ions in the cytosol. Each successive muscle contraction causes more and more calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and these ions cannot be recaptured back immediately.

As the frequency of contractions further increases, a new contraction begins to occur before the previous one is over. Thus, the second contraction is added to the first one and the strength of the contraction increases. As this phenomenon progresses, the frequency reaches a critical level and the contractions become so rapid that they fuse together into a smooth and continuous contraction. This phenomenon is known as frequency summation and tetanization (options B and C).

 

Length-tension relationship (option A) refers to the relationship between the length of the muscle fiber and the active tension that it develops. As the length of the muscle is increased, there is an increase in the active tension which develops in a muscle due to more overlapping between the actin filaments and the myosin cross-bridges. However, this increase in tension only occurs till a limit. The optimum length at which the maximum tension develops is 2.0 to 2.2 μm of length.

questions.text: On clinical examination, you find sensory loss in the region indicated. You would expect a deficit in:

choices.text: No associated motor weakness will be present

questions.solution:
The image shows Regimental Badge Sign. It is seen in Axillary nerve injuries. Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid which is responsible for abduction 15-90 degrees.

Other options:

  • Initiation of Abduction is not affected as it is caused by supraspinatus.
  • Overhead abduction is the function of serratus anterior and trapezius muscles and hence is not affected.
  • The posterior branch of axillary nerve supplies, teres minor and posterior of deltoid and terminates as the cutaneous nerve of armwhich supplies the skin over the lower half of deltoid. Deltoid muscle palsy can lead to loss of rounded contour of shoulder and palsy of lateral cutaneous nerve of arm are other significant features.

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of the prick. Histology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genus Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Points in favor:

  • Sub-Himalayan belt farmer with thorn prick injury
  • Verrucous growth
  • Histology showing "Medlar bodies"(sclerotic bodies)

 

  Chromoblastomycosis Sporotrichosis
Cause Pigmented fungi-Phialophora and Fonsecaea species Dimorphic fungi-Sporothrix schenckii
Presentation Warty, cauliflower-like growth at the site of the prick A linear chain of ulcerating nodules and sinuses along the lymphatics
Histology Medlar bodies/sclerotic bodies Asteroid bodies

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form, which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of foot

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother because she has not started menstruating. Her mother and older sister started menstruating at the age of 16 yrs. She is a healthy girl and lies along the 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. She has scant axillary and pubic hair and breasts are Tanner stage 3. Pelvic examination is normal and she says she is not sexually active. She has an old sonographic report of abdomen and pelvis that was normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
All women with amenorrhoea,whether primary or secondary, should undergo beta-HCG testing to rule out pregnancy. Only after this, other investigations, if needed, should be done.

Note: All reproductive-aged women with amenorrhea are assumed pregnant until proven otherwise. Thus, a urinary or serum β -hCG level is always obtained

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations?
questions.solution:
500-600 ml of transient loss/insensible loss per day would have to be accounted for in the calculation.

Although water is lost through sweating especially in hot climates or during physical exertion, we tend to lose water at rest as well. Physiologically, water evaporates from the skin and lungs at a rate of about 600 to 700 ml/day. This is known as insensible water loss.

questions.text: A minor surgery was planned for a 60 year-old-man. His preoperative serological tests showed Anti-HBsAg positive. All other serological markers were negative. What is the probable treatment required?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, anti-HBsAg alone is positive, which is seen in immunized individuals. The patient does not require any treatment.

The presence of anti-HBs can imply recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection, as well as successful vaccination against hepatitis B. In a patient who is fully immunized against hepatitis B:

  • Anti-HBs- positive
  • HBsAg- negative
  • Anti-HBc- negative

Antiviral drugs such as tenofovir and entecavir can be initiated when there is HBsAg positivity with evidence of cirrhosis, abnormal ALT (Alanine transaminase), and HBV DNA titer >20,000 IU/mL.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest field defect observed in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
A relative paracentral scotoma is the earliest clinically significant field defect observed in glaucoma.

The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and, and finally the nasal fibers. Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma. 

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A 40 yr old lady presents with large left parietal convexity meningioma with perilesional edema. She is scheduled for surgery the next day .A senior neurosurgeon asks a house surgeon to write the pre operative  notes for the lady. Which of the following pre op note is wrong?
questions.solution:
Perilesional oedema or vasogenic oedema responds to steroids thus lowering intracranial pressure. Therefore steroids are to be continued and morning dose has to be taken.

Related Pearl: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

  1. Antihypertensive medications (Exceptions are ACE Inhibitors and ARB) 
  2. Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  3. Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  4. Thyroid medications
  5. Eye drops
  6. Heartburn or reflux medications
  7. Narcotic medications
  8. Anticonvulsants
  9. Asthma medications
  10. Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  11. Statins
  12. Levodopa
  13. Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome. 
 

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman with a background of moderate aortic stenosis presents with a 2-week history of fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. She gives a history of nausea and altered bowel habits. Blood tests reveal a Hb level of 9.9 g/dL, white cell count of 16.0 × 10^9 /L and CRP level of 187 mg/L. Blood cultures were taken on admission and she was started on empirical antibiotics. TTE demonstrated aortic valve vegetations. Blood cultures revealed Streptococcus gallolyticus. What other investigations must be done considering the culture results?
questions.solution:
Colonoscopy must be done in this patient.

Streptococcus gallolyticus originates from the gastrointestinal tract, where it is associated with polyps and colonic tumors. In such a case prompt gastrointestinal investigations are needed.

Related Pearl: Source of microorganisms causing infective endocarditis

Microorganism

Source

Streptococcus viridans

Oral cavity

Staphylococcus aureus

Skin

HACEK organisms

Upper respiratory tract

Streptococcus gallolyticus

GIT (Colon )

Enterococci

Genitourinary tract

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The following image shows the Swirl sign. It is an area of low attenuation within an extraaxial hyperattenuating fluid collection.

The term "swirl sign" describes the appearance on a non-contrast CT scan when fresh blood leaks into a hematoma, such as in intracerebral, extradural, or subdural hematomas. This indicates the presence of unclotted blood, which appears lighter than the surrounding clotted blood.
 

Other options:

  • Mount Fuji sign - This sign is present in case of pneumocephalus. Gas is present between the tips of the frontal lobes with heaped up appearance giving the silhouette-like appearance.
  • Ice cream cone sign-it represents the normal appearance of malleus and incus on an HRCT.
  • Accordion sign/concertina sign is a non-specific sign related to a thickened edematous large bowel wall usually seen in CT abdomen of patients with infectious colitis.

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below:
questions.solution:
The egg in the given picture is that of a hookworm. Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

The eggs of hookworm are :

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless
  • Not bile stained
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell.
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the hospital following RTA.  Chest X-ray reveals fracture as shown by the arrow. The long bone fractured in the X-Ray is of which of the following types?
questions.solution:
Given X-Ray shows the fracture of clavicle. Clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity.

Long bones are classified as follows:

  • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. E.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.
  • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. E.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
  • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or ends, and no medullary cavity. E.g., clavicle.

questions.text: Shown below is a skin lesion. Which of the following is not a criterion to assess its malignant potential?
questions.solution:
The image shown above depicts a nevus. Diameter >6 mm is the diagnostic clue for the transformation of a nevus to a melanoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: Which of the following is the first line drug of choice in a patient with myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Pyridostigmine is the first-line drug of choice in the treatment of symptomatic myasthenia gravis.

Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine.
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment.
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding donor twin, in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS )?
questions.solution:
Donor twin is anemic in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a type of fetal syndrome that can arise when monozygotic twinning results in two amnionic sacs and a common surrounding chorion.

This leads to anatomical sharing of the two fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. It depends on the degree to which they are hemodynamically balanced. In those with significant pressure or flow gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic fetofetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

In this syndrome, blood is transfused from a donor twin to its recipient sibling such that the donor may eventually become anemic and its growth may be restricted. In contrast, the recipient becomes polycythemic and may develop circulatory overload manifest as hydrops.

Other features:

Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics
Oliguria Polyuria
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Hypotension Hypertension
Anemia Polycythemia
Renal failure Congestive cardiac failure
Growth restriction Premature rupture of membranes
Pulmonary hypoplasia Hyperbilirubinemia
Contractures  

Note: The donor twin is also known as the pump twin / stuck twin.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her right hand. Her daily routine involves taking care of her 2 kids. Of late, she feels excruciating pain in certain movements of her hand. On examination, the Finkelstein test is positive. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved in this condition?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the positive Finkelstein's test is suggestive of De Quervain's disease. The structures likely to be involved in this condition are extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test- the examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons. 

The image below shows Finkelstein's test. 


Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.text: A medical student while examining a patient during his skin postings identifies a flat, circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion of >1 cm size that differs in color from the surrounding skin. The lesion described in the above patient  is a ________________
questions.solution:
A Patch is a flat, circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion of >1 cm that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape.

  • A macule is a lesion of a similar description but of size <1 cm.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: Which of the following region of mRNA offers protection from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity?
questions.solution:
The poly(A) tail protects the 3′ end of mRNA from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease attack and facilitates translation.

Eukaryotic messenger RNA usually undergoes post-transcriptional modification and polyadenylation is an important part of this post-transcriptional modification. They help to stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened.  Eukaryotic mRNAs have poly-A tails at 3' end and 7-methylguanosine caps at 5' end.

Other options:

Option A: The attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the guanyl cap at the 5' end. It also prevents the attack of 5′→ 3′ exonucleases

Option B: TATA box is the site of pre-initiation complex formation, which is the first step in transcription initiation.

Option D: Shine-Dalgarno sequence initiates translation in prokaryotes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. The size of the uterus corresponds to the period of amenorrhea. On examination, the external os is closed. USG shows a well-formed gestational sac with fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of threatened abortion.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows a well-formed gestation ring indicating a healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Treatment involves bed rest, analgesics to relieve pain, and progesterone.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

Clinical type Description/ Clinical picture USG/ Investigations
Threatened 

Bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding

Closed cervical os

Gestational sac/ pseudo-gestational sac present

Fetal cardiac activity present
Inevitable 

Gush of vaginal fluid or bleeding

Cramping or fever

Dilated cervical os

Gross rupture of membranes

Low lying sac

Oligohydramnios
Incomplete 

Vaginal bleeding

Partial or complete placental separation

Dilated cervical os

Retained products of conception
Complete

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions distributed along the lines of Blaschko. Which of the following conditions is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
Incontinentia pigmenti has a Blaschkoid distribution.

 

The lesions can be described in 4 distinct stages, which are

  • Stage 1 - Erythematous vesicular rash
  • Stage 2 - Verrucous lesions
  • Stage 3 - Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls
  • Stage 4 - Hypopigmented Patches

 

Other options:

  • Option a. Herpes zoster (Dermatomal)
  • Option c: Hailey–Hailey disease is intertriginous in distribution.
  • Option d: Sporotrichosis (Lymphangitic) distribution of lesions

 

Distribution pattern Description Examples
Dermatomal/zosteriform  Unilateral and in the distribution of a single spinal afferent nerve root Herpes zoster  
Blaschkoid Following lines of skin cell migration during embryogenesis  Incontinentia pigmenti
Lymphangitic Distribution of a lymph vessel  Cellulitis, Sporotrichosis, Swimming pool granuloma 
Sun-exposed  Areas not covered by clothing (face, dorsal hands, V area of neck) Photodermatitis, subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus,
Sun protected  Areas covered by clothing Parapsoriasis, mycosis fungoides
Acral: Occurring in    Distal locations (hands, feet, wrists, and ankles)  Palmoplantar pustulosis, chilblains
Extensor   Dorsal extremities, overlying the extensor muscles, knees, or elbows  Psoriasis, Dermatitis herpetiformis
Flexor:   Flexor muscles of the extremities, the antecubital and popliteal fossae Atopic dermatitis (Childhood and adult phase) 
Intertriginous  Skin folds, where two skin surfaces are in contact (Eg: axilla, inguinal folds, inner thighs, inframammary skin)

Candidiasis, Hailey Hailey disease

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OHA intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Other options:

Option A - Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Option C - Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option D - Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man working in a factory for the past 30 years, presents with dyspnea and cough due to chronic exposure to a particular mineral agent. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows characteristic golden brown bodies with beaded and knobbed ends. All of the following are caused by exposure to this agent, except  ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing golden-brown asbestos bodies with knobbed or beaded ends is due to asbestos exposure. All of the given conditions are caused by exposure to asbestos except anthracosis. Anthracosis is a coal-induced pulmonary lesion.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung that occurs due to asbestos exposure. The disease usually manifests after a minimum of 10 years of exposure. Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Recurrent pleural effusions
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis 
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

Clinically, dyspnea and cough are seen. They can progress to respiratory failure, cor pulmonale, and even death. Chest radiograph can show irregular linear densities in lower lobes and in late stages can show a honey-combed pattern.

Histopathology shows diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and asbestos bodies. These appear as golden brown fusiform or rod-shaped beaded structures with a translucent center that is made of asbestos fibers coated by a proteinaceous material. They arise when asbestos gets phagocytosed by macrophages. Iron-protein complexes may coat other inorganic particulate matter to form ferruginous bodies.

The below image shows asbestos bodies.

 

Anthracosis is commonly seen in coal miners, urban dwellers, and tobacco smokers. It is caused by chronic exposure to coal dust. Wheeze is a typical finding seen in anthracosis. They can present with cough and, dyspnoea as well. Black carbon deposits in the lungs may be visible grossly as well as microscopically.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with angina. Coronary angiography revealed a block in the right coronary artery. Blood supply through which of the following arteries would not be affected?
questions.solution:
The circumflex artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right coronary artery. Hence, blood supply through the circumflex artery won't be affected.

The branches of the right coronary artery are:

  • Right conal artery - first branch of the right coronary artery
  • Artery of the SA node 
  • Acute right marginal artery 
  • Posterior interventricular artery (in 65% population)
  • Atrial and anterior and posterior ventricular branches

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient with increased blood pressure has come to the outpatient department. He asks about lifestyle modifications and a DASH diet was suggested. How much does the systolic blood pressure drop by adopting the DASH diet?

DASH: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension
questions.solution:
The systolic blood pressure drops by 8-14 mmHg by adopting the DASH diet.

DASH is a diet plan which involves consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced fat content. 

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension and the reduction in blood pressure are shown below.

Modification Impact on SBP
Weight reduction to maintain a normal body mass index 5–20 mmHg per 10kg weight loss
DASH diet 8–14 mmHg
Sodium intake reduction (< 6 grams of sodium chloride) 2–8 mmHg
Physical activity: 30 minutes of a brisk walk per day  4–9 mmHg

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Hypertension is a preventable disease. There are two approaches:

  • Primary prevention - includes measures that are taken to reduce the incidence by reducing the risk of onset. Population strategies are dietary modification, weight reduction, and exercise. A high-risk strategy prevents the shooting of blood pressure which might need institutional treatment.
  • Secondary prevention - includes the detection and usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. 

Related Pearl: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with increased hand and foot size, and the facial features depicted in the image. Insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-1) levels are elevated. Which of the following confirms your diagnosis?

GH - Growth Hormone

choices.text: Suppressed growth hormone after oral glucose load
Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load

questions.solution:
The clinical image of a man with mandibular enlargement, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), and jaw malocclusion with elevated IGF-1 suggests the diagnosis of acromegaly. Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load confirms the diagnosis.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

75g of oral glucose load is administered to the patient. The growth hormone levels are measured within 1-2 hours after administration. Normally, GH should be suppressed to less than 0.4 ug/L after the oral glucose load. A failure of suppression of growth hormone confirms the diagnosis of acromegaly. In some patients, growth hormone levels may demonstrate a paradoxical rise. 

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analog), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists or radiation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Elevated random growth hormone levels would not help in diagnosis as GH is secreted in a pulsatile fashion. In addition, the GH level does not correlate with severity. 

Option B - Suppressed growth hormone after an oral glucose load is seen in patients without acromegaly. 

Option D - Elevated random prolactin levels are seen in 25% of patients with acromegaly but is not used to confirm the diagnosis. 

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A patient is set to undergo surgery.  His past medical records reveal that he is homozygotic for the atypical pseudocholinesterase. Which of the following would you expect to encounter in this patient on administering succinylcholine?

choices.text: A rapid onset of action and a short duration of action
Delayed onset and a short duration of action

questions.solution:
A prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine would be expected in a patient with atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme.

Succinylcholine is rapidly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase as soon as it enters the circulation. This results in the short duration of action of succinylcholine, which is usually less than 10 minutes. 

Abnormal pseudocholinesterase, resulting from homozygous or heterozygous gene defect, cannot metabolize succinylcholine efficiently, leading to a prolonged duration of action. In patients heterozygous for the atypical pseudocholinesterase, the duration of action is prolonged modestly (2–20 minutes) whereas in homozygotes it may be prolonged up to 4–8 hours. The incidence of atypical pseudocholinesterase genes is more common in those with European ancestry.

The rapid onset of action of succinylcholine is because of its small volume of distribution resulting from very low lipid solubility. The onset is not affected by the atypical pseudocholinesterase.
