questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with breathing difficulty, poor feeding, and constipation. Upon examination, the physician notes a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. The mother gives a recent history of feeding honey. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: This condition is caused by an exotoxin
The toxin type G is associated with sudden death
Detection of antitoxin can aid in diagnosis
The toxin causes spastic paralysis by blocking the release of Acetylcholine

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of infant botulism. Statement 4 is the false statement since the toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine.

Botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, and is of three types:

  • Foodborne botulism
  • Infant botulism
  • Wound botulism

Infant botulism (also called floppy baby syndrome): It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months; It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxin. The characteristic clinical history is paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weak, altered cry, and loss of head control. Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxin or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

Other options:

  • Clostridium botulinum produces a powerful exotoxin that is responsible for its pathogenicity.
  • The toxin type G is associated with sudden death.
  • A retrospective diagnosis can be made by detection of antitoxin in the serum but it may not be seen in all cases.

Gram staining of clostridium botulinum:

questions.text: With respect to congenital heart diseases and chest x-rays, which of the following pairs is correct?

choices.text: Transposition of great arteries - egg on side appearance
Tetralogy of Fallot - box shaped heart
Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation - gooseneck sign

questions.solution:
The correct pair is TGA - Egg on side or egg on string appearance.

In the transposition of great arteries, the heart appears globular (like an egg) due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the appearance of an egg-on-a-string.

questions.text: The micrograph of a section of a diseased liver, stained with Masson’s Trichrome stain,  is given below.  The arrow points to:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the above micrograph of the diseased liver points to areas of fibrosis containing collagen that is stained blue by Masson’s trichrome stain. 

The liver has a prominent (centrilobular) macrovesicular steatosis (white/clear round/oval spaces) and mild fibrosis (blue). The hepatocytes are stained red.

The differential diagnoses of centrilobular macrovesicular hepatic steatosis are:

  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Alcohol

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower gastrointestinal bleed. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid colon. The histopathological image of the biopsy from the ulcer is given below.  Which of the following is the infective form of this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica.

In amebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

The following are the characteristic features of the various life stages of E. histolytica.

Trophozoite:

  • It is found only in tissues.
  • Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance.
  • The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called the linin network, thus giving a cartwheel appearance.
  • Pseudopodia are present, which exhibit gliding motility.

The image given below shows the trophozoite form of E. histolytica.

Precystic stage:

  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars.
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst.

Cystic stage:

  • The mature cyst has 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.
  • Chromatid bars disappear.

The image given below shows the cyst form of E. histolytica.

Treatment involves three classes of drugs: 

  • Luminal amebicides like diloxanide furoate, paromomycin which act in the lumen
  • Tissue amebicides like emetine and chloroquine
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides like metronidazole and tinidazole.

The following image shows the life cycle and complications of E. histolytica.

questions.text: You are a physician working in the paediatric emergency department. This is the arterial blood gas (ABG) of patient X: pH = 7.5, pCO2 = 25 mm Hg, bicarbonate = 24 mEq/L. Which of the following patients does this ABG belong to?

choices.text: A 3 yr old boy with severe vomiting with blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg
A 4 yr old girl with breathlessness and respiratory rate of 50 breaths/min
A 5 yr old girl with opioid overdose and respiratory rate of 6 breaths/min
A 6 yr old boy with fatigue and drowsiness and blood glucose of 600 mg/dL

questions.solution:
The ABG shows increased pH with low pCO2 (Respiratory alkalosis due to CO2 washout). Such a picture will be seen in a child with severe tachypnoea.

Other Options:

Option A: In this case, there will be metabolic alkalosis: High pH, high bicarbonate, high pCO2. Note: The blood pressure in this case is normal for a 3 yr old child.

Option C: In this case, there will be CO2 retention and respiratory acidosis: Low pH, high CO2

Option D: In this case, there will be metabolic acidosis: Low pH, low bicarbonate, low pCO2

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A pap smear was done on a 39-year-old woman as a part of a routine health checkup. The cytology picture is shown below. The cell marked A in the smear is _______.
questions.solution:
The cell marked A in the smear is a superficial cell which is an estrogen-dominant cell. These are acidophilic (pink) cells with a pyknotic nucleus seen predominantly in the first half of the menstrual cycle.

  • Intermediate cells: Progesterone dominant cells which are basophilic (blue or green) with distinct margins and nuclei bigger than that of superficial cells. These are seen in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.
  • Basal and parabasal cells are seen when no hormone predominates. These are basophilic cells with no distinct outlines and a much larger nucleus. Seen in menopause and the postpartum period.
  • Human papilloma infected cells: Shows koilocytes. These cells have hyperchromatic enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halo.

The cytology image of a normal Pap smear is shown below.

The koilocytes(right side) compared to normal Pap smear(left side).

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a previous history of preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with intermittent uterine contractions. To allow for fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow for fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage(IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC). 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Related Pearl: Tocolytic agents

Drugs Examples
Calcium channel blockers
Nifedipine
Nicardipine
Verapamil
Competitive inhibition to calcium ion
 Magnesium sulfate
Cyclo-oxygenase inhibitors
Indomethacin
Sulindac
Beta mimetics
Terbutaline
Ritodrine
Isoxsuprine
Oxytocin Antagonists
Atosiban
Nitric oxide (NO) Donors

questions.text: A patient with a complex psychiatric history is on a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. She visits her primary care physician with increasing depression. The physician adds a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Which of the following is she most likely to develop?

choices.text: Fever, rigidity, dilated pupils, and hyperreflexia
Fever, dystonia, rigidity and normal pupils
Fever, normotonia, dilated pupils and normal reflexes
Fever, rigidity, normal pupils and reduced bowel sounds

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of fever, rigidity, hyperreflexia, and dilated pupils are seen in the patient who is on a MAO inhibitor +  SSRI. It is due to the development of serotonin syndrome.

Serotonin syndrome occurs due to the concurrent administration of an SSRI with an MAO-inhibitor, L-tryptophan, or lithium, raising plasma serotonin concentrations to toxic levels. This serious and possibly fatal syndrome with the symptoms 

  • diarrhea, diaphoresis, flushing, mydriasis, salivation
  • restlessness
  • extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, and rapid fluctuations in vitals
  • myoclonus, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity; and eventually
  • delirium, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

Serotonin syndrome

Malignant hyperthermia

Co-prescription of MAO-I and SSRIs leading to increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels

hypermetabolic response causing an increased intracellular calcium level

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of blindness in India?
questions.solution: According to the National Survey on Blindness (2015-2019), cataract is the most common cause of blindness in India accounting for 66.2% of the total cases.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with microscopy showing ragged red fibres is suggestive of MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke).

It is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to complex I or complex IV deficiency. Patients have normal development previously and then present with symptoms of lactic acidosis and stroke (seizures with focal neurological deficits).

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead) as shown below.

Other mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • Leigh’s disease
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
  • Kearns–Sayre syndrome
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia
  • Pearson syndrome

questions.text: A 14-year-old professional sports player presents with complaints of pain in the upper limb on lifting weights. During the clinical examination of this patient,  you ask to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Now, wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle. Which of the following conditions should you suspect?
questions.solution:
The Cozen's test has been performed and produces pain over the lateral epicondyle which is positive in tennis elbow - lateral epicondylitis.

Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) is tendinopathy characterized by pain arising from the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) at the lateral epicondyle. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at the origin during activities that involve repeated forceful wrist extension and supination (Eg: backhand in tennis and use of a screwdriver). 

Patients present with outer elbow pain, radiating down the forearm and along with morning stiffness of the elbow. The pain is often aggravated by lifting objects and shaking hands. The elbow may appear normal or have slight swelling, with a full range of movement.

Tenderness is present over the lateral epicondyle. Clinical tests for tennis elbow are:

  • Cozen's test: Resisted extension of the wrist with the elbow in full extension elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley’s test: extension of the middle finger against resistance elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mill's sign: Extension of the elbow in pronation with a flexed wrist elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: Which of the following part of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), marked as "1" in the above image of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption.

The structures marked in the image are as follows:

  1. PCT
  2. Distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
  3. Loop of Henle
  4. Collecting duct

PCT reabsorbs about 67% of the filtered water. Isosmotic reabsorption occurs in the PCT i.e. the amount of solute and water reabsorbed are coupled and are proportional to each other. Here the solute that is reabsorbed along with the water is Na+. So 67% of both flitered Na+ and water are reabosrbed in the PCT. 

These large amounts of Na+ and water reabsorption is essential in maintaining the ECF volume. 

In addition to the isosmotic reabsorption, the water reabsorption in the PCT also occurs through the active water channels known as aquaporin-1. 

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

Related Pearl: Summary of Transport Across Proximal and Distal Portions of the Nephron

Proximal Tubule
Reabsorption

Secretion 

67% of filtered Na+ actively reabsorbed, not subject to control; Cl– follows passively

All filtered glucose and amino acids reabsorbed by secondary active transport; not subject to control

Variable amounts of filtered PO43- and other electrolytes reabsorbed; subject to control

65% of filtered H2O osmotically reabsorbed; not subject to control

50% of filtered urea passively reabsorbed; not subject to control

Almost all filtered K+ reabsorbed; not subject to control

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Organic ion secretion; not subject to control
Distal tubule
Reabsorption Secretion

Variable Na+ reabsorption, controlled by aldosterone; Cl– follows passively

Variable H2O reabsorption, controlled by vasopressin

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Variable K+ secretion, controlled by aldosterone

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with neurofibromatosis 1 (NF 1) brings her 9-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. She wants to know if the girl has NF 1. The presence of which of the following features would confirm NF 1 in the daughter?

choices.text: One iris hamartoma in the left eye

questions.solution:
The presence of one plexiform neurofibroma would confirm NF 1 in the daughter.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or von Recklinghausen's disease is an autosomal disease. NF1 is the most common of all neurofibromatosis. It is caused by a loss of function mutation, on the neurofibromin (NF1) gene. 

To diagnose neurofibromatosis 1, two or more of the following clinical manifestations should be present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules: > 5 mm in diameter in prepubertal and > 15 mm in diameter in postpubertal individuals
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris)
  • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

The FDA has recently approved a new drug selumetinib, mitogen-activated protein kinase 1 & 2 inhibitors for the treatment of NF1 in pediatric patients who are 2 years or older with symptomatic, inoperable plexiform neurofibromatosis. It can help reduce tumor progression. 

Related Pearl: Chromosomal abnormalities and syndromes associated with brain tumors

Syndrome Gene defect Tumor
Neurofibromatosis type 1 Neurofibromin (chr 17q)

Neurofibromas,

malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, optic nerve gliomas,

hamartomatous lesions, pheochromocytomas.

 
Neurofibromatosis type 2 Schwannomin (chr 22q)

Bilateral eighth nerve schwannomas, multiple meningiomas,

ependymomas of the spinal cord

 
Cowden's disease PTEN (chr 10)

meningioma, astrocytoma

Hemangioblastomas, Retinal angiomas

Gliomas, medulloblastomas

questions.text: A 4-week old infant presented to ER with projectile vomiting. Ultrasonography was done which showed Cervix sign and Nipple sign. Probable diagnosis is ______________
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis since cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis on USG.

  • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called Nipple sign.
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

questions.text: A 45-year-old, non diabetic and normotensive man comes with complaints of pain over the heel that is most severe while taking the first step in the morning and aggravated on dorsiflexion. The appropriate diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The above given complaints are suggestive of plantar fasciitis.

The pain is often worse when first getting up in the morning, with typical hobbling downstairs, or when first getting up from a period of sitting – the typical start-up pain and stiffness.

In Achilles tendonitis pain is increased with activity.

In calcaneal stress fractures there may be a history of unaccustomed and repetitive activity or one of a strenuous physical exercise programme. A common sequence of events is: pain after exercise – pain during exercise – pain without exercise.

In tarsal tunnel syndrome, there is pain and sensory disturbance in the medial part of the forefoot, unrelated to weight bearing, may be due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. The pain is often worse at night and the patient may seek relief by walking around or stamping the foot.

questions.text: An infant had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.solution:
Cotrimoxazole is a combination drug consisting of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, of which sulfamethoxazole is a sulfonamide. Sulphonamides displace bilirubin from plasma albumin, leading to elevation of serum bilirubin levels.

These drugs can cross the placenta and are secreted in milk and can therefore cause kernicterus in newborn infants if they are given to pregnant women near term or during lactation.

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of severe insomnia. She has been feeling ants walking over the skin of her legs, and an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep. The drug of choice for treating this condition would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with insomnia feeling ants walking over her skin along with an irresistible urge to move her legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep is indicative of restless leg syndrome and gabapentin is the first-line choice of treatment for this condition.    

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. Moving the leg or walking alleviates the symptoms. This cycle sometimes continues for hours during the night and can result in profound insomnia. Decreased dopamine receptor expression and mild dopaminergic hypofunction are usually noted in these patients.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

questions.text: A primigravida underwent a quadruple screening test at 16 weeks of gestation. All the parameters were low except for serum inhibin A level which was normal. Identify the condition in which the findings given above are seen.
questions.solution:
All the parameters like maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta HCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced in trisomy 18/Edwards syndrome. Maternal serum inhibin A level may be normal or reduced.

Quadruple testing is usually done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. This test can additionally help in picking up Smith-Lemli-Optiz syndrome. However, one of the limitations of the test is that it fails to detect trisomy 13. 

In trisomy 21 and neural tube defects, the changes in the screening markers are as follows:

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG  Beta HCG  Beta HCG 
PAPP-A  Unconjugated estriol  Unconjugated estriol 
This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG MSAFP  MSAFP 
  Serum inhibin A

questions.text: A resident while assisting a case of laparoscopic hernia repair observes the surgeon dissect certain anatomical landmarks to expose the triangle of doom. Which of the following does not form a boundary of this triangle?
questions.solution:
Cooper’s ligament does not form the boundary of the triangle of doom.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: A person with a gunshot wound of size 3 cm presents with a comminuted fracture of the tibia. On examination, the distal pulse could not be felt. Which grade does this belong to according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification?
questions.solution:
The above-described wound belongs to grade IIIC according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification.

Gustilo and Anderson's classification is the most commonly followed classification for open fractures.

An open fracture, with an arterial injury, that requires repair regardless of the size of the soft tissue wound, belongs to classification IIIC.

Related Pearl: Gustilo and Anderson classification for open fracture

Gustilo-Anderson's classification for open injuries    
Type Wound Level of contamination Soft tissue injury Bone injury
I <1 cm Clean Minimal Simple, minimal comminution
II >1 cm Moderate Moderate; some muscle damage Moderate comminution
IIIA usually >10 cm High Severe with crushing Usually comminuted; soft tissue coverage of bone possible
IIIB usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery
IIIC usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover; vascular injury requiring repair Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery


Management according to Gustilo-Anderson's classification:

Types Methods of fixation
Grade  I                                A technique that is suitable for closed fracture management i.e, debridement and internal fixation by intramedullary nail and plate  
Grade II, IIIA

Within 6hr same as grade I and after 6hr same as IIIB, IIIC
Grade IIIB, IIIC

Debridement and external fixation

questions.text: A  young patient presents with complaints of cramping abdominal pain and painless bright red bleeding in stools for the past 1 week. External and digital rectal examinations are normal. What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The first step in the workup of suspected lower GI bleed is to rule out the anorectal source of the bleed by digital rectal examination (DRE) and proctoscopy. Proctoscopy is a procedure used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum (up to 10 cm). Biopsy of the suspicious areas can be taken if needed.

Examination of the rectum:

- Visual inspection of the perineum
- Digital examination
- Proctoscopy
- Sigmoidoscopy – rigid and/or flexible

If the anorectal cause of bleeding is ruled out, it is important to eliminate an upper GI source through nasogastric (NG) aspiration or esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). An NG aspirate that contains bile and no blood effectively rules out upper tract bleeding in most patients.

Colonoscopy can be performed next when the anorectal or upper GI cause of bleeding is ruled out or if the extent of the hemorrhoid disease is incongruent with the patient’s symptoms, or if the patient has risk factors for colon cancer, such as a family history.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl has been deaf since birth. She now has symptoms suggesting hypothyroidism. Laboratory reports confirmed hypothyroidism and mutated SLC26A4 gene in her. Which of the following steps in the thyroid hormone biosynthesis is expected to be primarily defective in her?

choices.text: Internalisation of colloid into the follicular cells
Secretion of the thyroglobulin into the colloid
Iodide trapping and transport into the follicular cells
Iodide transport across the apical membrane in to the colloid

questions.solution:
The clues from the given clinical scenario such as congenital deafness, the mutation in the SLC26A4 gene, and hypothyroidism are highly suggestive of Pendred syndrome. Hence the transport of iodide across the apical membrane into the colloid is affected in this case.

Pendrin (coded by SLC26A4) is one of the members of the larger family of SLC26 anion exchangers. In the thyroid gland, it is located in the apical membrane of the follicular cell and transports iodide into the colloid in exchange for the chloride ion.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone:

  1. Thyroglobulin synthesis by thyroid follicular cells.
  2. Iodide trapping: Na+-I- symporter (NIS) actively transports I- into the follicular cells. This is inhibited by thiocyanate and perchlorate anions and is stimulated by TSH.
  3. Iodide is transported into the lumen of the follicle by I--Cl- transporter called pendrin.
  4. Oxidation of I- to I2 catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase (TPO).
  5. Organification/Iodination of tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin: Binding of I2  to tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin to form MIT (monoiodotyrosine) and DIT (diiodotyrosine). Catalyzed by TPO.
  6. Coupling reaction mediated by TPO: MIT + DIT → T3, DIT + DIT → T4.
  7. Storage and release: T3 and T4 are stored bound to thyroglobulin. When stimulated, they are cleaved from thyroglobulin and released into the circulation.

questions.text: The given image shows normal His Bundle Electrogram. The deflection shown by the arrow indicates _______
questions.solution:
The arrow mark shows V deflection of HBE which indicates ventricular depolarization.

His bundle electrogram (HBE):

The record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve is HBE. It shows 3 deflections as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes transmission through His bundle

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

PA interval

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of Parkinson disease on treatment for the past 10 years is complaining of hallucinations. From which of the following drugs, will the patient be benefited?
questions.solution:
Pimavanserin is an atypical antipsychotic approved for use in delusions and hallucinations associated with Parkinson’s disease.

It has a unique mechanism of action of antagonism and inverse agonism at 5-HT2A receptors with no action on dopamine receptors.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?
  1. Orphan drugs are drugs that are not used anymore.
  2. Orphan drugs are drugs for rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies.
  3. Orphan drugs act on orphan receptors.
  4. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified.
  5. Orphan receptors are receptors that do not serve any purpose.
questions.solution:
Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified.

There are two types of drug development. They are:

  • Traditional drug development: Initial drug discovery is followed by the characterization of the receptors the drugs are used to act on.
  • Contemporary drug development: Due to advances in molecular biology and genome sequencing, receptors are identified initially. These receptors do not have an endogenous mediator or ligand and are thus known as orphan receptors. However, they are potential targets for the development of new drugs, which can later be identified using chemical screening. 

Orphan drugs are drugs used for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases. Special incentives are given by the government to pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs. Examples of orphan drugs are:

  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Digoxin antibody (Digibind)
  • Fomepizole
